On behalf of the Executive Board, I should like to express our appreciation of the cooperation of the countries in the preparation of the second part of the Report. Not for Redistribution P A RT I ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution This page intentionally left blank ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution I. In troduc t ion1 Some of the most critical international mone­ tary developments of the entire period since World War II occurred during 1971. At the same time, the impressive expansion in world trade in recent years continued but at a slower pace with much of the impact felt—especially with respect to export prices—by the primary producing coun­ tries other than petroleum exporting countries. In terms of total value, the 1970-71 increase in world trade as measured by exports amounted to 12 per cent, compared with an increase of almost 15 per cent from 1969 to 1970. The difference resulted wholly from a slowdown in the rate of increase in the volume of world trade. The aver­ age rise in foreign trade prices—almost 6 per cent from 1970 to 1971—was as large as that of the previous year. For primary producing countries other than those exporting petroleum (the value of which was raised sharply by negotiated price increases), the 1970-71 rise in total export value is estimated to have been on the order of 7 per cent. Throughout the 1960s and early 1970s, the international monetary system became more and more affected by payments imbalances, in part resulting from growing international capital move­ ments. In addition, in several major industrial countries situations of fundamental disequilibrium emerged and were not corrected, or were cor­ rected only after a period of long delay, by changes in par values. In 1971, weaknesses in the balance of payments adjustment process cul­ minated in a series of far-reaching measures. In May 1971 Germany and the Netherlands informed the Fund that they would not ensure that the rates for exchange transactions involving the deutsche mark and the Netherlands guilder, respectively, within their territories would be con­ fined within the margins hitherto observed. Accordingly, the rates for exchange transactions involving the two currencies were allowed to float. The Canadian dollar had been floating since May 1970. At the same time that Germany and the Netherlands took the above steps, Switzerland and Austria revalued their currencies. On August 15, the United States announced that it would no 1 The period under review in this Report covers 1971 and the early part of 1972. longer, for the settlement of international trans­ actions, buy and sell gold freely under the second sentence of Article IV, Section 4(b) of the Articles of Agreement of the International Mone­ tary Fund and that a 10 per cent surcharge was temporarily being imposed on all dutiable imports not subject to mandatory quantitative limitations. Proposed were an accelerated investment tax credit to promote increased employment, to be effective from August 15, 1971 but not to be applicable to imported goods, and legislation providing for a new corporate entity that would afford to U. S. exporters more favorable tax treat­ ment. These proposals subsequently were enacted as the Job Development Investment Credit and the Domestic International Sales Corporation (D ISC ). In view of the developments that followed the action by the United States, the Fund called the attention of all its members to their undertakings under Article IV, Section 4(a) and requested that each member advise the Fund promptly and in detail of the exchange measures and practices applied in its territories. It was felt that, in general, the situation did not justify actions that would lead to new discriminatory currency arrangements, multiple currency practices, or restrictions on the making of payments and trans­ fers for current international transactions. When a member believed that it had an especially strong justification for the introduction of any such prac­ tices, the Fund was, of course, prepared to consult with the member. On October 1, 1971 the Board of Governors of the International Monetary Fund adopted a Resolution that called on members of the Fund to collaborate with the Fund and with each other in order, as promptly as possible, to (a) establish a satisfactory structure of exchange rates, maintained within appropriate margins, for the currencies of members, together with the reduc­ tion of restrictive trade and exchange practices, and (b) facilitate resumption of the orderly con­ duct of the operations of the Fund. Members were also called upon to collaborate with the Fund and with each other in efforts to bring about (a) a reversal of the tendency in present circumstances to maintain and extend restrictive trade and exchange practices, and (b) satisfactory arrange­ ments for the settlement of international trans- 1 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON E X C H A N GE RESTR ICT IONS actions which would contribute to the solution of the problems involved in the present international monetary situation. The Resolution also requested the Executive Directors of the Fund, inter alia, to make reports to the Board of Governors without delay on the measures necessary or desirable for the improvement or reform of the international monetary system (Resolution No. 26-9, adopted October 1, 1971). On December 18, the Ministers and Governors of the Group of T e n2 and Switzerland agreed on a new pattern of exchange rates among their curren­ cies. The Canadian dollar continued to float. After the agreement had been reached among the Group of Ten, the Executive Directors of the Fund adopted a decision "Central Rates and Wider Margins —A Temporary Regime" (Decision No. 3463-(7/126), December 18, 1971). On December 20, the United States eliminated the 10 per cent import surcharge and extended the provisions of the Job Development Investment Credit to imported goods. During the period August 15-December 18, 1971, of 118 member countries and three non- metropolitan territories of member countries, 73 had continued to apply their former fixed rates for the U. S. dollar (some, however, had slightly widened their margins for that currency). That group included certain countries that had intro­ duced a secondary free market (notably 15 countries of the French Franc Area) and 16 countries that had repegged their currencies from sterling to the U. S. dollar. The currencies of the remaining 48 countries and territories were float­ ing against the U. S. dollar, 20 as a result of having remained pegged to sterling and 26 independently. Of these 48 countries and terri­ tories, 31 had had an effective par value on August 15, 1971 in the sense that the main commercial rate was based on the par value. Despite the crisis in the international monetary system in 1971, there was only limited resort to increased use of exchange restrictions other than those resulting from multiple currency practices. Such restrictions as were adopted were primarily related to the slowing down of the growth of international trade, depressed or declining prices of primary products, and individual circumstances of some countries. 2 Countries which participate in the General Arrange­ ments to Borrow, viz., Belgium, Canada, France, Ger­ many, Italy, Japan, Netherlands, Sweden, United King­ dom, and United States. 2 There was, however, a marked movement toward increased use of multiple currency prac­ tices. Such practices were in some cases adopted as a means of influencing capital movements. They were also adopted, or their use increased, by several developing countries encountering balance of payments difficulties resulting from depressed export prices and/or expansionary domestic policies. In August, France introduced a dual market system, with an official market (in principle, for imports and exports, related inci­ dental expenses, and current official transactions) separated by exchange control supervision from a "financial" market (for all other transactions, including after October 20, foreign securities). The action by France was followed with minor modifications by all Operations Account coun­ tries 3 of the French Franc Area. In September, the Netherlands created a separate market for guilders representing the proceeds of listed guilder bonds sold by nonresidents to residents and required that further bond purchases by nonresidents be financed with such funds. Developing countries that adopted or increased their use of multiple currency practices included Argentina, Chile, Ecuador, and Ghana, among others. As mentioned above, after agreement on the realignment of their currencies was reached by the Group of Ten in December, the Executive Board of the Fund took a decision establishing a tem­ porary regime of central rates and wider margins, and indicating the practices that members may follow in the existing circumstances consistently with their obligations under Article IV, Section 4(a) of the Fund's Articles of Agreement and the Resolution of the Board of Governors referred to above. The intention of the decision was to enable members to observe the purposes of the Fund to the maximum extent possible during the period preceding the assumption of effective par values especially by the principal industrial countries, with appropriate margins in accordance with the Articles. A member which temporarily did not maintain rates based on a par value for its cur­ rency within the appropriate margins could com­ municate to the Fund as a central rate the new exchange value for its currency resulting from 3 Countries whose institutes of issue maintain an Operations Account with the French Treasury are Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Malagasy Republic, Ma l i, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A IN D E V E L O P M E N TS IN RESTR ICT IVE PRACT ICES realignment, and could permit the exchange rates for its currency to move within margins of 2XA per cent on either side of the par value or the central rate. Moreover, as long as a member took appro­ priate measures to maintain the exchange rates for its currency within 2XA per cent in terms of its intervention currency, it could permit the exchange rates for its currency in relation to currencies other than its intervention currency to move to a maximum of AV2 per cent. As provided in the decision, if a member of certain currency areas, e.g., the Sterling and French Franc Areas, main­ tained its currency within margins of 1 per cent of its intervention currency, it would be observing its obligations under the temporary regime. The decision also reiterated the Fund's position with respect to spreads between buying and selling rates for spot transactions involving a member's currency and the currency of other members, i.e., if a member establishes or tolerates a spread of more than 2 per cent it thereby introduces a multiple currency practice. In addition, members may not permit, under the decision, differential buying or selling rates for spot transactions, e.g., for different currencies or classes of commodities, or for current as against capital transfers, that the Fund regards as inconsistent with exchange stability. After the decision was adopted, members noti­ fied the Fund of any action taken by them with respect to par values, central rates, and wider margins. Many members decided that they would leave unchanged the par values of their currencies in terms of gold. Some members proposed changes in their par values while considerably more mem­ bers communicated central rates for their curren­ cies. Some 47 members indicated that they were availing themselves of the wider margins under the provisions of the decision establishing a tem­ porary regime of central rates and wider margins. During 1971, 3 countries—Fiji, Oman, and Western Samoa—became members of the Fund, raising total membership to 120 countries at the end of the year. This Report, and in particular the following sections, centers on exchange restrictions, but it also covers other measures and intergovernmental arrangements that may have direct balance of pay­ ments implications, such as import deposits, import surcharges, and measures to stimulate exports. II. Ma in Developments in Restrictive Practices 1. Trade and Payments Restrictions a. Restrictions on Imports and Import Payments The turbulence that occurred in the exchange markets in 1971 did not lead to any significant increase in quantitative restrictions on imports. Indeed, some industrialized countries reduced them. These countries also continued the process of liberalizing imports from member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance ( C M E A ) .4 However, certain industrial countries took measures designed to reduce the flow of imports. The most significant such developments were those taken by the United States on August 15, 1971, as mentioned in the Introduc­ tion. Denmark imposed a temporary surcharge of 10 per cent on commodities other than essential foodstuffs and raw materials. In addition, a num­ ber of industrial countries increased their resort to negotiated agreements to limit specified exports to them by their trading partners. These are of particular importance with respect to exports of textiles to the United States from the Republic of China, Hong Kong, Japan, and Korea, and also for exports of steel and steel products from the countries of the European Economic Community ( E E C )5 and Japan. Among other developed countries, New Zealand liberalized a further 200 import items and announced that over a five-year period quantita­ tive restrictions would be almost wholly eliminated. South Africa, however, intensified its quantitative restrictions. Although most of the developing countries felt constrained by balance of payments considera­ tions and did not relax import restrictions to any significant extent, a number of them, including Cameroon, Colombia, the Republic of China, the Khmer Republic, Singapore, and the Syrian Arab Republic, relaxed quantitative restrictions on imports. In the Khmer Republic, quantitative restrictions were abolished as part of a reform of the exchange and trade system that was intro- 4 Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Rumania, and U. S. S. R. 5 The members of the E EC are Belgium, France, Ger­ many, Italy, Luxembourg, and Netherlands. 3 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON E X C H A N GE RESTR ICT IONS duced in October, but to expedite aid utilization an exclusive import list was set up for certain essential commodities that might be imported only when financed with foreign aid. Countries which have tightened controls in respect of certain categories of imports or pay­ ments for imports during the course of the year included Algeria, Argentina, Ceylon, Chile, Ghana, India, Kenya, Mexico, Peru, Tanzania, and Uganda. In some cases the tightening of con­ trols took the form of prohibitions while in others there were additions to lists of commodities requiring prior approval. Argentina prohibited temporarily the opening of letters of credit for all imports. Ceylon raised from 6 months to 12 months the minimum deferred payments terms for private sector imports of specified commodities. Nigeria introduced a system of 90-day and 180- day deferred import payments. Payments arrears with respect to imports and invisibles were eliminated in Haiti in 1971 and with respect to imports in Nigeria in early 1972. The Sudan and the Syrian Arab Republic adopted programs to reduce their payments arrears. Other countries which continue to have such arrears include the Dominican Republic, Ghana, Para­ guay, and Uruguay. Costa Rica, which had been free of arrears, incurred new ones. D iscr im inat ion against member countries through quantitative import restrictions appears, on balance, to have been reduced again, as reli­ ance on bilateral trade and payments arrange­ ments was reduced further. In addition a number of member countries have ceased to invoke Article X X XV of the G A TT in respect of Japan or have eased the import licensing treatment accorded to Japan. Discrimination was reduced also owing to the relaxation by some member countries of re­ strictions on imports from state trading countries in Eastern Europe and Asia. An important development in commercial policy was the introduction of generalized tariff preferences on selected commodities (generally manufactures and semimanufactures) originating in developing countries by the E EC countries, Denmark, Finland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden, and the United Kingdom. Australia further expanded the coverage of its existing duty preferences for developing countries. b. Restrictions on Current Invisibles During 1971 France on several occasions increased the exchange allocations for tourist 4 travel, and since January 1, 1972 all bona fide requests for travel exchange are being granted. A number of Operations Account countries also relaxed their restrictions on the availability of foreign exchange for tourist travel. Japan, which did not restrict travel exchange, again increased the automatic allocations which authorized banks may make available without reference to the Bank of Japan. In New Zealand, the Reserve Bank announced that all reasonable requests for exchange for bona fide travel purposes would be granted. Restrictions on travel exchange were intro­ duced or tightened in several member countries. These included Argentina, Chile, Tanzania, Uganda, Uruguay, and Zambia. Argentina reduced allocations for foreign travel selectively and it and Uruguay limited the amount of foreign banknotes that may be exported as part of the total of foreign exchange available for travel pur­ poses. Panama and Peru imposed taxes on for­ eign travel, and Bolivia in 1971 temporarily levied a progressive travel tax that could go as high as $b 10,000 (about US$800) a trip depend­ ing on the number of trips a traveler made. A number of countries again revised their limits on the permitted import or export of domes­ tic currency notes, including Chile, Kenya, New Zealand, Tanzania, Uganda, and Yugoslavia. Chile subjected the importation of domestic cur­ rency notes to a 10,000 per cent advance deposit requirement, and their exportation to export licensing procedures. In 1970 France had resumed the practice of redeeming domestic banknotes when presented to the Bank of France by banks abroad; after the creation of a dual market, France accepted such banknotes for redemption only for credit to a Financial Account, and most Opera­ tions Account countries took similar action. With respect to payments for other current invisibles, the following were some of the main developments. Argentina closed its exchange market for several days in March 1971, and then gradually opened it up again for current invisibles, but not for remittances of profits, dividends, and royalties. In September, however, persons wishing to effect such remittances were permitted to pur­ chase negotiable and exportable five-year bonds issued by the Government and denominated in U. S. dollars. The Dominican Republic increased the allowances for education abroad, and resumed the granting of exchange for family remittances and medical expenses abroad. Upper Volta and ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A IN D E V E L O P M E N TS IN RESTR ICT IVE PRACT ICES some other Operations Account countries increased the exchange allocations for such purposes as study abroad. The United States lifted its prohibi­ tion on financial transactions with mainland China. Among countries taking steps to restrict pay­ ments for invisibles other than travel expendi­ ture, Chile further reduced allocations for a con­ siderable number of current payments. Zaire limited the transfer abroad of earnings by foreign professionals to one half of such monthly earnings after taxes. Zambia introduced a restriction on profit and dividend remittances, limiting such remittances to an amount not exceeding 30 per cent of equity capital and provided that the 30 per cent did not exceed one half of net profits. 2. Multiple Currency Practices The August 15 measures made it impossible for some countries to observe the legal margins around par and any multiple currency practices consequent to those measures have not been included in this review. However, the Fund main­ tained the customary degree of surveillance over multiple currency practices and other measures that were at variance with members' obligations under the Articles of Agreement. Simplification of exchange rate structures took place in Ghana, the Khmer Republic, and Viet- Nam. Ghana, during the period under review, first introduced several multiple currency practices but, when devaluing its currency at the end of 1971, abolished the foreign exchange bonus scheme and the exchange taxes. Subsequently, when it informed the Fund early in 1972 that a rate less depreciated than the new par value would be applied to international transactions, no new mul­ tiple currency practices were introduced. In the Khmer Republic all multiple currency practices were eliminated and a flexible unitary rate was established, but in January 1972 a dual rate sys­ tem was introduced based on an exchange rate for aid imports and another for all other transac­ tions. Viet-Nam, which had an exchange rate structure comprising an official market and a parallel market, introduced a three-tier rate struc­ ture within the latter; this proliferation of rates was offset to some extent by the elimination of exchange taxes and exchange subsidies. Among countries that modified existing multi­ ple rate systems, Chile introduced additional rates in the banking and brokers' exchange markets and increased existing exchange taxes in the latter. Uruguay introduced a new multiple exchange rate system by imposing and gradually increasing cer­ tain "commissions" on foreign exchange sold to the public; there also were many changes in exchange taxes on exports. In March 1972 the rate structure was considerably simplified, with a greatly depreciated official rate for the U. S. dol­ lar. Venezuela, while maintaining its multiple currency rate structure, appreciated each of the effective exchange rates slightly in terms of the U. S. dollar. Turkey continued to apply a special buying rate to the export proceeds of certain tra­ ditional agricultural commodities. Argentina, Costa Rica, and Ecuador each rein­ troduced a secondary exchange market. The Argentine free market rate initially was confined to financial transactions, but soon was used also as a mixing rate for trade transactions. Among countries operating a flexible exchange rate policy and maintaining multiple currency practices, Brazil and Colombia continued to depreciate their currencies from time to time, without otherwise changing their multiple rate systems. In the Philippines, where the rate had been stabilized in late September 1970, the peso appreciated slightly in mid-1971; later in the year, however, it depreciated to its previous level. Korea, another developing country with a flexible rate policy, does not have multiple currency practices. The rate for the won depreciated in the first half of 1971 and ir the first half of 1972. Following the August 15 measures, France, as indicated above, established a dual exchange market and the Operations Account countries took similar action. In October, the security currency market in France was merged into the financial franc market. The operation of the investment currency market in the United Kingdom did not undergo much change during the period under review, but in March 1972 important changes in capital con­ trols were announced which affected, inter alia, the method of financing certain direct investments abroad that might previously have had to be made with investment currency (see section 5, Measures Affecting Capital, below). The Netherlands created a security currency market in September by prescribing that nonresidents could acquire listed guilder bonds only with the proceeds from the sale of such bonds by nonresidents to resi­ dents. The O-guilder in this so-called bond circuit has consistently been at a small premium. There were two major changes in the operation of the exchange markets in the Belgium-Luxem- 5 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON E X C H A N GE RESTR ICT IONS bourg Economic Union (BLEU ). With effect from May 11, 1971, the official exchange market and the free market were separated completely and the governing regulations were modified so that foreign currencies, which previously could not go to a discount in the free market, henceforth could go to a discount as well as to a premium in that market. On August 23 the B L EU floated the franc rate in the official market. At the same time, the B L EU and the Netherlands began a "joint float"; under this policy (relating in the B L EU to the official market only) the rates for their currencies were not allowed to deviate from the previous cross-parities by more than 1.5 per cent in either direction, the same maximum deviation previously permitted under the margins notified by these countries under the European Monetary Agree­ ment ( E M A ). This policy was continued after the general realignment of currencies which took place after December 18, 1971. 3. Import Deposits, Import Surcharges, and Measures to Stimulate Exports of deposit for countries of the Latin American Free Trade Association ( L A F T A ). b. Import Surcharges The most significant development concerning import surcharges in 1971 was the temporary imposition by the United States on August 15 of a 10 per cent surcharge on all dutiable imports not subject to mandatory quantitative restrictions, and its subsequent removal on December 20, 1971. Denmark late in 1971 imposed a temporary surcharge of 10 per cent on commodities other than essential foodstuffs and raw materials. Among developing countries, Ghana, when devaluing its currency at the end of 1971, abol­ ished the temporary surcharges introduced in 1970. On the other hand, Argentina, India, and Zambia introduced import surcharges; the Argen­ tine ones were eliminated in early 1972. Hon­ duras introduced special surcharges on imports from Japan, and Yugoslavia, after reducing its temporary import surcharge from 5 per cent to 2 per cent, raised it again to 6 per cent. a. Advance Import Deposits c. Export Incentives and Export Taxes A number of developing countries, including Colombia and El Salvador, acted to facilitate imports by relaxing their advance import deposits. Iran lowered the advance import deposit rate on certain food imports from 100 per cent to 15 per cent. Israel at the beginning of 1971 reduced the advance import deposit rate from 50 per cent to 40 per cent of the c.i.f. value, and a year later to 30 per cent. Spain first reduced and then abol­ ished its advance deposit requirement. Turkey lowered certain guarantee deposit rates in Janu­ ary 1971. Yugoslavia in the same month abol­ ished the advance import deposit requirements, which had been reduced previously on two occasions. Other countries increased their reliance on advance import deposits to restrain imports. Chile subjected additional imports to a 10,000 per cent advance deposit requirement when imported by the private sector, and then by granting individual exemptions from the requirement used it as a sub­ stitute for import licensing controls. Korea intro­ duced advance import deposits on imports of raw materials that were also produced locally. Advance import deposits were introduced in Uganda in November 1971, and Uruguay tripled its prepay­ ment deposit requirement for some imports in September 1971, while retaining preferential rates 6 Late in 1971 the United States introduced a DISC Export Tax Deferral Program, whereby companies adopting DISC (Domestic Interna­ tional Sales Corporation) status would be granted tax deferral privileges on 50 per cent of their gross export income. The United Kingdom per­ mitted authorized banks to make foreign currency loans for specified trade purposes without a minimum repayment period to exporters, mer­ chants, and firms authorized to trade on com­ modity exchanges. In addition, U. K. exporters tendering for overseas contracts were invited to apply for forward exchange cover in respect of a tender or of foreign components included in a tender price. The rate charged on medium-term and long-term finance for exports other than ships was reduced. A number of industrial countries, including Japan, took steps to prevent the unduly early surrender of foreign exchange proceeds from exports in the expectation of exchange rate changes. France required that export proceeds when sold before the due date had to be sold in the financial franc market. The surrender require­ ments for export proceeds were suspended in Norway. In view of the wider fluctuations of exchange rates, certain industrial countries, such as France and Germany, took steps to provide ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A IN D E V E L O P M E N TS IN RESTR ICT IVE PRACT ICES exchange rate guarantees to exporters for exchange rate risks that could not be covered by existing banking facilities. A number of developing countries, including Argentina and Brazil, further modified or extended their fiscal export incentives. Mexico introduced a provision that manufacturers were entided to full remission of duties on imported inputs and full reimbursement of the indirect domestic federal taxes levied when a product was exported. Panama granted exemption from profit and property taxes to enterprises manufacturing solely for export. The Syrian Arab Republic used its Fund for the Development of Industrial Exports to subsidize exports of cotton textiles. Uruguay revoked the 14 per cent export tax; export retention rates were reduced, and tax refunds for some exports were revised upward. Among other measures designed to encourage exports, Argentina introduced a preferential mix­ ing rate for "promoted" exports at the time the dual market was established but eliminated it when the country devalued the peso in March 1972. In Egypt, proceeds of certain agricultural exports received a 35 per cent exchange premium. Ceylon introduced import duty rebates for speci­ fied industrial exports. 4. Bilateral Payments Arrangements Further progress has been achieved in the elimination of bilateral payments arrangements by member countries. Spain terminated its pay­ ments agreements with Czechoslovakia, Mexico, Morocco, Paraguay, Poland, and Yugoslavia. Austria placed its trade with Bulgaria, Czecho­ slovakia, Hungary, Poland, and the U. S. S. R. on a convertible currency basis, leaving Rumania as the only country with which it still maintains a bilateral payments arrangement. Yugoslavia abol­ ished the bilateral payments arrangements with Guinea, Ma l i, Spain, and Turkey; and Ma li ter­ minated its arrangement with Bulgaria. The Belgium-Luxembourg Economic Union and the Netherlands terminated their last remaining pay­ ments agreements, those with the U. S. S. R. Thus, 7 bilateral payments arrangements between mem­ bers were terminated during the period under review, leaving some 50 in force, compared with about 80 at the end of 1967. In addition, more than 10 bilateral payments arrangements with nonmember countries were abolished, but these still number over 200. Fund members have become increasingly aware of the disadvantages of bilateral payments arrangements. For some time now, there has also been growing evidence that nonmember countries are turning away from an earlier preference for strict bilateral clearing arrangements in international settlements. 5. Measures Affecting Capital In the turbulent exchange market conditions prevailing in mid-1971, measures to control capi­ tal movements were widespread among industri­ alized countries. A good many of these measures were revoked or eased after the December cur­ rency realignment, but a second wave of controls occurred early in 1972. In most cases, the meas­ ures were designed to limit an undesired accumu­ lation of foreign exchange reserves and to reduce the domestic monetary effects of inflows of exchange. This often had the effect of turning around the operation of exchange control, which previously had aimed primarily at preventing unauthorized capital outflows; where such a reversal occurred, there usually was also a relaxa­ tion of restraints over capital outflows, but the easing tended to follow with a certain time lag or to be limited to specified types of transactions. Among the measures taken to offset the domestic monetary effects of inward capital movements, the majority have affected the operations of domestic banking systems, but measures of a monetary nature have also been taken in the non- banking sector, e.g., by restricting the acquisition by nonresidents of domestic money market paper or bonds. Another instrument employed for dis­ couraging excessive capital inflows has been the dual exchange market (see section 2, Multiple Currency Practices, above), and some countries have relaxed exchange restrictions or other con­ trols to stimulate outflows, e.g., by admitting for­ eign bond issues on the domestic capital market. The controls introduced over the banking sys­ tem have comprised direct limitations on the acceptance of nonresident deposits by banks and other financial institutions and, more generally, on the banks' external positions. Among the countries which either introduced or modified such controls were Austria, Belgium-Luxembourg, France, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom. In France, banks were instructed on August 3 to prevent any deterioration in their overall net external position in francs and foreign currency; the banks were therefore led to verify the purpose underlying purchases of francs against foreign currencies, so as to ensure that the 7 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON E X C H A N GE RESTR ICT IONS transaction was not motivated by speculative rea­ sons. In September, the rule prohibiting banks from maintaining a positive net foreign currency position in excess of that of September 3, 1968 was rescinded, and on December 20 the limita­ tions on the banks' net external liabilities were revoked. Shordy before the currency realignment, nonresidents were temporarily prevented from purchasing French short-term securities. Controls on banks' net external positions were also applied in Italy where banks were required to maintain a balanced net position after September 15. Japan restricted external borrowing by commercial banks. The United Kingdom prohibited financial nonbanking institutions and local authorities from accepting further sterling deposits or loans from non-Sterling Area residents, and temporarily pre­ vented nonresidents from purchasing certain domestic securities. In Austria, credits to schil­ ling accounts resulting from the conversion of foreign exchange by nonresidents which did not arise from current transactions were made sub­ ject to the prior approval of the central bank; the "gentlemen's agreement" of August 1971, designed to prevent foreign borrowing by banks, was extended in February 1972, when banks were in addition requested to appeal to their large cus­ tomers not to borrow abroad. In the period March-September, Belgium required banks to exercise restraint in undertaking operations that were likely to increase their net foreign debtor positions; in March 1972, the external position of banks in Belgium and Luxembourg was made sub­ ject to limitation. Also in March 1972, the Netherlands forbade the placement of guilders on nonresident time deposit accounts or the renewal of such accounts, as well as the payment of inter­ est on nonresident sight deposits, both, however, subject to a limited exemption for private indi­ viduals. Capital controls directed at operations of domestic banking systems have also included indirect measures. These have been designed to reduce the profitability of utilizing foreign funds domestically and to limit the incentives that banks could offer to attract foreign capital. Among such measures, changes in reserve requirements for banks' external liabilities and restrictions on the maintenance of interest-bearing deposit accounts by nonresidents were the most important. Selec­ tive reserve requirements against banks' liabilities to nonresidents have been either intensified or introduced in Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, 8 and Spain. In Belgium, banks had to make special deposits in Belgian francs for the amount by which they exceeded the limit fixed on their net foreign debtor position. France raised the reserve requirement against nonresident franc deposits in May and again in August 1971; in Germany the special reserve requirement applied since Decem­ ber 1970 against increases in banks' liabilities to nonresidents was raised in June 1971 to twice the requirement ratios set for residents' deposes; moreover, when reserve requirements against banks' liabilities to residents were reduced by 10 percentage points later in the year, the require­ ments applicable to the banks' liabilities to non­ residents were left unchanged. In France, com­ mercial banks discontinued, with effect from August 11, payment of interest on nonresident- held term deposits of less than 90 days denomi­ nated in francs; previously, only sight deposits did not bear interest. The prohibition was rescinded after realignment. Partial or complete suspension of interest payments on balances in nonresident accounts was also introduced in Germany and the Netherlands in May, in Spain in October, and in Italy in December. The United Kingdom pro­ hibited payment of interest on any increases accruing after August 31 in nonresidents' balances on external sterling accounts; certain categories of such accounts were subsequently exempted from this provision and the prohibition was lifted on December 20. Some member countries have imposed direct limitations on the domestic utilization of nonresi­ dent funds as a disincentive to the attraction of further amounts of foreign capital. The United Kingdom took similar measures in January 1971 primarily to restrict domestic credit, but during the last few months of 1971 the conversion of foreign currency into sterling on a swap basis was also severely restricted. Some countries have also introduced capital controls of a monetary nature that are focused primarily on the nonbanking sector. They included France, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom. France took measures to restrict the acquisition by nonresidents of domes­ tic short-term securities effective only from December 3 to December 20, and also to limit long-term borrowing abroad. Germany required nonresidents to obtain approval from the mone­ tary authorities for the purchase of domestic money market paper. Moreover, in December 1971 a Cash Deposit Law was enacted which ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution M A IN D E V E L O P M E N TS IN RESTR ICT IVE PRACT ICES aimed at discouraging capital inflows by large companies in order to strengthen the effectiveness of domestic monetary policy. The Law enables the Government to require enterprises to make interest-free deposits of up to 50 per cent of their specified outstanding foreign liabilities and the requirement may be made retroactive. These powers were invoked on March 1, retroactive to January 1, 1972, and the rate of deposit was set at 40 per cent. In France, Japan, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom temporary prohibitions were introduced on the acquisition by nonresi­ dents of specified domestic securities, including treasury bills and other short-term paper. Among the industrialized countries, Belgium- Luxembourg, France, and the Netherlands used dual exchange markets as a means of stemming capital inflows (see section 2, Multiple Currency Practices, above). Among the countries which relaxed exchange controls or transaction controls to stimulate capi­ tal outflows were France, Japan, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom. France increased the standard allocations for various capital transfers, such as those of emigrants' assets, and authoriza­ tion of direct investments abroad became con­ siderably more liberal. Furthermore, the prior declaration requirement for direct investments in or from E EC countries was abolished early in 1971, when such investments remained subject to exchange control only. Foreign bond issues had not been authorized for a number of years, but in 1971 the authorities allowed bond issues by the Inter-American Development Bank and the Euro­ pean Coal and Steel Community to be placed on the French capital market. Also an incentive scheme was introduced chiefly for new direct investment in the Operations Account countries; in the course of 1971 it was announced that, sub­ ject to the negotiation of bilateral investment agreements, the incentives would also apply to investments in Mauritius and Zaire. Japan relaxed restrictions on long-term capital outflows of resident-owned funds, particularly in the form of direct investment purchases of foreign securities by institutional investors as well as by other resi­ dents, and the acquisition of real estate abroad by residents. Also for the first time certain foreign loan issues were permitted on the Japanese capital market, beginning with international institutions. At the same time, in conformity wtih previous liberalization plans, restrictions on long-term inward direct investment were further relaxed. In Apr il 1972, the Netherlands gave permission to Netherlands institutional investors to lend to non­ residents on the market for privately placed loans. The United Kingdom announced a time schedule for the progressive dismantling of the controls over portfolio and direct investment in E EC countries as well as personal capital transfers to the Community. In March 1972 a number of capital controls were abolished or relaxed. The program of voluntary restraint on direct and port­ folio investment in the more developed countries of the overseas Sterling Area (Australia, Ireland, New Zealand, and South Africa) was terminated. Official exchange rather than other methods of finance (for example, involving the use of the more expensive investment currency) was granted, subject to a limit of £ 1 million a project a year, for all new approved direct investments in mem­ ber countries of the E EC and in Denmark and Norway. Unlimited sterling borrowing in the U. K. market was normally to be allowed (a) by U. K. companies controlled by residents of the eight indicated countries; (b) by U. K. companies in which any nonresidents have less than a con­ trolling interest; and (c) for new expenditure in development areas and similar regions, by U. K. companies controlled by any nonresidents. The U. K. Treasury ceased to grant exchange rate guarantees on loans taken up outside the Sterling Area by public sector bodies. Denmark facilitated capital inflows by relaxing restrictions on nonresident purchases in the domes­ tic bond market and by easing resident access to foreign borrowing, and early in 1972, Sweden eased the restrictions on purchases by residents of Swedish securities held abroad, as well as those on exports of capital by emigrants. The United States maintained its mandatory foreign direct investment controls and the volun­ tary program for the restraint of foreign credits by banks and other financial institutions. On Apr il 1, 1971, the Interest Equalization Tax was extended to March 31, 1973. The coverage of the voluntary program was narrowed when export credit was, late in 1971, exempted from the ceil­ ings. In December 1971, direct investors who had foreign claims in excess of the amount permitted under the ceiling for 1971, as established under the mandatory program, were permitted to post­ pone until the end of February 1972 the repatria­ tion of these funds to comply with the program ceilings for 1971. The developing countries, on the whole, did ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON E X C H A N GE RESTR ICT IONS not relax restrictions on capital outflows. The operation of existing dual market structures and of newly introduced or modified multiple cur­ rency practices in many instances had the effect of making any permitted outflows more expensive; in a number of these cases the outflows were limited essentially to nonresident-owned capital. The extension of exchange control to formerly exempt areas (see below) has involved a widen­ ing in the geographical scope of existing restric­ tions on capital outflows. As regards inflows, a number of developing countries have again found it necessary to impose limitations on the accept­ ance of suppliers' credit, while others increased their reliance on foreign financing of their imports, e.g., by prescribing the use of suppliers' credit for specified minimum periods. A few developing countries, such as Iran, Ivory Coast, Mexico, Singapore, and Venezuela, have successfully placed public sector bonds or notes in the Euro­ dollar or Asian-dollar markets. In Singapore the size of the Asian-dollar market grew sufficiently in 1971 for the authorities to allow two Asian- dollar note or bond issues. Two Sterling Area countries, Guyana and Jamaica, extended exchange control to the rest of the Sterling Area, and the Libyan Arab Repub­ lic ceased to be a member of the Sterling Area. Early in 1971 Tanzania extended exchange con­ trol to Kenya and Uganda, following similar action by the latter countries in 1970. 6. Gold Regulations governing nonofficial transactions in gold remained unchanged in most countries. In the United Kingdom, the restrictions on the buying, holding, and selling of gold coins that had been imposed during 1966 were revoked, and the ban on the use of gold for making medallions was lifted. Ireland also allowed residents to buy, hold, and sell gold coins. Austria eased further the liberal regulations on dealing in gold coins by residents and allowed travelers to export gold coins up to a specified weight or value. The United States took steps to prevent a domestic futures market for gold coins from being estab­ lished. Trading in gold coins was suspended by Mexico in August 1971 but was resumed early in 1972. III. Regional Arrangements During the period of review, the European Economic Community entered into a number of 10 new agreements with associated and third coun­ tries. On January 1, 1971 the Second Yaounde Convention with the African and Malagasy Asso­ ciated States 6 entered into force, as did the sec­ ond Association Agreement with the countries of the East African Community. On Apr il 1, 1971 the Association Agreement with Malta entered into force. An interim agreement with Turkey, which is to lead eventually to a customs union, entered into force on September 1, 1971. Important steps were taken during 19^71 toward the enlargement of the E EC to include the United Kingdom, Ireland, Denmark, and Norway. By January 15, 1972 all outstanding issues with these countries had been settled and the four applicant countries formally signed the acts of membership on January 22, 1972. The common external tariff of the E EC became operative on January 1, 1971, together with the implementation of the fourth of the five duty reductions agreed upon in the Kennedy Round. As of July 1, 1971 the EEC 's generalized prefer­ ences for developing countries, covering manu­ factured and semimanufactured products and some processed farm goods, became effective. The preferences applied to 91 developing coun­ tries. On February 1, 1971 a common fisheries policy entered into force. The EEC 's Commission pre­ sented in February 1971 proposals for a new orientation for agricultural policy, seeking to establish a link between agricultural structures and prices. A modified version of the proposals was adopted in March 1972. In June, the adoption of complementary regulations in the dairy sector entered into force; this implied that henceforth dairy products would move freely within the E E C. The valuation of the unit of account used under the common agricultural policy presented certain problems following the exchange crises of May and August. A system of border adjustments adopted in May 1971 and elaborated early in 1972 was used as an interim solution. In the previous Report, it was noted that the Council of the E EC decided in February 1971 to move in stages toward the creation of an eco­ nomic and monetary union. The Report also made reference to the system of short-term monetary 6 Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Malagasy Republic, M a l i, Mauritania, Niger, Rwanda, Senegal, Somalia, Togo, Upper Volta, and Zaire. On September 9, 1971 Mauritius applied for accession to the Yaounde Convention. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REG IONAL A R R A N G EM E N TS support set up in 1970 and to a new medium-term monetary support system which was to come into effect on January 1, 1972. Under the medium- term system the member states would have to con­ sult their E EC partners before seeking medium- term assistance. During the first three years credit would be granted for a maximum of two to three years but after that the period would be two to five years. The rate of interest would be halfway between that charged by the International Mone­ tary Fund and the current market rate. Progress toward a monetary union was hampered in 1971, first by the floating of the deutsche mark and the Netherlands guilder in May, and then by the emergency measures with respect to exchange rates and capital controls that were introduced in E EC countries and elsewhere after August 15. Within the E E C, discussions centered on exchange rate margins and the desirability of capital con­ trols. In May the Council agreed to allow under certain conditions a widening of the fluctuation band of E EC currencies, and in June the Com­ mission presented a plan for measures to deal with international capital flows. On November 4, 1971 a Ministerial Conference of the E EC confirmed certain principles on which the exchange systems of the E EC countries should be based, including a return to fixed parities; it also recommended the adoption of measures to combat destabilizing capital movements. Following realignment and the Fund's decision on wider margins, the E EC resumed its efforts toward early monetary and economic integration. Discussions were held aiming at agreement on ways to limit the exchange rate fluctuations between E EC currencies by prescribing consid­ erably narrower margins than those that could result from the application of the new 2.25 per cent limits against the U. S. dollar. Related prob­ lems that were subjected to review were the modalities of intervention in the exchange markets, notably as to the currencies to be used for this purpose and the financing of support operations, and again the desirability of capital controls. On March 7, 1972 the Finance Ministers agreed on the following. a. The central banks of the E EC countries will reduce progressively the existing fluctuation mar­ gins between the currencies of the E EC while using fully the margins allowed by the Fund for the currencies of nonmember countries. By July 1, 1972 at the latest, the fluctuation band among the E EC currencies is to be reduced to 2.25 per cent or 1.125 per cent above or below their new official values. If exchange rates for E EC currencies reach the fluctuation limits within the narrow band of 2.25 per cent, the central banks will inter­ vene in E EC currencies. The intervention will be in U. S. dollars if the rate of the dollar on the currency market concerned reaches the fluctua­ tion limits authorized by the Fund. Prior agree­ ment among the E EC central banks will be required for any intervention inside the 4.5 per cent band permitted for the U. S. dollar. The central banks will settle debts resulting from operations in the currencies of the E EC within a period of one month but this period may be extended if experience shows it to be necessary. The method of settlement will depend on the structure of the debtor country's monetary reserves. b. The EEC 's Monetary Committee and the Committee of Central Bank Governors are to report by June 30, 1972 on the organization and functions of a European monetary cooperation fund to coordinate central bank market interven­ tion and harmonize reserve policies. c. Within the Council of Ministers of the E E C, a coordinating group of high-ranking national and commission officials will be set up for the coordi­ nation of short-term economic and financial policies. The Council on March 21, 1972 confirmed this agreement and also adopted the proposals made by the Commission for the regulation of short-term capital flows and the neutralization of their impact on E EC economies. Members would accordingly be enabled to regulate short-term money market investment by nonresidents, to control international borrowing operations other than those in support of commercial transactions, and to introduce obligatory reserve requirements, in particular in respect of nonresident-owned holdings of E EC currencies. The Council Resolu­ tion of March 21 was implemented on Apr il 24, 1972, when the member countries began to apply narrower margins for dealing in each other's currencies. Following the December currency realignment, the E EC and the United States pursued their dis­ cussions regarding immediate and longer-term trade matters. In February 1972 agreement was reached regarding wheat, feedgrains, and citrus fruit. With regard to the first two items, the E EC agreed to augment its stocks of wheat and to operate its system of export payments on grains 11 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON E X C H A N GE RESTR ICT IONS so as not to divert trade in its favor, while the United States agreed to stockpile 10 per cent of its production of grains and to withhold additional land from wheat and grain production. With regard to citrus fruit, the E EC agreed on a reduc­ tion of duty on a number of items. It was also agreed to initiate and support a comprehensive review of trade matters. Furthermore, the United States and the E EC agreed to call for a multi­ lateral review of trade matters, to take place in 1973 within the framework of the G A T T. This move was supported by a similar joint statement by Japan and the United States. Developments in the European Free Trade Association ( E F T A )7 were dominated by the negotiations, first for accession to the E EC by the United Kingdom and by Denmark, Ireland, and Norway, and then for special agreements with the E EC by those E F TA members that are not candidates for accession to the E E C. Within E F T A, the examination of nontariff barriers was continued, and three new agreements to end such obstacles to trade in specified categories of goods were concluded during the period July 1970- June 1971. None of these agreements is intended to be limited to E F TA countries. One of the major preoccupations of E F TA is how to pre­ serve free trade between the present E F TA coun­ tries even after some of them join the E E C. The Council of Ministers for Asian Economic Cooperation at their meeting in Kabul in Decem­ ber 1970 had called for the establishment of special committees to pursue trade and monetary cooperation in the countries of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East ( E C A F E ). Pursuant to this, the Preparatory Committee for the Establishment of an Asian Clearing Union was convened in March 1971 and adopted a Draft Agreement for the Asian Clearing Union. The Intergovernmental Committee on Trade met in November 1971 and studied the scope for con­ cessions in the context of regional trade expan­ sion. It agreed to meet again at some future date to consider further the question of trade conces­ sions. In the East African Community, Tanzania, in an effort to stem the decline in its foreign exchange reserves, imposed restrictions on capital exports, 7 The present members are Austria, Denmark, Iceland, Norway, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland, and United Kingdom. Similar measures were adopted in the same month by Kenya, thus effectively suspending the free move­ ment of capital within the East African Commu­ nity. The range of functions exercised by the three central banks was broadened further. In Central America further difficulties arose regarding the operation of the Central American* Common Market ( C A C M ). At the end of 1970 Honduras had suspended its full participation in the C A CM by imposing tariffs on all imports from the region and suspending the surcharge on imports from outside the area. In response, Guate­ mala, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica imposed tariffs on all imports from Honduras, as authorized by the common market treaty. At a meeting of all members, except Honduras, a Normalization Commission was created to settle certain problems concerning trade in staples and to prepare pro­ posals for restoring the full operation of the Com­ mon Market. At its meeting in October 1971 agreement was reached on the specific trade prob­ lems and on a formula to resume free trade. On May 1, 1971 British Honduras became a member of the Caribbean Free Trade Associa­ tion ( C A R I F T A ) .8 At the Ninth Ministerial Meeting of the Council of Ministers of C A R I F TA in October 1971, the question of a common external tariff and the harmonization of fiscal incentives were discussed but no agreement was reached. In the Andean Group 9 a foreign investment code was ratified and became effective on July 1, 1971. Under this code a common policy is estab­ lished for the treatment of foreign capital, the import of technology, patents, trademarks, and the repatriation of profits, royalties, and interest. The new investment code has been ratified by all the member countries except Colombia, where it was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court. Not for Redistribution Explanatory Note to Country Surveys In Part II, individual surveys of the exchange systems of the member countries of the Fund, including three nonmetropolitan territories, are given. The exchange system of one other coun­ try which was not a member of the Fund at the time this Report was written is also described. In general, the surveys relate to the exchange systems as at the end of 1971. For a few countries the surveys relate to the exchange systems at a later date or include references to significant developments which took place early in 1972. The description of an exchange system is not necessarily confined to those aspects involving exchange restrictions or exchange controls. As in previous Reports, questions of definition and juris­ diction have not been raised, and an attempt has been made to describe restrictive systems in their entirety, except for the tariff structure and, in most cases, direct taxes on exports and imports. Thus, the surveys include references to such features as import licensing, advance deposit requirements, import surcharges, travel taxes, export licensing, and export incentive schemes. Similarly, the sec­ tion "Changes during 1971" may include refer­ ences to certain developments that have a direct impact on international transactions but are not reflected in the body of the survey, such as major revisions of import tariffs or developments relating to regional cooperation. A standardized framework has been employed in drafting the surveys: each system is described under similar headings, and each country survey contains a final section that lists chronologically the more significant changes which took place in the restrictive system during 1971. An indication of the subject matter to be found under these headings is given in the following paragraphs. Under Exchange Rate System, the par value and/or the central rate and/or the official exchange rates are given, the latter usually in terms of the U. S. dollar, together with a refer­ ence to other rates which may be essential to the country's exchange rate system. In the surveys of certain countries with multiple exchange rate sys­ tems, further details are given in the Table of Exchange Rates (see below). The rates quoted are those effective on December 31, 1971, unless stated otherwise. Under Exchange Control Territory, the extent of applicability of the exchange control is ex­ plained when it covers two or more sovereign or autonomous territories whose residents have com­ mon rights and obligations under the exchange control regulations. Under Administration of Control, some indica­ tion is given of the authorities responsible for policy and administration of the controls and of the extent to which their powers are delegated for practical working purposes. Under Prescription of Currency, the require­ ments affecting the selection of the currency and method of settlement for transactions with other countries are described. Where a country has concluded payments agreements with other coun­ tries or monetary areas, the terms of these agree­ ments often lead to prescription of the currency for specified categories of payments to and from the countries concerned. The countries with which bilateral payments agreements are in force are listed either in the text or in a footnote. For a country whose currency has international impor­ tance, the prescription of currency arrangements involve the use of its own currency held by non­ residents in accounts with authorized banks. Pay­ ments to and from such nonresident accounts are then regarded as equivalent to settlements in for­ eign currency. Under Nonresident Accounts, an indication is given of the manner in which the country regards the accounts in its currency of account holders not regarded as resident in that country, and the facilities and limitations attached to such accounts. Where there is more than one type of nonresident account, the nature and operation of the various types are described. Under Imports and Import Payments, import licensing requirements are described briefly, and details are given of the additional requirements imposed on payments for imports and of any advance deposit requirements. The term "open general license," which is used in some countries, indicates arrangements whereby certain imports or other international transactions are exempt from the restrictive application of licensing require­ ments, in contrast to an "individual license," which may be either given freely, or restricted in its issue, according to administrative decisions. The expression "global quota" is employed in the sense that many countries now use it, to indicate quotas that are not necessarily universal in their application but instead may apply to a group of countries, e.g., global quotas for imports from 17 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution REPORT ON E X C H A N GE RESTR ICT IONS countries in the European Economic Community. Under Payments for Invisibles, action in the matter of permitting payments abroad for current transactions in invisibles is described briefly, together with any limitations on the export of foreign and domestic banknotes. For some coun­ tries that do not impose limitations on payments for invisibles, this section is combined with the section on Proceeds from Invisibles (see below). Under Exports and Export Proceeds, the appli­ cation of export licensing, where this is operative, is indicated, together with a brief outline of the requirements imposed on the proceeds derived from exports. The expression "exchange receipts must be surrendered" is used to indicate that the recipient is required by the regulations to sell his foreign exchange against local currency, usually at the official rate, to the central bank or to a com­ mercial bank or exchange dealer authorized for this purpose. In some countries there is a require­ ment that the exchange be sold in a free market. Under Proceeds from Invisibles, any conditions governing exchange derived from transactions in invisibles are given, and any limitations on the import of foreign and domestic banknotes are described. Under Capital, a general indication of the spe­ cial arrangements or limitations attached to inter­ national receipts and payments in respect of capi­ tal items is given. Where special arrangements for foreign capital also cover the income thereon, they are dealt with in this section rather than in the sections on Payments for Invisibles and Pro­ ceeds from Invisibles. Under Gold, the principal provisions are sum­ marized that govern the holding, negotiation, and import and export of gold coins and gold in other forms. In the Table of Exchange Rates, which is pro­ vided for certain countries having a multiple cur­ rency practice involving more than two rate levels, the exchange rates effective on a specified date are given. For convenience, the data in these tables are in terms of local currency units per U. S. dollar. The tables include effective rates arising from the negotiation of percentages of the total exchange at different rates, the imposition of exchange taxes, the negotiation of exchange cer­ tificates, etc. Under Changes during 1971, the more signifi­ cant changes in the country's restrictive system during 1971 are presented in chronological order. Important measures made effective in the early months of 1972 are indicated in certain surveys in footnotes to the text. * * * The individual country surveys were prepared by the staff of the Fund and reviewed by the authorities of the countries concerned. Prepa­ ration of this part of the Report was under the general direction of M r. J. H. C. de Looper, Advisor, Exchange and Trade Relations Depart­ ment. 18 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution AFGHAN ISTAN Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0197482 gram of fine gold per Afghani. The Afghanistan Bank (the central bank) charges commissions ranging from Vio of 1 per cent to v2 of 1 per cent on exchange transactions. The Bank's official buying and selling rates for the U. S. dollar are Af 44.70 and Af 45.30, respectively. The official selling rate applies to certain foreign exchange payments by the Central Government. The official buying rate applies to the proceeds of exports of karakul (which is exported only to the convertible currency area), wool (except cashmere wool exported to the convertible currency area), cotton, and natural gas (which is exported only to the U. S. S. R . ); to 30 per cent of the foreign cur­ rency salaries of foreign employees of the Government, government enterprises, and domestic companies; and to purchases of bilateral agreement currencies for maintenance in Afghanistan of embassies and state trad­ ing organizations by the respective bilateral partner countries. Exchange subsidies are applied to the official buying rate as follows: Af 3 per US$1 for export proceeds from cotton when payment is received under a bilateral payments agreement; Af 10 per US$1 for proceeds in convertible currencies from exports of woo l; Af 25 per US$1 for proceeds in convertible currencies from exports of cotton; and Af 20 per US$1 for pro­ ceeds from exports of karaku l. A ll other transactions take place at free market rates through either the banks or the bazaar; proceeds from the export of walnuts received over bilateral payments accounts are subject to an exchange tax of 9.5 per cent. The Afghanistan Bank maintains its operational free market selling rate for the U. S. dollar within Af 2.0 per US$1 of the daily free market rate quoted in the bazaar. On December 30, 1971, the free market rate of the Afghanistan Bank was Af 78.00 buying, and Af 78.50 selling, per U S $ 1, and the free market rate in the bazaar was Af 77.45 buying, and Af 77.95 selling, per US$ 1. The Afghanistan Bank also posts free market rates for deutsche mark, French francs, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs, which reflect their relative values to the U. S. dollar in international markets, and free market rates for the Indian rupee and Pakistan rupee that are determined by demand and supply for the currencies concerned. The Afghanistan Bank from time to time buys and sells in the free market bilateral agreement dollars and bilateral agreement sterling resulting partly from loans for consumer goods under certain of Afghanistan's bilateral payments agreements; most of this exchange sold by the Bank is purchased by govern­ ment commercial and industrial enterprises for their imports from the countries concerned. The selling rate for U. S. S. R. clearing dollars was Af 60.50 per US$1 on December 30, 1971, and that for mainland Ch ina clearing sterling was Af 206.20 per <£ stg. 1. On the same date, the selling rate for clearing dollars under the payments agreements w i th Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Poland, and Yugoslavia was Af 55.50 per US $ 1. Administration of Control Foreign exchange is controlled by the Government through the Afghanistan Bank. The control is facilitated by the existence of relatively large companies, some of them government owned or government controlled, specializing in the export of such commodities as karakul, cotton, wool, and carpets. However, these companies do not exercise a monopoly over the export of such commodities. Prescription of Currency Settlements with countries with which Afghanistan has bilateral payments agreements 1 must be made in the foreign currencies specified in the agreements. The proceeds from exports of karaku l, woo l, and cotton to other countries must be obtained in convertible cur­ rencies. There are no other prescription of currency requirements. Imports and Import Payments Imports are not subject to license. Imports of a few items (e.g., some drugs, liquor, arms, and ammunition) are prohibited on public policy grounds or for security reasons; in some instances, however, special permission to import these goods may be granted. The importation of certain other goods (e.g., a few textiles and selected nonessential consumer goods) also is prohibited. There are no quantitative restrictions on other imports. Most bilateral agreements, however, specify quotas (and sometimes prices) for commodities to be traded, and the Government facilitates the fulfillment of the commit­ ments undertaken in the agreements. On the whole, trade with bilateral agreement countries is carried out on a compensation basis and usually both imports and exports are arranged by the same trader; imports against exports of cotton and wool are carried out by the Government or government agencies, or the proceeds of exports are allocated for the Government's external debt servicing. Exchange is provided at the official rate for imports by the Government. Payments for imports through the banking system may be made only under letters of credit, against which a deposit of 100 per cent of the value of the imports in afghanis calculated at the pre­ vailing free market rate, or in foreign exchange, is required upon establishment of the letter of credit. Such deposits may be used as collateral to obtain loans from 1 Bulgaria, mainland China, Czechoslovakia, Poland, U. S. S. R., and Yugoslavia. There is also a bilateral payments arrangement with India under which the bulk of trade is settled through a special account maintained in inconvertible Indian rupees with the Reserve Bank of India. 21 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution A F G H A N I S T AN commercial banks. The Afghanistan Bank is authorized to refuse to sell foreign exchange for the importation of a group of consumer goods that are regarded as non­ essential. However, exchange for these items may be purchased either from the commercial banks or in the bazaar. Payments for Invisibles Central government payments for foreign debt service and other invisibles are made at the official rate. A ll other payments are settled at free market rates. Travelers leaving Afghanistan may take out not more than Af 500 in Afghan banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports are not subject to license. Exports of a few commodities (e.g., opium and museum pieces) are prohibited. Otherwise, control is exercised only over exports to bilateral agreement countries (see section on Imports and Import Payments, above). However, exporters of cotton are required to sell at least 20 per cent of their total exports to countries from which pay­ ments w i ll be received in convertible currencies. K a r a k ul is not exported to payments agreement countries. Exchange receipts from exports of karaku l, woo l, and cotton must be surrendered at the official rate, irrespec­ tive of destination. The net proceeds of a ll exports other than karaku l, wool, and cotton, irrespective of the cur­ rency in which they accrue, must either be sold at free market rates to a domestic bank or be used by the exporter or a third party to pay for imports. Export receipts from cotton are subject to an exchange subsidy at the rate of Af 25 per US$1 for convertible currency receipts and Af 3 per US$1 for exports settled under bilateral payments agreements. Convertible cur­ rency receipts from wool exports are paid an exchange subsidy at the rate of Af 10 per US$1 and those from karakul exports are paid an exchange subsidy of Af 20 per U S $ 1. Proceeds from the export of walnuts received over bilateral payments accounts are subject to an exchange tax of 9.5 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles Th i r ty per cent of the foreign currency salaries of foreign employees of the Afghan public and private sectors must be converted into afghanis at the official rate, but the remaining 70 per cent may be remitted abroad or exchanged at the free market rate. Except in the case of India, receipts over bilateral payments agree­ ment accounts from the embassies and state trading organizations of the countries concerned for their local expenses in Afghanistan are converted at the official rate. A ll other receipts from invisibles are sold at free market rates through either the banks or the bazaar. Travelers entering Afghanistan may bring in Afghan banknotes not exceeding Af 500. 22 Capital Foreign investment in Afghanistan requires pr ior approval and is administered, as is domestic private investment, by an Investment Committee composed of five cabinet ministers. The Foreign and Domestic Private Investment L aw (February 10, 1967) provides for a number of benefits, which include (1) income tax exemption for five years, beginning from the date of the first sales of products resulting from the new investment; (2) exemption from import duties on essential imports for five consecutive years after approval of the invest­ ment; (3) exemption from taxes on dividends for five years after the first distribution of dividends, but not more than eight years after the approval of the invest­ ment; (4) exemption from personal income tax and corporate tax on interest on foreign loans wh ich con­ stitute part of an approved investment; (5) exemption from export duties for ten years after the approval of the investment; and (6) mandatory purchases by govern­ ment agencies and departments of their requirements from enterprises established under the law where such products are substantially competitive w i th imports in price and quality. The law also establishes that an investment approved by the Investment Committee shall require no further license to operate in Afghanistan. P r inc ipal and interest installments on loans from abroad may be remitted freely to the extent of the legal obligation involved. Profits may be repatriated freely, and capital may be repatriated after five years at an annual rate not exceeding 25 per cent of the total registered capital. A ll the foregoing transfers are made through the free market. Joint ventures of foreign and Afghan capital are encouraged, but no specific per­ centages of domestic participation are prescribed and 100 per cent foreign-owned investments are not pre­ cluded by law. Gold Residents may freely import and purchase, ho ld, and sell domestically gold in any form. Exports of gold and silver in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the C o u n c il of Ministers; such licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. C om­ mercial exports of gold and silver jewelry and of other articles containing minor quantities of gold or silver do not require a license and may be made freely. Customs duties are payable on imports and exports of silver in any form, unless the import or export is made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. The import duty on gold is 1 per cent.
