Not for Redistribution PAK ISTAN Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.186621 gram of fine gold per Pakistan Rupee or PRs 4.76190 = US$1. The exchange rate system is based on this rate for the U. S. dollar; the State Bank of Pakistan maintains official rates of PRs 4.7619 buying and PRs 4.7775 selling per US $ 1. A ll transactions in foreign exchange must be conducted through authorized dealers, whose transactions with the general public must be effected at rates authorized by the State Bank. Au thor ized dealers in Pakistan are per­ mitted to cover in the London market their requirements of specified currencies. They may also cover their per­ mitted transactions in specified currencies against U. S. dollars or Pakistan rupees, either spot or forward for a limited period, with their agents in the countries con­ cerned. Other effective rates arise from the negotiation of bonus vouchers which certain exporters and certain other earners or recipients of exchange may sell at freely determined rates to importers who need them in order to obtain import licenses for various commodities or to importers or others to obtain exchange for certain invisibles. The vouchers are quoted spot and forward on the Ka rachi and Lahore stock exchanges. On Decem­ ber 31, 1971, these vouchers issued under the Export Bonus Scheme were quoted at about PRs 194 per PRs 100 of nominal value. Foreign tourists receive an effective exchange rate based on 45 per cent bonus. Administration of Control The State Bank of Pakistan has delegated to 21 banks and financial institutions authority to deal in a ll foreign currencies, to supervise surrender requirements, and to sell exchange for specified purposes within limits pre­ scribed by the State Bank. The Ch ief Controller of Imports and Exports is responsible for the issue of licenses and the implementation of import and export policies. Certain foreign trade transactions are conducted through the Trad ing Corporation of Pakistan, L t d ., a state trading agency. Prescription of Currency Pakistan is a member of the Sterling A r e a, and the prescribed methods for settling both trade and nontrade transactions are similar to those of most other Sterling A r ea countries. Payments between Pakistan and the Republic of Ch ina, India, Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are suspended; there is an inoperative clearing account with India. Exchange receipts must be obtained through an authorized dealer. Receipts from countries in the Sterling A rea must be received in sterling from the account of a resident of the Sterling A r ea (other than a resident of Pakistan) or in Pakistan rupees from the account of a bank in the Sterling A r e a. Receipts from countries outside the Sterling A r ea must be obtained in sterling from an Ex ternal Account in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom, in Pakistan rupees from the account of a bank outside the Sterling A r e a, or in any non-Sterling A rea currency. Payments abroad must be made through an author­ ized dealer. Payments by residents of Pakistan to coun­ tries in the Sterling A r ea are made by transferring sterling or any other Sterling A r ea currency, including Pakistan rupees, to an appropriate account. Payments to countries outside the Sterling A r ea are made by trans­ ferring sterling or Pakistan rupees to a nonresident account or, in some cases, in the recipient's currency. F or imports, payment is normally made to the country of origin of the goods. No exchange control is exercised over transactions with Afghanistan, and settlements are made in Pakistan rupees or afghanis. Trade transactions under "barter" agreements are settled through special accounts in incon­ vertible currencies. Trade in specified commodities with Bulgaria, mainland Ch ina, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, N o r th Ko r e a, Nepa l, Po land, Ruman ia, the U. S. S. R ., and Yugos lav ia is settled through clearing accounts maintained in inconvertible Pakistan rupees. Payments to and from Iran and Tu rkey relating to visible trade (excluding border trade, Iranian o i l, and defense mate­ rials) are settled through clearing accounts maintained by the respective central banks in U. S. dollars. Certain settlements w i th Cey lon are made through special accounts. Nonresident Accounts Different rules apply to nonresident rupee accounts of individuals, firms, or companies, on the one hand, and to nonresident rupee accounts of banks, on the other. Au tho r ized dealers may open rupee accounts for banks abroad without reference to the State Bank, but approval is required for opening other nonresident accounts. Transfers from nonresident banks' rupee accounts in Pakistan to the corresponding sterling accounts in the Un i ted K ingdom are allowed, but other nonresident account holders must obtain permission from the exchange control authorities for transfers from their credit balances. Accounts of residents of India are b locked .1 Imports and Import Payments Permitted imports are classified in four lists: a free list, a licensable list, an export bonus list (also called bonus import list), and a cash-cum-bonus list. A ll * With effect from May 11, 1972, the par value was changed to 0.0744103 gram of fine gold per Pakistan rupee and the export bonus scheme was abolished. 1 On January 18, 1972 the restrictions on the bank accounts of the Indian High Commission and its personnel were lifted. 334 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution imports require licenses, except goods on the free l i s t2 and goods imported by the Central Government for defense or other purposes, goods in transit, personal baggage, certain imports over the land routes from Afghanistan and Iran, and certain other items per­ mitted under a M in i s t ry of Commerce Notification (No. 335 /260 /24 of June 12, 1951). The commercial import of goods on the free list is restricted to registered industrial consumers and commercial importers, unless exemption from registration is obtained; however, l im i­ tations are applied to ind iv idual import entitlements for goods on this list, ceilings on ind iv idual letters of credit being based on past import performance. Permissible sources and conditions of procurement are prescribed for a ll items on the list. Import licenses for commodities on the licensable list are granted on a discretionary basis; these licenses and licenses for items on the export bonus list and the cash-cum-bonus list are issued in accordance w i th procedures indicated below. Goods on the free list and the licensable list are imported at the official exchange rate. Commodities not included in any of the four lists are prohibited or are not being licensed. W i th the exception of specific country licenses issued in accordance w i th trade, aid, or loan agreements with particular countries, import licenses may be used in any country of the wo r ld other than the Republic of Ch ina, India, Israel, Rhodesia, or South A f r i c a. Certain imports are only or in part effected through the intermediary of the T rad ing Corporation of Pakistan, L t d .; they include sugar from specified countries, specified raw materials, pig i ron, and certain other metals. L icens ing takes place in accordance with criteria that are determined admin­ istratively, and imports take place at the official rate but, depending on the commodity, may be subject to price equalization levies. Imports of rice, wheat, and coal are also reserved for public sector agencies. Import licenses are issued on a c. & f. basis to estab­ lished commercial importers and industrial consumers and only for commodities specified in the semiannual import program. The quantities to be licensed to estab­ lished importers are determined by the authorities on an historical basis. A special industrial licensing procedure operates for imports of licensable items by recognized industrial units. Th is procedure allows specified indus­ tries to receive import licenses for items not on the free list on a specific basis determined by the competent authority. F or items on the licensable list, industrial consumers receive licenses according to fixed entitle­ ments based on requirements for operations at single- shift capacity; commercial importers receive licenses under fixed quotas based on past import performance. Supplementary import licenses under a Raw Ma ter ial Replenishment Scheme are granted to specified export- 2 While private sector imports of free list items do not require an import license, public sector agencies require either an allocation from the Government or an authorization. A ll free list imports must be financed under aid arrangements or bilateral agreements. P A K I S T AN ing industries. The imports concerned must be made on cash-cum-bonus terms. Import licenses are issued freely under the Export Bonus Scheme for items on the export bonus list and for any item (other than sheet or plate glass) included in the free list, licensable list, or cash-cum-bonus list, provided that bonus vouchers equivalent to 100 per cent of the amount of the license requested are surrendered when applying for an import license. The holder of a bonus voucher (entitlement to import) must apply w i th in 90 days (12 months for imports of heavy machinery and equipment) of the receipt of the voucher for the issue of an import license for any of the items eligible under the Export Bonus Scheme. Th is license is issued without restriction and without the importer having to be registered. Import licenses issued against bonus vouchers are va l id for 6 months from the day of their issue, except for imports of heavy machinery and equipment, for which the period may be extended up to 24 months. Licensing of items on the cash-cum-bonus list is subject to the surrender of bonus vouchers equiv­ alent to 50 per cent of the amount of the license. Indus­ tr ial consumers importing under the Raw Ma te r ial Replenishment Scheme and, in specified circumstances, other commercial and industrial importers, must sur­ render vouchers for imports no later than 15 days after the receipt of the shipping documents (subject to bank guarantee, indemnity bond, or, for public sector imports, letter of authority from the government department concerned). Capital goods generally are licensed only under for­ eign aid. Imports of capital goods are payable at the official rate, but any required downpayment on private sector imports of capital goods and on most public sec­ tor imports of such goods requires surrender of bonus vouchers equivalent to 100 per cent of the downpay­ ment (which is normally 10 per cent). Under a Pay- A s -You -E a rn Scheme, certain plant and machinery may be imported and financed on a deferred payment basis. Industrial units covered by the Scheme may use up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value of export earnings for meeting their debt liabilities. Except for imports of books, periodicals, and news­ papers, and those against bonus import licenses, irre­ vocable letters of credit must be opened for a il commer­ c ial imports. Remittances are not normally permitted before shipping documents are received, but in special cases, e.g., machinery and other capital goods for wh ich deposits have to be made with foreign manufacturers, the State Bank may authorize advance payments for a part of the value of the goods. No import payments are permitted to be made for goods originating in or con­ signed from the Republic of Ch ina, India, Israel, Rho­ desia, or South A f r i c a. Imports at the official rate of certain aid-financed iron and steel items, cement, coal, edible oils, and raw materials for the electrical equipment industry, etc., are subject to price equalization levies; the same items, 335 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution P A K I S T AN when not financed w i th aid, are imported at the cash- cum-bonus rate. Imports of a ll commodities, except machinery, are subject to a "defense surcharge" of 25 per cent of the applicable rate of customs duty. M any imports are sub­ ject to a customs surcharge ("regulatory du ty " ). Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are controlled by the State Bank and in many cases require its prior approval. No remittances are permitted to be made to the Republic of Ch ina, India, Israel, or Rhodesia. Under authority delegated to them, authorized dealers may sell exchange or make remittances in accordance with detailed regula­ tions. Certain remittances of a personal nature are sub­ ject to annual quotas, but most are approved at the discretion of the State Bank. Remittances by Pakistan nationals to their families abroad require special authori­ zation. Payments for invisibles connected with imports are generally given the same treatment as that accorded the underlying trade transaction. Transport insurance must, except with respect to certain aid shipments, be taken out with insurance companies in Pakistan. Most payments for invisibles are made at the official rate but some (payments for medical treatment, pro­ fessional training, operating expenses of Pakistan ships, technical fees, office expenses abroad, advertisement and legal fees, bank commissions and charges, royalties, trademarks, and patent and registration fees) are at the cash-cum-bonus rate, i.e., subject to surrender of bonus vouchers equal in face value to 50 per cent of the for­ eign exchange required. Certain insurance payments are made on 45 per cent bonus and 55 per cent cash terms. In addition, certain exchange allocations for pilgrimages are granted at exchange rates deviating from the official rate (see be low ). The remittance of dividends declared out of current profits is allowed freely to foreign shareholders where the investment was made w i th the Government's approval. Profits of branches of foreign companies may be remitted freely to their head offices. The same applies to head office expenses charged to a branch's profit and loss account and accepted for tax purposes by the Pakistani income tax authorities, but such remit­ tances must be effected at the cash-cum-bonus rate. There is an annual allowance for pilgrims' travel to Saudi A r a b i a; for those traveling by air or first class by steamer, the allowance is subject to surrender of bonus for an equivalent amount.3 Those eligible are selected by ballot. There are also minor pilgrimage facilities for other M idd le Eastern countries, subject to similar conditions for surrender of bonus. No exchange is being granted until further notice for tourism or other 3 Deck passengers are granted their allocation at the official rate, and those traveling second class by steamer are allowed their exchange quota against surrender of bonus vouchers equivalent to 50 per cent of that quota. 336 private travel. However, exchange for business travel, medical treatment, education, and sponsored cultural trips may be granted on an individual basis. Exporters may use a limited percentage of their entitlements under the Export Bonus Scheme for business travel or for opening and maintaining branch offices outside Pakistan. Pakistan writers and journalists and certain other earners of foreign exchange from services sup­ plied abroad may use their foreign exchange earnings for approved travel abroad. The approval of the State Bank is required prior to booking passage for foreign travel. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency not exceeding the amounts they brought in and PRs 20 in Pakistan currency notes. Residents leaving for Afghanistan may take out PRs 50 in Pakistan currency notes and coins and any amount of Afghan currency. Persons traveling on Category " A" visas (to India) may not take out any Pakistan currency notes or coins. Residents traveling to other foreign destinations may take out PRs 20 in Pakistan currency and, subject to State Bank authorization, up to the equivalent of <£10 in foreign currency notes and coins. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of most commodities are allowed freely. However, export licenses are required for 24 listed items, as well as for certain types of sports goods and a few other items subject to m in imum export prices, and for mill-made cotton piece goods and ready-made garments intended for export to the Un i ted K ingdom. Exports to the Republic of Ch in a, India, Israel, Rho­ desia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. The Trad ing Corporation of Pakistan, L t d ., has a monopoly over exports of specified products. The State Bank exercises control over exchange receipts and requires a declaration by the exporter that, when payment in accordance with the prescribed method is received, he w i ll surrender the exchange within a certain period of time. Af ter making certain that the exporter's declaration meets a ll conditions, the authorized dealer certifies the shipment. Exporters are obliged to collect and surrender export proceeds within four months; export proceeds from jute manufactures, however, must be repatriated within six months. The surrender of Afghan currency accruing from exports to Afghanistan is not required. Under an Export Bonus Scheme applicable to a ll goods, exporters after surrendering all their exchange receipts for local currency are issued bonus vouchers of a face value equivalent to 10 per cent or 15 per cent (for primary products) or 35 per cent or 45 per cent (for other goods) of the net exchange surrendered. Bonus vouchers are also issued to approved sales centers for their local sales to nonresidents against payment in foreign exchange. Exporters must apply to the State Bank within 15 days of the date of realization of export proceeds or of the date of export, whichever is ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution later (within 15 days from the date of negotiation of documents in case of exports against confirmed or irrevocable letters of credit) for the issuance of bonus vouchers. These vouchers are freely transferable and entitle the holder to import a wide range of specified commodities, which are not otherwise licensed for importation, as we ll as any commodity (except sheet or plate glass) included in any one of the three other import lists. Under a P ay -A s -You -E a rn Scheme, certain industrial units are permitted to utilize up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value of exports for servicing of suppliers' credit on imports of plant and machinery. Under a Raw Ma te r ial Replenishment Scheme, sup­ plementary import licenses are available to most export­ ing industries. Proceeds from Invisibles W i th the exception of Afghan currency, wh ich may be retained, incoming foreign exchange derived from invisibles must be surrendered at the official rate within one month. Under the Export Bonus Scheme earners of foreign exchange derived from certain invisibles are issued bonus vouchers of a face value equivalent to 10 or 45 per cent of the exchange surrendered. Foreign tourists receive an effective rate of exchange based on 45 per cent bonus. Pakistanis and persons of Indo- Pakistan origin who are employed abroad are entitled to receive bonus vouchers equivalent to 45 per cent of all remittances of savings made by them to Pakistan through official channels; Pakistanis receiving pensions in foreign exchange are entitled to receive 45 per cent bonus; and Pakistanis receiving earnings in foreign exchange abroad from a wide range of professional, commercial, and cultural services also receive 45 per cent bonus and may alternatively use their foreign exchange earnings for approved foreign travel. Earners of foreign exchange from certain other services (air­ craft repairs, salvage and lighterage operations, and ship repairs) are entitled to receive bonus vouchers equivalent to 10 per cent of the net foreign exchange earned by them; and earners of foreign exchange from shipping are entitled to receive bonus vouchers equiva­ lent to 45 per cent of their exchange earnings. Bonus facilities apply also to all projects in Pakistan that are financed by the I B RD or the I D A; a ll sup­ pliers are entitled to bonus vouchers equivalent to 45 per cent of the foreign exchange earned from machinery items and 35 per cent from a ll other supplies, but not to bonus vouchers for advance payments. Persons traveling on Category " A" visas (from India) may not bring in any Pakistan currency notes or coins. Other travelers may bring in PRs 20 in Pak­ istan currency notes, subject to declaration to the customs, and Rs 5 in coins that are legal tender in India; Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50, 100, and 500 may not be brought in. There is P A K I S T AN no limitation on the import of other currency notes and coins, but they must be declared to the customs on entry. Capital Investments in Pakistan by nonresidents are subject to approval. In order to encourage industrial develop­ ment in Pakistan, the Government follows a liberal policy toward foreign entrepreneurs, who can start any industry in the private sector without any conditions being la id down regarding the participation of local capital. It is, however, expected that local rupee expen­ diture w i ll ordinarily be met from local equity capital. Repatriation facilities are as follows: (1) Foreign capital invested in approved industries established after September 1, 1954 may be repatriated at any time thereafter to the extent of the original investment, and current profits may be transferred without restriction, to the country of origin of the capital. (2) Profits that are reinvested in approved industrial projects with the approval of the Government may be treated as invest­ ment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. (3) Appreciation of any capital investment under (1) and (2) may also be treated as investment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. These repatriation facilities do not apply to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange unless the purchase is an integral part of an approved investment project, or to capital invested in Pakistan before September 1, 1954. Guarantees provide for just and fair compensation in the currency of the country of origin of the invest­ ment in the event of nationalization of any project. Foreign nationals in Pakistan or abroad may register their investments in Na t ional Prize Bonds issued by the Government of Pakistan, and thus facilitate repatria­ tion at any time of the principal and the prize winnings. Transfers of capital abroad by resident nationals are, in general, not permitted; the purchase of foreign secur­ ities by resident Pakistanis requires approval by the State Bank and is seldom permitted. Detailed rules govern the transfer of capital by persons emigrating or retiring from Pakistan, depending upon the nationality of the person concerned and the country or monetary area to which the transfer is to be made. Foreign nationals temporarily residing in Pakistan are treated as nonresidents for purposes of transfer of securities. General permission has been given in connection with the issue, sale, or transfer of securities issued in Pakistan in favor of nonresidents, provided the securities are registered in Pakistan and investment is made on the basis of nonrepatriation of capital and return. Pakistan securities held by nonresidents may be transferred to other nonresidents against payment abroad with the same facilities in respect of remittance of capital and earnings as those obtained by the transferor. A general license has also been issued allowing foreign nationals temporarily resident in Pakistan to make investments in units of the Na t ional Investment Trust, subject to 337 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution P A K I S T AN certain stipulations. Foreign life insurance companies have been given general permission to invest in shares issued by Pakistan companies and quoted on the stock exchange. Exports of securities are subject to approval. Proceeds accruing from the liquidation of nonresident capital assets that are not covered by repatriation arrangements may be credited to blocked accounts. Subject to approval by the State Bank, balances on blocked accounts may be invested in approved government securities payable in Pakistan rupees or placed on time deposit with banks. A general permission allows Pakistan nationals resi­ dent abroad to acquire securities in Pakistan by remit­ tance of foreign exchange or to the debit of their non­ resident accounts in Pakistan; dividends or interest thereon, as well as the proceeds upon sale, must be credited to nonresident accounts and cannot normally be transferred abroad. Pakistan nationals holding movable or immovable assets abroad require the prior approval of the State Bank to sell these, and the liquida­ tion proceeds must be repatriated to Pakistan through normal banking channels. Gold The export and import of gold is prohibited unless authorized by the State Bank. No such permission is granted, but there are no restrictions on the internal sale and purchase of nonmonetary gold. Changes during 1971 January 1. The import program for the first half of 1971 went into effect. Not for Redistribution PANAMA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.888671 gram of fine gold per Panamanian Balboa. Panama has established a central rate of B 1.00 = US$1 and does not avail itself of wider margins. U. S. currency notes and coins circulate freely in Panama, and local currency is represented only by limited amounts of silver balboas and subsidiary coins. Exchange transactions by commercial banks are based mainly on New Y o rk market quotations. Panama has no exchange restrictions on foreign payments, with the exception of a prohibition on payments to Rhodesia other than those for pensions or for humanitarian, edu­ cational, medical, or informational purposes. On Novem­ ber 26, 1946, Panama notified the Fund that it accepted the obligations of A r t i c le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the F u nd Agreement. Administration of Control Import and export policy is determined by the M i n­ istry of Industry and Commerce and the M in i s t ry of Agr icu l ture; import policy is made in consultation with the Committee of Adjustments, on which the Govern­ ment, producers, and consumers are represented. Most import and export licenses are issued by the Price Regu­ lation Office, a semiautonomous institution of the Pana­ manian Government. In rare cases, import and export licenses are issued by one of the Ministries mentioned above. The Price Regulation Office is responsible for the implementation of restrictions on imports of commodi­ ties that compete with national production and on cer­ tain exports; the Ministries of Industry and Commerce and Agriculture determine the import quotas for com­ modities that are produced or are about to be produced in Panama. Prescription of Currency dise on which export taxes are imposed is also subject to licensing. Export taxes are imposed on gold, silver, platinum, manganese, other minerals, bananas, coconuts, scrap metals, pearls, animal wax, nispero gum, ipecac root, and rubber. Exports of wheat flour, firearms, and ammunition are prohibited. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except for most payments to Rhodesia. A travel tax of 4 per cent is levied on air and sea tickets bought in Panama or on such tickets pur­ chased for travelers commencing their journey in Panama. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, except for most payments to Rhodesia. Three foreign- supervised banks are authorized to conduct business only with nonresidents. Gold Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home and abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form with residents or nonresidents at home and abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry carried as personal effects by travelers are sub­ ject to license if made by residents other than the mone­ tary authorities; import and export licenses are issued freely by the M in i s t ry of Industry and Commerce. Exports of unworked gold produced in Panama are sub­ ject to an export duty of 1 per cent ad valorem, and exports of gold coins (other than U. S. coins, which are exempt) to a duty of V2 per cent. No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Changes during 1971 Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Quotas are imposed on imports of commodities competing with present or prospective domestic production; some of these are not being licensed. Import licensing also applies to imports of various foods. Other imports are free. Payments abroad may be made freely. A tax of 6 per cent on the f.o.b. value is levied, in addition to import duty, on imports of all dutiable goods other than speci­ fied foodstuffs, for which the rate is 3M> per cent. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited, except those for humanitarian, educational, medical, or informational purposes. Authorization is required for exports of coffee in any form, coconuts, copra, and beef cattle. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY Exchange Rate System On M a r ch 1, 1956, a new par value for the Para­ guayan Gua rani was established by Paraguay with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. Exchange trans­ actions take place at free market rates, which since October 1960 have been pegged at 0 123.60 and 0 126.00 per U S $ 1, buying and selling. Settlements with Spain are made through a clearing account at a fixed rate of 0 126.00 per US $ 1. A ll purchases and sales of foreign exchange must be made through author­ ized commercial banks, except those related to govern­ ment payments for imports and services, wh ich are carried out through the Central Bank. A ll purchases and sales of exchange by banks are subject to a tax of 1 per cent, except transactions with foreign embassies and diplomats; transactions with meat packing plants; and transactions relating to investments in Paraguay that are covered by L aw N o. 216 of November 9, 1970. In addition, banks charge a commission of 2 per cent on a ll sales of foreign exchange. A tolerated parallel market exists in which the buying rate for the U. S. dollar was about 0 142 on December 31, 1971. There are no forward exchange facilities. The authorized banks are required to sell 30 per cent of their gross foreign exchange receipts in specified cur­ rencies 1 to the Central Bank. Administration of Control The Central Bank of Paraguay determines foreign exchange policy and supervises the foreign exchange transactions carried out by authorized commercial banks. Prescription of Currency Settlements with Spain under a bilateral payments agreement with that country must be made through a clearing account maintained in terms of U. S. dollars .2 Otherwise, there are no prescription of currency require­ ments. Payments between Paraguay and Argentina, Ch i le, Mex ico, and Peru may be made through accounts which the Central Bank of Paraguay and the other cen­ tral banks concerned maintain with each other, within the framework of the L A F TA multilateral clearing system. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited .3 A ll a Argentine pesos, Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 3 The termination of the payments agreement with Spain was agreed upon in 1971, but at the end of the year it was still in force. 3 These include certain agricultural products, depending on the season, certain petroleum products, cement, and certain wire and wire products. 342 other imports are free of quantitative restriction and licensing. Imports of most commodities are subject to an advance deposit of 100 per cent of the f.o.b. value, which is retained for 120 days, or if the deposit is made after the date of shipment, 180 days, or for nonexempt commodities imported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay, 90 days. Advance deposits are not required for, inter alia, public sector imports, imports by foreign diplomats and by foreign staff of certain international organizations, fuel and petroleum derivatives, certain machinery, agricultural equipment, wheat, and news­ print from any source, imports from neighboring coun­ tries (including U rugu ay ), and imports from other L A F TA countries of items included in the Paraguayan concession list (the Na t ional L i s t ). Surcharges, calculated on the c.i.f. value, are payable on most imports even if no foreign exchange payment takes place. An import surcharge of 36 per cent applies to most general imports from any source; however, for goods originating in L A F TA countries and included in the Paraguayan Na t ional L i st the rate ranges from 3 per cent to 30 per cent, and for certain other L A F TA goods (mainly pharmaceuticals) in a special list the rate is 8 per cent. Fu el derived from petroleum is subject to a surcharge of 15 per cent (10 per cent for neighbor­ ing countries, including Uruguay). There is an addi­ tional surcharge of 5 per cent (resulting in a total sur­ charge of 41 per cent) on imports from a ll sources of radios and record players and their parts and acces­ sories. Commodities that are exempt from surcharge generally are also exempt from advance deposit. These surcharges are collected by the banks at the time of delivery of the documents for customs clear­ ance or when the import payment is made, whichever is earlier. The following are the pr inc ipal exemptions from surcharge: wheat; crude petroleum; equipment for petroleum exploration and exploitation; agricultural tractors; imports for the Government; imports for religious, charitable, cu l tura l, or educational purposes; imports by foreign diplomats and certain international organizations; Spanish agricultural and industrial machinery and implements imported through the Span­ ish free zone in Paraguay; agricultural machinery and equipment for the Na t ional Wheat Program; books and periodicals; and imports for investments under the new Cap i tal Investment L aw N o. 216. Imports of investment goods and of raw materials for export industries receive exemption on a case-by-case basis. In addition to the above surcharges, a tariff sur­ charge is levied on certain imports by virtue of L aw N o. 1334/67, wh ich implemented Decree-Law N o. 451 of M a r ch 31, 1967, and L aw N o. 10 of August 29, 1968. On goods that are not exempt, it is 12-24 per cent (8-16 per cent for certain goods subject to L A F TA concessions) and is levied on the c.i.f. value, which is calculated as follows: the f.o.b. value plus 10 per cent ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution for imports from neighboring countries and the f.o.b. value plus 20 per cent for imports from other coun­ tries. Exempt from this complementary import duty are public sector and diplomatic imports; raw materials and equipment for the production of goods that are subject to internal consumption taxes; imports under Cap i tal Investment L aw N o. 216; and a ll imported goods taxed under the Internal Consumption Tax L aw. Imports that are considered to be of a luxury or nonessential char­ acter are subject to sales tax at 5 per cent or 10 per cent by virtue of L aw N o. 69 /68. In addition to those mentioned above, the following charges are levied on the c.i.f. value of imports: a consular fee of 5 per cent, an import clearance fee of 1 per cent, and a customs surcharge of IV2 per cent, from wh ich wheat and certain other commodities are exempt and the proceeds of wh ich go to the Institute of Technology and Standards. Moreover, imports of construction materials are subject to an additional cus­ toms surcharge of 1 per cent, the proceeds of which go to the Institute of Hous ing and Urban iza t ion. Imports on credit for a term of more than six months require approval from the Central Bank. Th is approval is normally granted only for imports of machinery and other capital goods. Import payments must be made through banks. Import payments are free from formal restriction, but certain arrears have arisen from time to time as a result of periodic releases of foreign exchange to the private commercial banks by the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles Au thor ized banks may sell exchange freely for speci­ fied current invisibles, provided that appropriate docu­ mentation is submitted. They may grant allocations for travel purposes as follows, for each person each tr ip: the equivalent of US$150 for Argentina, Bo l iv i a, B r a z i l, and Uruguay; of US$300 for other L a t in Ame r ican countries and of US$1 ,000 for a ll other countries. Banks may also sell exchange for l iv ing expenses of students abroad (including tuition) in amounts gen­ erally up to US$200 a month. App l ica t ions for exchange for other invisibles or for unusually large amounts require the pr ior approval of the Central Bank. Trav­ elers may take out any amount in foreign or domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of logs are subject to an annual quota that is being reduced gradually. Certain exports require licenses in order to assure domestic supplies. A ll other exports are free of license but require a certificate issued by the Institute of Technology and Standards. The proceeds of exports must be collected w i th in 180 days after comple­ tion of shipping formalities, and the exchange sold to an authorized commercial bank; there are no legal sanc­ tions for noncompliance with this requirement unless P A R A G U AY this is notified to the Central Bank by the Superintend­ ency of Banks. F or a ll exports minimum surrender prices (aforos) are established; export proceeds corre­ sponding to these prices, on which any fiscal charges are based, should be surrendered. Advance receipts of export proceeds must be sold to authorized banks. P ro­ ducers of coffee are permitted to retain 50 per cent of their export proceeds; such retained proceeds may only be used to meet dividend and interest payments due to nonresidents and to pay for imports of machinery and equipment for the producers' own use. Most exports are subject to taxes payable in guaranies of IV2 per cent, 5 per cent, or l>k per cent of the f.o.b. value; these taxes are collected by the banks. Exports of meat prod­ ucts are exempt, but a single tax of 0 515 per head of cattle slaughtered is levied on the meat processing plants. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from invisibles must be sold to authorized banks, but there is no sanction on noncom­ pliance. Travelers may bring in any amount in foreign or domestic currency. Capital A ll inward and outward transfers must be recorded by the authorized banks. Au thor ized banks may grant exchange freely for contractual capital transfers, sub­ ject to presentation of appropriate documentation. Other outward transfers of capital require the prior approval of the Central Bank. L aw N o. 216 of November 9, 1970, the Cap i tal Investment L aw, empowers the Gov­ ernment to grant special tax, customs, import surcharge, and advance deposit concessions to proposed private foreign investments, provided that these are registered; the terms may vary from case to case. Cap i tal imported under L aw N o. 216 may be retransferred in install­ ments of up to 20 per cent from the third year after the beginning of production, in the currency originally imported. Gold Decree-Law N o. 18 of 1952 provides that the Cen­ tral Bank may determine the maximum amount of gold and foreign exchange that residents may hold; exempt is any amount acquired from the Central Bank or insti­ tutions authorized to deal in foreign exchange. In prac­ tice residents may freely purchase and sell gold in the form of jewelry. Exports and imports of gold in any form other than jewelry require the pr ior approval of the Central Bank, which is granted to residents other than banks and industrial users. Changes during 1971 January 22. Central Bank Resolution N o. 10 revised the regulations on advance repatriation of export pro­ ceeds (divisas anticipadas). Exporters could no longer 343 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution P A R A G U AY pay for imports w i th the proceeds of export prepay­ ments. A ny exchange received by exporters for future exports had to be sold to authorized banks. March 24. These provisions were not applicable to trade w i th L A F TA countries. July 20, Central Bank Resolution N o. 4 increased the 32 per cent surcharge on imports to 36 per cent. August 23. Not for Redistribution P E RU Exchange Rate System On December 18, 1946, a par value for the Peruvian Sol was established by Peru w i th the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange market with two fixed exchange rates, an exchange"cer—* tificat^maTkef ra1F*appTyirig to a ll trade transactions and specified nontrade transactions, including the p r in­ cipal capital movements, and a draft market rate for services and most other nontrade transactions. The for­ eign exchange requirements of the public sector are met entirely through the certificate market. Export proceeds must be converted into exchange certificates, which are valid for three days and are issued by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru in _ U. S. dollars only. These exchange certificates may be used, only through the intermediary of commercial banks, to pay for imports and for certain nontrade transactions. Generally, no exchange certificates are issued against export proceeds surrendered by the pub l ic sector, nor are certificates used to cover foreign payments of the public sector, since normally the Central Reserve Bank buys and sells foreign exchange direct from and to government agencies at the certificate rate. When approved appli­ cations for certificates exceed the supply, the Central Reserve Bank sells foreign exchange at the certificate market rate without any delay. A ll foreign exchange receipts that are not required to be surrendered at the certificate rate must be sold in the draft market, in which only the Banco de la N a t i on and its author­ ized agents operate. Access to the draft market is controlled and purchases of foreign exchange are permitted only for specified payments not eligible for exchange at the certificate rate. The banks are required to quote a single rate for buying and selling certificates, but they may charge a commission of % of 1 per cent on certificate sales and a commis­ sion of % of 1 per cent, buying and selling, on trans­ actions in the draft market. On December 31, 1971 the certificate market rate was S /. 38.70 per US$1 and the draft market rate was S /. 43.38 buying, and S /. 43.50 selling, per U S $ 1. A stamp tax of 1 per cent is payable on most out­ ward remittances. Peru formally accepted the obligations of A r t i­ cle V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control Export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Fo r­ eign Trade in the M in is t ry of Industry and Commerce. The Central Reserve Bank controls the use of certifi­ cates for import payments. It also authorizes the use of certificates for nontrade transactions; for profit remittances by branches of foreign companies, pr ior approval by the M in i s t ry of Economy and Finance must be obtained in addition. A ll imports of, and most payments for services by, the pub l ic sector require the approval of the Board for Foreign Transactions for the Pub l ic Sector and a resolution of the M in is t ry of Economy and Finance; a similar Board for Foreign Transactions for the Private Sector prepares an annual foreign exchange budget for the private sector. Mo re­ over, imports by the industrial, agricultural, and fishery sectors require the prior authorization of the ministry responsible for the sector concerned. Most borrowing abroad by the public sector as well as borrowing abroad with a government guarantee by the private sector are subject to prior approval by the M in i s t ry of Economy and Finance, upon favorable recommendation by the Na t ional Planning Institute and the Permanent Commission on Ex ternal Credits in the M in i s t ry of Economy and Finance. Prescription of Currency In principle, all export proceeds must be received in convertible currencies; exchange certificates at present are only issued in U. S. dollars, but the central bank is empowered to issue certificates denominated in any convertible currency. Settlements in respect of trade transactions with Hungary and Poland must be made through special accounts denominated in U. S. dollars, wh ich have been established under bilateral payments agreements. No other prescription of cur­ rency requirements are in force. Payments between Peru and Argentina, Bo l iv i a, B r a z i l, Ch i le, Co lomb ia, Ecuador, Mex ico, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru and the central banks concerned, within the framework of the L A F TA multilateral clearing system. Imports and Import Payments The import of a number of consumer goods that are considered nonessential is prohibited from any source other than L A F TA countries. Moreover, the import of a large number of manufactures included in the Na t ional Register of Manufactured Products requires the approval of the customs authorities, wh ich is granted only in exceptional circumstances. Private sector imports must take place within the foreign cur­ rency quota allocated to each importer by the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector. Pub l ic sector agencies, however, may not place import orders without the pr ior approval of the Commission on Exter­ nal Transactions and the M in i s t ry of Economy and Finance. Certain agricultural commodities, such as rice and wheat, may be imported only by, or within quotas set by, the Pub l ic Company for Ag r icu l tu ral Services (EPSA ), and crude petroleum and petroleum derivatives only by Petroperu, a government agency. Exports and Export Proceeds T he B a n co M i n e ro d el P e ru has a m o n o p o ly ov er the expo rt of p r e c i o us me ta l s, u n c ut p r e c i o us stones, and pea r l s, a nd the Em p r e sa M i n e ra d el P e ru has a m o n o p o ly ov er a ll o th er m i n e r al expo r t s. A ll expo r ts are subject to l icen se to assure the necessa ry s u p p ly of e x p o rt p r o­ ceeds to the ce r t i f ica te m a r k e t. E x p o rt p roceeds must be r e c e i v ed in U. S. d o l l a r s. T r a d i t i o n al expo r ts mu st be s o ld aga inst an i r r e v o c a b le le t ter of c r e d it c o n f i rm ed by a b a nk e s tab l i shed in P e r u; the la t ter mu st su r render the f o r e i gn exchange p ro c e eds w i t h in ten w o r k i ng days of p a ym e n t. In s p e c i al cases, a nd w i th the a u t h o r i z a t i on ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution of the Central Reserve Bank and the Directorate of Foreign Trade, exports may be sold against sight drafts, provided that payment is received w i th in 180 days of shipment. Exporters of nontraditional exports are granted transferable tax credit certificates equivalent to 15 per cent of the f.o.b. value (18 per cent when the goods are shipped in Peruvian vessels). These certifi­ cates may be used by the exporter in payment of his tax obligations or may be sold to other taxpayers, who may use them for the same purpose. Proceeds from Invisibles Pub l ic sector entities must surrender their fu ll receipts at the certificate rate. A ll other receipts from invisibles must be sold in the draft market. Travelers may not bring in more than S /. 1,000 in Peruvian currency. Capital A ll outward capital transfers require pr ior approval. In addition to government payments, certain capital payments on private account may be effected through the certificate market. The use of exchange certificates may be authorized for the amortization of foreign loans contracted by the private sector, provided that the for­ eign exchange proceeds of the loan have been surren­ dered to the Central Reserve Bank. Where such debt was contracted before October 9, 1967, certificate exchange may be allotted by the Central Reserve Bank only to public utility enterprises, to earners of foreign exchange, for payment of debts to international organi­ zations, and for payments of debts guaranteed by the State. The proceeds of a ll foreign loans received after June 17, 1971 must be converted in the certificate market; amortization and service payments in respect of these loans also are settled through the certificate market. Payments in connection with a ll other loans must be transferred through the draft market. Foreign investment in Peru is governed by Decree- Law N o. 18900 of June 30, 1971, which ratified the Andean Common Market's policy on the treatment of foreign capital, and by Decree-Law N o. 18999 of October 19, 1971 which implemented that policy for most types of activity. A ll foreign investment in Peru requires the prior approval of the competent authorities with a view to channeling such investments to projects considered essential for the country's develop­ ment. If they wish to enjoy for their products the advan­ tages deriving from the duty-free program of the Car­ tagena Agreement, foreign companies incorporated in Peru as at December 30, 1970, have to agree, within a period of 3 years, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in such companies so as to transfer them to mixed or national companies during a maximum period of 15 years following the entering into effect of this regime. F or this purpose, mixed companies are defined as those in which national investors hold between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital, while national companies are those in which at least P E RU 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national inves­ tors. Upon expiration of the 3-year period, the par­ ticipation of national investors in the capital of an enterprise has to amount to not less than 15 per cent; this participation must increase to at least 45 per cent after 10 years and to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign companies established in Peru as at January 1, 1971, the 15 per cent participation by national investors must be secured at the time of the initiation of production. Foreign investments in firms engaged in basic industries and in those which export at least 80 per cent of their produc­ tion to countries outside the Andean Common Market are exempt from the gradual transfer requirement to mixed companies. Investment in the mining sector is governed by the General M i n i ng L aw (Decree-Law N o. 18880) of June 8, 1971, which replaced the M i n i ng Code of M ay 12, 1950. Companies holding mining concessions may enter into mining contracts with the Government providing for special incentives and guarantees or constituting mixed enterprises with government participation of at least 25 per cent. Under the regime of mining contracts, the Government may grant to mining concessionaires initiating large-scale investment programs tax incen­ tives and guaranteed availability of foreign exchange for transfers of (a) recovery of investment; (b) interest payments if the rate does not exceed 3 per cent above the prime rate in the financial market from which the loans originate; (c) payments for justified services; and (d) reasonable profit remittances, together with guaranteed access to the most favorable exchange rate. M ix ed mining enterprises may receive all the benefits and incentives which may be granted by special con­ tract and, in addition, special tax reductions. Gold Residents may freely purchase, ho ld, and sell gold in any form in Peru. A ll imports and exports of gold are settled in the certificate market. Exchange is made available only for imports of gold bars by the monetary authorities and by authorized industrial and professional users. The import and export of precious metals is the monopoly of the Banco M ine ro del Peru. Changes during 1971 January 19. Decree-Law N o. 18737 entered into effect. It amplified certain provisions of Decree-Law N o. 18275 of M ay 15, 1970 which had introduced comprehensive exchange control measures in the draft market. The Banco de la N a t i on was authorized to permit the opening of foreign exchange accounts by nonresident individuals and firms. Such accounts could be credited only with funds originating from abroad and with interest accruing on any outstanding balances. The Central Reserve Bank and the Banco de la N a t i on were authorized to permit Peruvian credit institutions to maintain foreign exchange accounts to the extent 347 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution P E RU that such accounts were required to carry out foreign exchange transactions in the exchange certificate and draft markets. A ll documents pertaining to investments and foreign exchange holdings of Peruvian nationals abroad had to be deposited with the Banco de la N a t i on within 30 days from January 19. January 20. Supreme Decree N o. 004-71-EF of Janu­ ary 19 became effective; it implemented Decree-Law N o. 18275 of M ay 15, 1970, which had reorganized the operation of the draft market. Conditions were outlined in detail under which foreign exchange could be sold by the Banco de la N a t i on or its agents for a large number of payments for cur­ rent invisibles. The Decree transferred from the Exchange Committee established by Decree-Law N o. 18275 to the Banco de la N a t i on the power to authorize the sale of exchange in excess of standard allocations in exceptional cases. It also defined the con­ ditions under which the proceeds of the sales of assets owned in Peru by nonresident physical persons could be transferred abroad. Tax clearance was made a prerequisite for obtaining exchange in a large number of cases. The Decree further specified that claims in foreign exchange accruing to natural or jur id ical per­ sons residing in Peru had to be declared at the Banco de la N a t i on within 15 days of their accrual. A ll foreign exchange receipts from abroad derived from services rendered, income from investments, and other transactions not channeled through the exchange certi­ ficate market had to be sold to the Banco de la N a t i on within 10 days of receipt; this did not apply, however, to those individuals and companies allowed to maintain foreign exchange accounts with the Banco de la N a t i o n. Jur id ical persons established in Peru and regularly requiring or receiving foreign exchange outside the certificate market had to submit annually to the Banco de la N a t i on an estimate of their expected requirements or receipts; if they failed to do so, the Banco de la N a t i on was released from the obligation to consider their applications for foreign exchange. The Decree also defined resident status of ind i­ viduals and companies for purposes of the regulations governing the draft market. It established for exchange control purposes the provisions that legal residence abroad for at least two years was required before Peruvian nationals could be considered nonresidents; Peruvians acquiring foreign nationality would during that two-year period remain subject, therefore, to the same exchange control treatment as Peruvian nationals. Restrictions were imposed on payments for certain cur­ rent invisibles that previously were unrestricted; certain existing restrictions were intensified. Detailed provisions of the Decree included the following: The allocation for tourist travel was set at the equivalent of S /. 1,500 a person a day, subject to a maximum of S /. 90,000 a person a calendar year, and that for business travel at S /. 2,200 a day for company directors (plus S /. 20,000 a trip for repre­ 348 sentation expenses), S /. 1,700 a day for executives, and S /. 1,300 a day for other employees. Exchange alloca­ tions for a ll travel were subject to pr ior payment of the travel tax. Previously, there was a general travel alloca­ tion of S /. 1,800 a person a day, for up to 60 days in any one calendar year, as we ll as an additional allocation of S /. 8,000 a person, which could only be taken up once a year. Foreign nationals leaving Peru permanently could henceforth purchase the equivalent of S /. 1.5 m i l l ion in foreign currency, provided that they could prove the source of their income; any balance remaining over this l im it had to be deposited at the Banco de la N a t i on and would be remittable in annual installments, the size of which would be deter­ mined on the merits of each individual case. Residents of foreign nationality could remit the equivalent of up to S /. 50,000 a year to dependents l iv ing abroad. Foreign nationals receiving their pay in soles could remit up to 50 per cent of their income for payment of social insurance contributions and pension funds, and for the payment of proved debts and obligations; if such remittances were made, however, they could not purchase foreign exchange for any other purpose within the same calendar year. Foreign nationals apply­ ing for foreign exchange for tourist or business travel received the same treatment as Peruvian residents, unless they held a current account in foreign currency at the Banco de la N a t i o n, in which case they were not entitled to purchase foreign exchange for travel or any type of personal remittance. No exchange would be granted for the transfer of pensions of former c iv il servants who without official permission resided abroad. January 26. Industrial firms were to use Peruvian capital goods and materials whenever avail­ able, and required prior approval for a ll imports. The time l im it stipulated in contracts signed with the State for the reversion to Peruvian control of foreign-owned industrial firms would depend on the size of the invest­ ment, the type of firm, the estimated profits, and the level of technology used. January 27. Decree-Law N o. 18748 provided defini­ tions of national and foreign investors and companies. It classified as foreign investors those persons who con­ tribute capital to a company from abroad w i th the right to repatriate the capital and to transfer earnings abroad; owners of local currency funds derived from the reinvestment of capital that could be remitted abroad were also classified as foreign investors. Foreign companies were defined as those in which national investors held less than 51 per cent of the company's capital, and mixed companies as those in which national investors held between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital. Na t ional investors were considered to be the Government and its agencies, national com­ panies, employees' associations, other Peruvian-owned institutions, and individual nationals resident in Peru; foreign nationals who had maintained uninterrupted residence in Peru for one year could also be classified as national investors, provided that they renounced the right to re-export capital and transfer profits abroad. National companies were those in which at least 80 per cent of the capital was held by national investors. March 9. Decree-Law N o. 18802 provided that the State would guarantee the exchange risk involved in external borrowing operations by the public sector. Such borrowing and the giving of guarantees on foreign borrowing henceforth required prior approval by the M in is try of Economy and Finance. March 26. The General Fisheries L aw (Decree-Law N o. 18810 of M a r ch 25) became effective. The fishing industry was divided into three priority categories. Foreign companies classified in the first category (i.e., engaged in fishing for direct human consumption) would be treated as national companies, but a ll other foreign- owned companies in the industry were required to sign contracts with the State within 180 days, stating the date by which 51 per cent of their capital would be transferred to Peruvian investors. April 2. Decree N o. 106-71-AG permitted the unre­ stricted sale of all forms of coffee in the domestic market. April 11. Decree-Law N o. 18826 extended until July 31, 1971 the date by which companies must, under the terms of the General Industrial Law, declare to the Ministry of Industry and Commerce the extent of for­ eign participation in their capital and sign contracts with the Government. The deadline was further extended to December 31, 1971 by Decree-Law N o. 18895 of June 23. May 18. Decree-Law N o. 18858 restricted further the granting of loans by local banks and other financial or credit institutions to firms with foreign equity participa­ tion of 20 per cent or more. The total amount of such credits with less than a one-year maturity could not P E RU exceed the capital and retained earnings of the bor­ rower. Loans for longer periods could be granted only to finance new investment projects and could not exceed three times the value of the loca l ly owned equity hold­ ing. Discounts of local firms' trade bills were excluded from these limitations. May 25. Decree-Law N o. 18865 replaced the existing tax on the sale of exchange for foreign travel w i th a tax on a traveler's consumption of goods and services abroad. The tax was to be applied to the value of goods and services acquired abroad gratuitously, against pay­ ment, or in exchange for a traveler's goods and services. It was to be paid by residents prior to departure on the basis of a sworn declaration specifying, separately, the amount of the fare, the value of anticipated services to be received, and the amount of daily expenses; any excess or deficiency was to be settled upon return on the basis of a final declaration of expenses. The rate of tax remained unchanged (at 10 per cent on amounts within the daily allocations and 50 per cent on amounts in excess of those allocations), but the coverage was broadened to include the cost of passages, whether pur­ chased in Peru or abroad and whether settled in foreign or domestic currency, and the minimum amount of tax was set at S /. 50 a day for the period spent abroad. June 8. Supreme Decree N o. 064-71-EF became effec­ tive. It modified certain provisions of Supreme Decree N o. 004-71-EF (see January 20, above). The require­ ment was removed that exceptional circumstances had to be involved before the Banco de la N a t i on could authorize the sale of foreign exchange in excess of established limits for those categories of invisibles for which basic limits were fixed. The condition of a pr ior tax clearance was removed for the sale of exchange for amortization and interest payments on foreign loans, payments of insurance and reinsurance premiums, and expenses for foreign travel. A l s o, the condition under which foreign exchange was sold for the payment of correspondence courses abroad was changed; hence­ forth, such exchange would be sold provided a prior authorization of the M in is t ry of Education had been obtained for such study. June 8. A new General M i n i ng L aw (Decree-Law N o. 18880) was published, to become effective 120 days after the date of its publication and to replace the M i n­ ing Code of M ay 12, 1950. It consolidated and elabo­ rated the main principles of existing m in ing legislation as modified in A p r il 1970. The Empresa M ine ra del Peru would by October 14, 1971 be granted a complete monopoly over mineral exports, with the exception that joint-venture companies were permitted to negotiate long-term supply contracts abroad in order to obtain financing. Decree-Law N o. 18891 modified certain pro­ visions of Decree-Law N o. 17710 and Supreme Decree N o. 150-69-EF regarding the operation of the certificate market. F or purposes of complying with the surrender requirement, exporters could deduct from the f.o.b. value of their export proceeds specified percentages for commissions and other established charges incurred abroad. Henceforth, a ll exchange receipts from foreign loans and from private bond issues abroad had to be surrendered in the certificate market; previously, foreign exchange in respect of the above transactions was chan­ neled through the certificate market only if service pay­ ments for such obligations were to be made through that market. Service payments for the refinancing of specified obligations contracted prior to the re- establishment of the dual market (October 1967) could be made through the certificate market. June 17. Supreme Decree N o. 088-71-EF modified certain other provisions of Decree-Law N o. 17710 and the regulation implementing this law (Supreme Decree N o. 150-69-EF). Procedures for the sale of foreign exchange through the certificate market for salaries of foreign technicians were restated. Certain prior require­ ments for the sale of such exchange were removed; these related to the observance of a maximum participa­ tion of foreign technicians in both the employment of and the wage b i ll of Peruvian companies. Interest pay­ ments on foreign loans, including import financing, could not exceed the rates prevailing for the same type of operations in the country of the lender; previously, interest payments for import financing could be up to 3 per cent above the prime rate in the market front- where the financing originated. The use of foreign exchange certificates for import payments was made subject to the prior authorization of the Central Reserve Bank. In the case of advance import payments without shipping documents, submission of contracts or other documents supporting the transaction was required, and the bank had to deposit with the Central Reserve Bank the local currency counterpart of the f.o.b. value of the import; the deposit was to be taken over by the Central Reserve Bank if the required shipping documents were not submitted w i th in 30 days after the utilization of the foreign exchange. The surrender requirements for the proceeds from nontraditional exports were eased by allowing the exporter to deduct 8 per cent of the f.o.b. value for commissions. 350 June 22. June 30. Decree-Law N o. 18900 ratified the Andean Group's Cartagena Agreement on the treatment of for­ eign capital and with minor modifications amended Peruvian legislation in accordance with Decisions 24 and 37 of the Cartagena Agreement. A ll foreign invest­ ment in Peru required the pr ior approval of the com­ petent authorities with a view to channeling such invest­ ments to projects considered essential for the country's development. The Decree-Law modified the provisions of the General Industrial Law (N o. 18350) of July 1970 which required existing foreign companies to reduce the share of foreign capital participation to specified per­ centages; foreign companies incorporated in Peru before June 30, 1971 now had to agree, w i th in 3 years, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in such companies so as to transfer them to mixed or national companies (for definitions see January 27, above) during a maximum period of 15 years following the entry into effect of this regime. U p on expiration of the 3-year period, the participation of national investors in the capital of an enterprise had to amount to not less than 15 per cent; this participation had to increase to at least 45 per cent after 10 years and to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign companies established in Peru as at January 1, 1971, the 15 per cent participation by national investors had to be secured at the time of the initiation of pro­ duction. Foreign investments in basic industries (e.g., mining, forestry, and petroleum), and in those exporting at least 80 per cent of their production to countries out­ side the Andean Common Marke t, were exempt from the requirement of gradual transfer to mixed com­ panies. Implementing regulations were to be issued w i th in 30 days. June 30. In accordance w i th Decree-Law N o. 18900, transfers of profits on foreign capital were limited to 14 per cent a year. Decree-Law N o. 19028 provided for the establishment w i th in 15 days of a Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector. The Board's main functions were to prepare annually a foreign exchange budget for the private sector (in accordance with the priorities set forth in the Development Plan) and to establish the annual amounts up to which individual private sector importers could import. A ll private ind i­ viduals and companies would be required to submit to the Central Reserve Bank and the Banco de la N a t i o n, on a date to be established by the Board, a statement of their foreign currency needs, specified as to certificate market and draft market. Pending the formulation of the Board's 1972 for­ eign exchange budget, the amount of imports that could be made by individuals and companies during the next six months was to be established by the Central Reserve Bank on the basis of the monthly average recorded dur­ ing 1970 and the first half of 1971, and would be re­ corded on temporary importers' cards. 11.
