In addi­ tion, varying provisional rates of refund not exceeding 10 per cent were introduced pending final classification of some commodities. The tax refund must not exceed the amount of indirect taxes and charges actually paid. Proceeds from Invisibles F i rms or individuals not in the category of authorized institutions cannot accept more than the equivalent of US$100 from foreign tourists and are required to sur­ render any exchange earnings in the form of foreign banknotes and travelers checks to an authorized bank within ten days. Otherwise, foreign exchange accruing to residents for services rendered by them to nonresi­ dents must be surrendered to an authorized exchange dealer within three months from the date on which the service was rendered or within ten days from the date of acquisition of the exchange. Remittances from Tu rk ish workers abroad are sold to the Central Bank at LT 10.50 per U. S. dollar; when the Tu rk ish l i ra equivalent is credited to a bank account in Turkey, an additional amount of 33% per cent is immediately credited to the account representing three years' interest at 11.11 per cent per annum, resulting in an effective exchange rate of LT 14.00 per U. S. dollar. The amounts deposited plus the interest can be withdrawn at any t im e .12 Fo r­ eign travelers wishing to take out articles with a value exceeding LT 2,000 must show proof that they have converted foreign exchange to cover the portion of the cost exceeding this l im i t. The import of Tu rk ish banknotes and coins by trav­ elers (whether of Tu rk ish or foreign nationality) is limited to LT 100. The import of foreign currency by travelers is unrestricted. Capital Foreign investments in Turkey require approval. Cap i tal transfers abroad by residents and capital trans­ actions between residents and nonresidents are subject to the approval of the exchange control authorities. Residents are not normally permitted to acquire foreign securities or real estate. W i th the exception of certain investments made in accordance with the provisions of the Law to Encourage Foreign Investments or the Petroleum Law, foreign companies and contractors who wish to do business in Turkey must import the required capital and operating funds in the form of foreign exchange, although under certain conditions blocked funds may be used for investment in the tourist industry. Borrowing in Tu rk ish liras by such foreign companies and contractors is sub­ ject to quotas set by the M in is t ry of Finance in accord­ ance with their equity capital in Tu rkey. Except for approved investments, nonresidents may not convert 12 Foreign nationals in Turkey and Turkish workers abroad may open convertible lira accounts at Turkish banks. 4 30 into foreign currency any assets or balances owned by them, or earnings accruing to them; a ll earnings are blocked but if, at the end of the calendar year, such earnings are less than LT 5,000, the amount involved is deblocked. Subject to ind iv idual permission, blocked assets and balance may be utilized w i th in Turkey, e.g., for the payment of taxes, insurance, and maintenance and repair of property; and for l iv ing expenses of up to LT 4,500 a month for each beneficiary for owners of such funds or their authorized representatives, and up to LT 2,500 for certain relatives. They may not, however, be utilized as business capital except for investment in the tourist industry. No rma l ly, such blocked funds may not be transferred to others except by legal succession. The investment of blocked funds in the tourist industry is subject to the following conditions: (1) there must be a contribution in new foreign exchange or imported equipment equal to at least 50 per cent of the blocked funds to be used and (2) the investor must undertake not to request transfer for at least five years of that part of the capital financed by means of the blocked funds. Blocked funds used in this manner are considered as foreign capital imported under the L aw to Encourage Foreign Investments. Balances on nonresident accounts established at the Central Bank in accordance with the Paris Agreement on Commerc ial Debts Owed by Residents of Turkey (1959) may be used either partially or wholly by the creditors for investment or to pay expenses in Turkey at any time prior to the date, established under the Agreement, when the balances may be transferred. The use of these balances for investment purposes is subject to the provisions of the Law to Encourage Foreign Investments. However, invested funds and income related thereto may not be transferred abroad before the transfer date established under the Agreement, except for investment in the export industry or in other industries earning foreign exchange; in such instances the equivalent of up to 25 per cent of the investment may be transferred annually. Foreign capital invested in Turkey under the terms of the Law to Encourage Foreign Investments is accorded preferential treatment, provided that the enterprise in which the investment is to be made is deemed to con­ tribute to the economic development of the country, or w i ll operate in a field of activity open to Tu rk i sh p r i­ vate enterprise and w i ll not entail monopoly or special privilege. Under this law, a ll or part of the invested capital or foreign loans may be remitted abroad in the original currency of the capital. U p on application, the M in is t ry of Finance guarantees the transfer of dividends and of the proceeds from the sale or liquidation of shares or stock certificates registered on the books of companies established under the law. Such registered shares or stock certificates are freely transferable between foreign nationals, both in Turkey and abroad, and between foreign nationals and residents. The trans­ fer guarantees pass on to the new owner, provided that ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution his name is notified to the M in is t ry of Finance; if the shares or stock certificates are sold to a resident, how­ ever, they must be presented to the M in is t ry of Finance for cancellation of the guarantees. The capital and interest on long-term loans and credits extended by non­ residents to enterprises in Turkey (including those of an agricultural character) may be accorded the same trans­ fer benefits. Foreign capital imported under the Petro­ leum Law is accorded additional preferential treatment. Transactions in securities, including their export and import, require approval when nonresident interests are involved. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Turkey for numismatic purposes. W i th this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad; any unworked gold held in Turkey, however, may be pre­ sented for minting by the State M i n t. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the M in is t ry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and indus­ tr ial users. Changes during 1971 January 4. The 1971 import program was published, introducing a new import system. Imports under the program were expected to amount to $1,045 m i l l ion during the year. Imports were classified into liberalized goods, for which licenses were to be issued freely, l ib­ eralized imports requiring authorization, and an annual list of imports subject to global quotas. Guarantee deposits were reduced to 50 per cent of the value of imports for goods on liberalized list I and to 40 per cent for imports on liberalized list II. Ea r ly in the year, the existing backlog of exchange applications for imports was eliminated. February 5. A communique was issued amending the regulations concerning imports without foreign exchange allocation. March 31. The bilateral payments agreement with Yugoslavia expired. April 29. A decree was published revising the trade system. Au thor i ty to regulate imports and exports was vested in the newly established M in is t ry of Foreign Economic Relations ( M O F E R ). Imports and exports were made subject to prior price control by M O F E R. In the examination of applications for export price approval and in the allocation of foreign exchange for imports, M O F ER would consider, among other factors, the income earned and income or corporation tax paid by exporters and importers during the preceding three T U R K EY years. The issuance of permits for authorized imports, formerly vested in various ministries according to com­ modity, was made the responsibility of M O F E R. May 5. Regulations were issued specifying details of export and import procedures. May 13. Applications for foreign exchange allocations against specified import quotas were required to be accompanied by a certificate confirming that the com­ modities concerned were not manufactured in sufficient quantity and quality by local industry. July 9. The special exchange rate applying to the proceeds of specified agricultural exports was depreci­ ated from LT 12 to LT 13 per U S $ 1. August 23. The official buying and selling rates for the U. S. dollar were maintained at LT 14.85 and LT 15.00 per US $ 1. September 1. The commercial provisions of the interim agreement with the European Econom ic C om­ munity regarding the transitional period of Turkey's association with the E EC entered into effect. Customs duties on imports into Turkey from E EC countries were reduced by 5 per cent and 10 per cent, depending on the commodity; an equivalent reduction applied to the stamp duty. Turkey freed from quantitative restriction commodities included in a list of liberalized imports consolidated to the E E C, covering 35 per cent of Turkey's private imports from member countries of the Community during 1967; the proportion of liberalized goods would be raised at specified intervals during the transitional period. Turkey would refrain from intro­ ducing new quantitative restrictions on imports from E EC countries; however, should Turkey find it neces­ sary to restrain imports of items included in the liberal­ ized lists, it would open quotas for imports of these items from E EC countries equal to at least 75 per cent of average imports of such commodities from the C om­ munity during the preceding three years. Du r ing the period of transition to a customs union with the E E C, Turkey was to reduce progressively import duties or taxes with an equivalent effect on imports from member countries of the Community. F or this purpose, imports were classified into two categories. Du r ing the transi­ tional period, Turkey's external tariff would be aligned to that of the E E C. October 15. The selling rate for the U. S. dollar was changed from LT 15.00 to LT 15.375 per US $ 1. The buying rate remained unchanged at LT 14.85 per US $ 1. November 14. The maximum exchange allocation for tourist travel was increased from the equivalent of US$200 to US$400 a person a calendar year. December 22. A central rate of LT 14 = US$1 came into effect, and Turkey would avail itself of wider mar­ gins. The separate rate applying to proceeds of specified agricultural exports was maintained at LT 13 = US $ 1. 431 ©International Monetary Fund. S. dollar, the intervention currency, is U Sh 7.14286 = US $ 1. Uganda has availed itself of wider margins. The Bank of Uganda does not deal in foreign cu r renc ie s1 other than sterling, U. S. dollars, and deutsche mark; its rate for the U. S. dollar is fixed and its rates for sterling and deutsche mark are based on the previous day's London rates against the U. S. dollar. Commerc ial banks in Uganda deal in a ll speci­ fied currencies 2 and base their rates on the previous day's closing rates against the U. S. dollar in London, except for K enya and Tanzania shillings, which are dealt in at par. East A f r i c an shillings (which have ceased to be legal tender) may be exchanged at par at the Bank of Uganda and the commercial banks. The latter may freely deal forward with customers in ster­ l ing, U. S. dollars, and other currencies, provided that there is an underlying import or export contract and that the term of the forward contract does not exceed three months; contracts for longer periods require exchange control approval. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Uganda on behalf of the M in is ter of Finance. Au thor i ty for approving many payments in respect of current invisibles and some capital payments is delegated to the authorized banks. Import and export control is administered by the M in i s t ry of Commerce and Industry under the External Trade A ct and by the Export and Import Corporation under the Export and Import Corporation A c t. The Minister of Commerce and Industry has powers to pro­ hibit imports and exports. The Na t ional Trad ing Co r­ poration has the sole right to the wholesale distribution of specified commodities. Together with K enya and Tanzania, Uganda is part of the East A f r i c an currency area but exchange control is temporarily being applied to both Kenya and Tan­ zania. Prescription of Currency Uganda is a member of the Sterling A r ea and main­ tains prescription of currency requirements similar to those of the Un i ted K ingdom; a ll payments to K enya and Tanzania, however, must be effected in East A f r i­ can currency,3 either through an East A f r i c an Account 1 Foreign currencies are all currencies other than the Uganda shilling. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish and Faroese kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U. S. dollars, and all Sterling Area currencies other than the Uganda shilling. 8 East African currency comprises Uganda shillings, Kenya shillings, and Tanzania shillings. 4 32 in Uganda or in Kenya or Tanzania shillings. Payments to residents of countries in the Sterling A r ea other than Kenya, Tanzania, and South A f r i ca may be made in Uganda shillings to the credit of a Sterling A r ea Account in Uganda or in any other Sterling A r ea currency; receipts from such countries may be obtained in Uganda shillings from a Sterling A r ea Account in Uganda or in any convertible currency. Au thor ized pay­ ments, including payments for imports, by residents of Uganda to residents of countries outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesia may be made to an External Account in any Sterling A r ea country, in Uganda shil­ lings to the credit of an External Account in Uganda, or in any other non-Sterling A r ea currency except Rho­ desian currency that is appropriate to the country of residence of the payee. Receipts from countries outside the Sterling A rea other than Rhodesia may be obtained in Uganda shillings from an External Accoun t, in any Sterling A r ea specified currency from an External Accoun t, or in any other specified currency that is not a Sterling A r ea currency. Payments to Rhodesia, South A f r i c a, and South-West A f r i ca (Nam ib ia) are pro­ hibited. Nonresident Accounts Sterling Area Accounts are held by residents of other Sterling A r ea countries except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be credited freely with all authorized pay­ ments to such Sterling A r ea countries by Uganda resi­ dents, with transfers from other Sterling A r ea Accounts, with transfers from External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales to an authorized dealer in Uganda of any foreign currency or gold by residents of any other country in the Sterling A r ea except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be debited freely for payments for exports to other countries in the Sterling A r ea and other payments due by residents of other countries in the Sterling A r ea to Ugandan residents, for payments to residents of other countries in the Sterling A r ea for any purpose, for transfers to other Sterling A r ea Accounts in Uganda, for purchases of any Sterling A r ea currency, and for withdrawals by the account holder while he is temporarily resident in Uganda; provided that permis­ sion of the appropriate exchange control authorities in a Sterling A rea country has been obtained, Sterling A rea Accounts may exceptionally be debited for transfers to External Accounts in Uganda or elsewhere in the Ster­ l ing A rea, and for purchases in Uganda of any non- Sterling A rea currency or gold. Accounts in Uganda shillings held by residents of countries outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesia with authorized banks are, with exchange control approval, designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments to such coun­ tries by residents of Uganda, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution any non-Sterling A rea currency (other than Rhodesian currency) and gold by nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea to authorized dealers; provided that the permission of the appropriate exchange control authorities in a Ster­ ling A r ea country has been obtained, External Accounts may also be credited with transfers from Sterling A r ea Accounts. They may be debited freely for payments to residents of the Sterling A r e a, for transfers to other External Accounts in Uganda or in any other Sterling Area country, and for purchases of non-Sterling A rea currencies from authorized dealers. Nontransferable funds of persons not resident in Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prior approval, balances on Blocked Accounts may be used for the purchase in Uganda of specified bonds and shares issued in Uganda; the redemption proceeds of government bonds so acquired are transferable begin­ ning five years from the date of purchase. Subject to ind iv idual permission, such balances may also be used for payments to residents not related to export transac­ tions. Transfers between B locked Accounts in Uganda, and to B locked Accounts in Kenya and Tanzania, require prior approval. Imports and Import Payments A ll permitted imports require licenses. Some imports from a ll sources are prohibited for reasons of public po l icy; imports prohibited for other reasons include cotton fabrics, electrical home refrigerators, transistor radios, and matches. A ll imports from Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited and imports from Portuguese-controlled territories in A f r i ca are not being licensed. A ll goods originating in mainland Ch ina must be imported through the intermediary of the Na t ional Trad ing Corpora t ion. A number of other commodities may only be imported by or to the order of the Export and Import Corporation, or with the Corporation's writ­ ten authorization. Imports normally must be purchased direct from the country of or ig in. Some imports of manufactured goods from Kenya and Tanzania are sub­ ject to transfer taxes. When the importer has obtained authorization to import from the Export and Import Corporation, the Bank of Uganda w i ll allocate foreign exchange upon payment of the specified advance deposit. The deposit amounts to 10 per cent of the c.i.f. value for essentials, 100 per cent for specified luxury goods, and 50 per cent for a ll other goods. The deposits must be held for a m in imum of three months for imports from Kenya and Tanzania and for at least six months for other imports. The Export and Import Corporation w i ll issue the import license after the importer has received an exchange allocation and has made the required deposit. Documentary evidence showing that the goods have been imported into Uganda must be forwarded to the Exchange Con t rol within six months. Payments for non­ essential imports are made after arrival of the goods, but advance payment is permitted for essential goods. U G A N DA Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are controlled and those to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Authorized banks are empowered to approve specified categories of current payments up to established limits; amounts above these limits may be approved adminis­ tratively. The basic allowance for travel outside Uganda is the equivalent of U Sh 2,000 a person every three years, which may be taken out in foreign banknotes. The allowance is available for travel to any country except Kenya and Tanzania, for which holiday facilities of up to U Sh 500 a person a year are available, and Rhodesia and South A f r i c a, for which no allocation is granted. Salaried noncitizens recruited from outside East A f r i ca may obtain allocations for travel outside East A f r i ca at the time of their overseas leave. No foreign exchange is released for nursery, primary, and secondary education abroad except for children of diplomats, technical assistance personnel, nonnationals working in Uganda on overseas terms, nonnational missionaries, and other special cases. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may during their stay in Uganda remit to their country of origin up to 33V3 per cent of their gross monthly earnings, to cover family maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment which includes a firm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the con­ tract. The export of Uganda banknotes and coins by trav­ elers is prohibited, except that travelers to Kenya and Tanzania may export U Sh 100 in Uganda currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain foodstuffs and agricultural products require licenses and may be subject to restriction in order to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Uganda. Other goods may be exported without licenses. A ll exports to South A f r i c a, the Portuguese territories in A f r i c a, and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds in specified currencies (see foot­ note 2) must be collected within six months of expor­ tation and offered to an authorized bank in Uganda for conversion into Uganda shillings. Coffee is subject to export duty, and an export tax of 40 per cent ad valorem is levied on copper and copper alloys sold at a price in excess of <£ stg. 400 a ton. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 2) must be sold to an authorized bank. The import of Uganda banknotes and coins by travelers is prohibited, except that travelers from Kenya and Tan­ zania may bring in U Sh 100 each. Travelers may freely bring in foreign currency notes and foreign cur­ rency travelers checks. 433 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U G A N DA Capital Cap i tal transfers to a ll countries are restricted and those to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Residents of Uganda, however, may be granted exemp­ tions from the deposit and surrender requirements in respect of foreign assets for specified Sterling A r ea assets held prior to June 11, 1965. Specified capital transfers up to established amounts are approved by authorized banks; all other capital transfers require individual exchange control approval. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may transfer their assets up to the equivalent of U Sh 50,000. (The allowance is reduced by the amount of insurance pre­ miums remitted after 1965 outside the facilities for remittance of savings.) A further transfer of up to the equivalent of U Sh 20,000 upon each anniversary of the emigrant's departure is allowed. A ll remaining funds must be credited to a Blocked Account and may either be invested in certain approved securities or held on deposit with a bank in Uganda; such funds become transferable after five years. The income from such investments is transferable also during the period when the funds are blocked. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Uganda; but to secure guaranteed repatriation, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the investment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Pro­ tection) A c t, 1964, which in normal circumstances is given freely. Foreign and domestic investment in speci­ fied types of production require approval under the East A f r i c an Industrial Licensing A ct and the Uganda Licensing A c t, 1969. Dividends and profits due to nonresidents from normal trading operations and dis­ tributed by companies operating in Uganda are trans­ ferable. A ll imports and exports of securities require approval. App roval is freely granted for the purchase by non­ residents of Ugandan securities, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is remittable, and the proceeds on resale are normally remittable also. Purchases of securities outside Uganda by residents are not normally per­ mitted. A resident of Uganda may not send, as a gift, to any country more than U Sh 100 a year without specific exchange control approval. W i th minor exceptions, loans or overdraft facilities granted to a nonresident or to a body corporate resi­ dent in Uganda which is by any means controlled, whether directly or indirectly, by persons resident out­ side Uganda require prior exchange control approval. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Uganda for numismatic purposes. W i th this excep­ tion, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in Uganda in any form 434 other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the M in is t ry of Finance. Expo rt licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. The import of the fo l­ lowing from a ll sources other than Kenya and Tan­ zania, and from Kenya and Tanzania when originating in other countries, is subject to ind iv idual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or s i l­ versmiths' wares, including set gems; bu l l ion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Import licenses for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets), gold jewelry, and gold coins are issued to goldsmiths only and are issued restrictively. Changes during 1971 April 26. Market rates for spot transactions in other convertible or externally convertible currencies (except those currencies for which quotations are based on sterling) are free to move within a range of rates resulting from the official dollar limits of the United K ingdom in relation to the dollar limits of the other countries concerned. Au thor ized banks are allowed to engage in spot and forward exchange transactions in any currencies, except Rho­ desian currency, subject to the observance of limits on open positions and the accumulation of spot foreign exchange. Fo rwa rd rates may fluctuate under the influ­ ence of market forces; transactions with resident cus­ tomers may be entered into only for approved pur­ poses, where there is an underlying commercial contract and in the currency of the contract.1 There is also a market in which the foreign currency proceeds 2 (referred to as investment currency) resulting mainly from the sale outside the Sterling A r ea of for­ eign currency securities,3 direct investments, and per­ sonal property owned by residents may be negotiated at freely determined rates, usually attracting a premium over the official market rate; at the end of 1971, that premium was about 2 9^ per cent. These funds are available for reinvestment in marketable foreign cur­ rency securities and for approved direct investments and personal property acquisitions in countries outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesia. The authorized banks may deal among themselves and with residents and nonresidents in foreign notes and coins (other than Rhodesian currency) at free market rates of exchange. The United K ingdom formally accepted the obliga­ tions of A r t ic le V I I I, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory Exchange control is not imposed on transactions with other parts of the Sterling A r ea ("Scheduled T e r r i­ tories" in the nomenclature of the U. K. exchange control) .4 Exceptionally, sterling payments to Hong K o ng are screened under Hong K o ng regulations to ensure that residents in other parts of the Sterling A r ea do not have access to Hong Kong's free market, and special restrictions are imposed on the disposal of sterling assets of residents of H o ng K o n g. Con t rol is also exercised over the acquisition of foreign currency securities from the rest of the Sterling A r e a. W i th respect to outward capital transfers, a program of voluntary restraint applies to direct and portfolio invest­ ment in the more developed countries of the Sterling A r ea (Australia, the Irish Repub l ic ,5 New Zealand, and South A f r i c a, see section on Cap i ta l, below).6 Administration of Control Exchange control in the Un i ted K ingdom is adminis­ tered by the Bank of England on behalf of the U. K. Treasury, as is the voluntary restraint program on certain outward investment. However, practically a ll commercial banks are authorized to approve most current payments requiring exchange control permis­ sion. The licensing of imports and exports is handled by the Department of Trade and Industry. Prescription of Currency Receipts from countries in the Sterling A r ea may be in any Sterling A r ea currency; those from countries outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesia must be in sterling from an Ex ternal Account or in any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency), wh ich must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless permis­ sion has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Payments to countries in the Sterling A r ea may be made in any Sterling A r ea currency; pay­ ments to countries outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesia may be made by crediting sterling to an Exter­ nal Account or in any foreign currency except Rhode­ sian currency. External Accounts. W i th the exception of Rhodesian Accounts and the Rhodesian Special Account (see below), the sterling accounts of nonresidents with banks in the Un i ted K ingdom, i.e., those of residents of countries outside the Sterling A r e a, are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments by residents of the Sterling A r e a, w i th transfers from other External Accounts, with the proceeds from sales of gold or foreign cur­ rency other than Rhodesian currency (including bank­ notes), and with sterling banknotes mailed from out­ side the Sterling A r e a. External Accounts may be debited, subject to general or special permission, for payments to residents of the Sterling A r e a, for transfers to other External Accounts, for transfers to Rhodesian Accounts other than in payment for certain goods exported from Rhodesia, for payments in cash in the Un i ted K ingdom, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency (including banknotes) or gold. Rhodesian Accounts. These accounts are applicable to residents of Rhodesia only. Permitted credits include transfers from External Accounts, provided that the U N I T ED K I N G D OM bank has no reason to believe that the payment is for a purpose prohibited by the Southern Rhodesia (United Nations Sanctions) (No. 2) Order 1968; payments by residents of Sterling A r ea territories other than the Un i ted K ingdom to residents of Rhodesia, subject to the approval of the exchange control authority in the territory concerned; and payments by U. K. residents to residents of Rhodesia in respect of (1) the sale of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency, (2) the discount or maturity proceeds of U. K. treasury bills, (3) permitted imports from Rhodesia which have entered customs in the United K ingdom, (4) insurance and freight charges resulting from permitted trade between Rhodesia and any Sterling A rea territory, (5) insurance claims directly related to such permitted trade, (6) pensions and widows' annuities where asso­ ciated with the deceased husband's employment, and (7) charges and fees relating to patents, designs, and trademarks registered in Rhodesia, Zambia, or M a l aw i. Permitted debits include transfers to the Rhodesian Special Account in respect of pensions and widows' annuities; payments for l iv ing expenses in the Un i ted K ingdom of persons resident in Rhodesia and their families; authorized purchases of U. K. sterling securi­ ties to be held for the account holder; purchases in the Un i ted K ingdom of treasury bills to be held for the account holder; payments to residents of the Sterling A rea for (1) interest on and repayment of outstanding personal loans, advances, and overdrafts granted before November 11, 1965, (2) patents, designs, trademarks, and royalties, (3) distributions from Rhodesian estates and trusts, and (4) subscriptions to newspapers and other periodicals; and payments to U. K. residents for (a) expenses arising out of property in the United K i n g­ dom owned on or before November 11, 1965, (b) taxes, (c) educational fees and incidental expenses, (d) insur­ ance premiums and capital and annuity payments on personal policies taken out on or before November 11, 1965, (e) medical fees, (f) gifts and maintenance not exceeding £ 2 50 for any one payment, to individuals and religious, medical, educational, and charitable organizations, and subscriptions to such organizations, (g) contributions to pension funds provided the person was a member of the fund before November 11, 1965 or before taking up residence after that date, and (h) bank and safe custody charges. Transfers between Rhodesian Accounts and from Rhodesian Accounts to External Accounts are not normally allowed. Suspense Accounts. Unless eligible for credit to Rho­ desian Accounts or to the Rhodesian Special Accoun t, payments to persons resident in Rhodesia must be withheld unless the Bank of England directs otherwise; the funds may be placed on Suspense Accounts and, except with specific permission, may only be (1) used to meet U. K. tax payments and safe custody charges due on the monies in question, or (2) placed on deposit with banks or other financial institutions in the name of the U. K. resident by whom they are held. Permis- 437 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM sion is normally given for residents of Rhodesia to use Suspense Account monies to purchase U. K. sterling securities on a recognized stock exchange in the Un i ted K ingdom and to purchase U. K. Treasury bills and savings bonds and certificates. Permission is only given for them to purchase Rhodesian securities, however, when the funds for the purchase are derived from the sale proceeds of other Rhodesian securities. The Rhodesian Special Account. Th is is an account operated by the Rhodesia Pensions Office staff in London and maintained with the Standard Bank, London. Pensions and associated payments due to beneficiaries in Rhodesia from residents of the Sterling A r e a, and pensions due from Rhodesia to residents of the Un i ted K ingdom and most other parts of the Sterling A r e a, are normally settled through this account. Corresponding transfers from Rhodesian Accounts in the names of individuals to the Rhodesian Special Account are freely permitted. Permission is not nor­ mally given for payments of any other nature to be credited to the Rhodesian Special Accoun t. Subject to specific approval by the Bank of England, any balance on the Special Account may be used to meet the cost of permitted exports to Rhodesia from the Sterling A r ea and of services provided by residents of the Sterling A r ea for account of persons resident in Rhodesia. Imports and Import Payments F or import licensing purposes, countries outside the United K ingdom other than Rhodesia 7 are divided into five groups: other Sterling A rea countries, the Do l lar A r e a ,8 Japan ,9 the Eastern A r e a ,10 and a ll other coun­ tries. Imports from countries other than Rhodesia are admitted under an Open General License without restriction, with the following exceptions: (a) from a ll other countries, 12 commodities or groups of commod­ ities; 11 (b) from all other countries except the Sterling A r e a, 3 commodities or groups of commodities; (c) from the Do l lar A r ea only, 5 commodities or groups of commod i t i e s ;12 (d) from Japan only, certain textiles and domestic pottery; and (e) from the Eastern A r ea only, 14 commodities or groups of commodities. Most 7 A ll goods from Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are not normally granted. 8 The Dollar Area comprises Bolivia, Canada, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Liberia, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Philippines, United States, and Venezuela. 9 Japan will ultimately cease to be treated as in a category by itself. 10 The Eastern Area comprises Albania, Bulgaria, mainland China, Czechoslovak:'a, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, People's Republic of Mongolia, Poland, Rumania, U. S. S. R., and North Viet-Nam. 11 Coffee and coffee preparations from all sources require a specific license to ensure compliance with the International Coffee Agreement. The skins of certain rare animals also cannot be imported under the Open General License from any source. The restrictions on cotton textiles do not apply to countries in Western Europe, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and the United States. 12 With effect from January 20, 1972, quantitative restrictions on imports of certain dairy products originating in or consigned from the Dollar Area were removed. 438 articles subject to restriction can be imported in limited quantities under bilateral or global quotas. Imports of whole hams, other than hams preserved in airtight con­ tainers, are prohibited from a ll non-Sterling A r ea sources. Imports of cereals and cereal products, beef and veal, mutton and lamb, poultry meat, and dairy products other than butter and cheese are subject to minimum import prices enforced through variable import levies. Permission to import from countries outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesia, whether under Open General License or some other form of license carries with it an entitlement to purchase foreign currency or to credit sterling to an External Account to pay for the import, provided that evidence of customs entry is sub­ mitted or evidence that the goods have been dispatched to the United K ingdom or are to be dispatched imme­ diately on receipt of payment. Advance payments for imports are approved by the Bank of England in a ll cases where the payment is considered necessary or in accordance with the traditions of the trade and the continuance of the practice is considered to be essen­ t ia l. Exchange control forms are not required for pay­ ments to residents of the Sterling A r e a; neither are they required for payments to residents of other coun­ tries, unless the payment represents part or final settle­ ment for goods for which the total amount payable exceeds <£ 2,000, and evidence of importation cannot be presented to the bank before making the remittance, or unless foreign currency exceeding the equivalent of <£250 is being bought forward. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Sterling A r ea countries may be made freely. Payments to resi­ dents of countries outside the Sterling A r ea require exchange control authorization, which (except for pay­ ments to residents of Rhode s ia )13 is granted freely for a ll purposes other than sterling usance credits to finance trade directly between principals resident outside the Sterling A r e a, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence. The completion of an exchange control form is required for payments exceeding £ - 2 50 or its equiv­ alent. Authorized banks are permitted to approve applications for transfers on account of many cate­ gories of current invisibles without any l im i ta t ion, and for other categories up to established l im i t s .14 App l i c a- 13 For security reasons, virtually all current payments to Rhodesia are prohibited, except when these result from permitted trade in goods. F or any type of travel outside the Sterling A r ea (except to Rhodes ia), U . K. residents can obtain on demand from banks and authorized travel agents foreign exchange up to the equivalent of £ 3 00 a per­ son a trip; for travel for business or professional rea­ sons, an allowance of <£40 a day up to a maximum of £ 2 , 0 00 for any one journey can be authorized by banks and certain authorized travel agents. A p p l i c a­ tions for additional amounts are approved by the Bank of England unless there is reason to suspect that the exchange is to be used for purposes other than genuine travel expenditure. The cost of accommodation, fares, etc., can be paid for without limit in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom. T ravel exchange purchased in the Un i ted K ingdom must normally be recorded in the traveler's passport. Under arrangements agreed with certain banks, per­ sonal checks may be cashed abroad for travel purposes, up to . £ 30 per check, if backed by check cards. Cred it cards may be used freely to settle travel expenses. Resi­ dent travelers may take out up to £ 3 00 in foreign cur­ rency notes. A ny unused travel exchange must be sur­ rendered w i th in one month of issue or, if the traveler is s t i ll abroad, within one month of return to the United K ingdom. Travel facilities expressed in sterling may be held for six months from the date of issue or for one month from the date of return to the Un i ted K ingdom, if later. In addition, resident travelers may take with them up to £ 25 in U. K. and other Sterling A rea banknotes, which may be exchanged or spent abroad only for travel expenditure; but those traveling direct to the Irish Republic or the Channel Islands may take out any amount. Visitors are, in addition, allowed to take out any notes that they brought in with them, other than notes in excess of £ 25 expressed in the currencies of the United K ingdom or the Irish Republic. Au thor ized banks are permitted to approve, within certain limits and subject to the submission of appro­ priate documentary evidence of the amounts due, applications to pay fees, accommodation charges, and a ll incidental expenses arising from the education of U. K. residents outside the Sterling A r e a. Special regulations apply to a ll travel to Rhodesia. For approved official and essential business journeys the Bank of England w i ll authorize the issue of foreign currency at a rate of up to £ 10 a day with a maximum of £ 2 5 0. Facilities for private travel are authorized only where there are strong compassionate grounds. U N I T ED K I N G D OM Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are not normally issued. V i r tu a l ly a ll exports to other destinations are free of license. No exchange control forms are required. Exporters to countries outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesia must normally obtain appropriate payment w i th in six months of shipment; special exchange control permis­ sion to collect at a later date is required only where the exporter extends credit for more than six months w i th­ out having covered the terms of insurance w i th the Export Credit Guarantee Department ( E C G D ). Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless the recipient has obtained spe­ cific permission to credit them to a retained currency account (subject to supervision) or permission has been given for them to be used for some other purpose. Per­ mitted exports to Rhodesia must be paid for prior to shipment in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency or, if specific permission is granted by the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Accoun t. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of inv is i­ bles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, unless recipients of such currencies have permission to credit them to a retained currency account or to use them for some other purpose. Br i t ish and other bank­ notes may be brought into the Un i ted K ingdom freely. Capital Residents of the United K ingdom who receive the currency of a country outside the Sterling A r ea other than Rhodesian currency from certain capital account sources (mainly the sale or redemption of foreign cur­ rency securities and the sale or liquidation of direct investments or personal property situated outside the Sterling Area) may, in certain circumstances and with permission, use the exchange (which is regarded as investment currency once permission has been given) for the purchase abroad of marketable foreign currency securities or personal property or sell the exchange for sterling to other residents to be used for the same pur­ poses.15 If permission is not forthcoming, the foreign currency must be offered for sale at the rates ru l ing in the official market to an authorized bank in the United K ingdom. K. stock exchange, the income therefrom being freely remittable through the official exchange market. After the four- year period any remaining assets are transferable in accordance w i th the rules then applicable to the assets of a nonresident; at present, the transfer at the official rate of exchange is normally allowed. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized depositories, transactions in securities of a ll types may generally be carried out freely between residents of the Un i ted K ingdom, except that transactions in Rhodesian securities may only be effected on a recognized stock exchange in the Un i ted K ingdom. Residents are nor­ mally permitted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Sterling A r e a, and, after 25 per cent of the proceeds has been sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange, to reinvest the balance of the exchange pro­ ceeds (investment currency) in other marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for such investments or for approved direct investments outside the Sterling A r e a. When foreign currency securities are sold on a U. K. stock exchange for sterling, an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be purchased in the investment cur­ rency market for resale to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. Professional dealers making a "book" may on application be exempt from the 25 per cent requirement in respect of transactions on the "book." Investment currency held for a continuous period of 6 months ceases to be investment currency unless an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the amount held is, at the end of the 6-month period, sold to an authorized bank at the current mar­ ket rate in the official foreign exchange market. Invest­ ment currency may only be retained as investment cur­ rency for a maximum of 12 months, after which period any amount remaining must be offered for sale to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange ma rke t .23 U. K. investment trusts, unit trusts, certain other institutional investors, and pro­ fessional security managers on their own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of making portfolio investments in marketable foreign currency securities. U. K. jobbers and other security dealers may, w i th permission, arrange day-to-day borrowing of for­ eign currency, whether from U. K. banks or from non­ residents, to finance a "book" in foreign currency secu­ rities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Permission is required for a ll transfers of securities in the Un i ted K ingdom in which a nonresident is involved as either transferor or transferee, but most transfers are covered by a general authority. Nonresidents except Rhodesian residents may buy sterling securities on a recognized stock exchange in the Un i ted K ingdom against payment in foreign currency or in sterling from an External Accoun t. Securities so purchased may be exported from the Un i ted K ingdom. Foreign currency securities may be bought and sold by nonresidents on a stock exchange in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom for settlement only in foreign currency; in no circumstances may settlement be in sterling. Nonres i­ dents must obtain permission to buy securities in the Un i ted K ingdom other than on a stock exchange, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Au thor ized banks may freely accept foreign curren­ cies from nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea for deposit; such deposits may be re-lent to other nonresidents or switched into sterling and made available to domestic borrowers. Individual ceilings are set on each bank's open position and on the amount of spot assets which may be held against forward liabilities in foreign cur­ rencies. A l though legal tender, these do not circulate in the Un i ted K i n g d om. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal co in which is for the time being current in the Un i ted K i n g­ dom or wh ich, having been current there, has at any time after M ay 16, 1969 ceased to be so. The import by any resident of the Un i ted K ingdom of gold bu l l ion, gold coins, and gold medals, medal­ lions, tablets or other pieces in p ic tor ial relief or bear­ ing inscriptions is on Open General License, from all sources except Rhodesia, but the holding of, or dealing w i th, bu l l ion is subject to restrictions, as stated above. The export of gold bu l l ion and a ll gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. Au tho r i ty has been given to authorized dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bu l l ion and co in purchased by any non-Sterling A r ea resident in the London gold market against payment in Ex ternal Account sterling or foreign currency. A license is required from the Department of Trade and Industry for the export of gold jewelry, etc., containing diamonds. The export of gold in manufactured form over 100 years o ld and valued at £ 2 , 0 00 and over also requires a license from the Department of Trade and Industry. Manufactures of gold other than medals, medallions, tablets or other pieces in p ic tor ial relief or bearing inscriptions may be imported without quantitative restriction under Open General License from a ll sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are freely traded among (1) authorized dealers in gold, (2) any nonresidents of the Sterling A r e a, and (3) residents of the Sterling A r ea who are sellers of new production. The U. K. authorities do not intervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of Va of 1 per cent is charged on a ll purchases; there is no commission on sales. The market operates on a spot cash basis. Au thor ized banks may not enter into forward transactions in gold without prior permission from the Bank of England. Banks may not finance purchases of gold by nonresidents by lend­ ing foreign exchange or by accepting gold as collateral for advances in foreign currencies or Ex ternal Account sterling to nonresidents of the Sterling A r e a. Changes during 1971 January 1. A ll quota levels for imports of cotton textiles in 1971 were increased by 1 per cent over the 1970 level. January 1. Imports of sugar from countries outside the International Sugar Agreement were restricted. January 5. The Condom in ium of the New Hebrides ceased to be treated administratively as being within the Sterling A r e a. U N I T ED K I N G D OM January 12. Restrictions were placed on borrowing by U. K. residents from nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea to finance expenditure in the Un i ted K ingdom. Au thor ized banks in the Un i ted K ingdom could no longer lend non-Sterling A r ea currency to U. K. resi­ dents other than authorized banks for any purpose without prior reference to the Bank of England. U. K. residents other than authorized banks normally would no longer be permitted to borrow non-Sterling A r ea currency from nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea for conversion into sterling for use in the Un i ted K ingdom, or to finance current payments to nonresidents of the Sterling A r e a, unless the term of the borrowing was at least five years; consideration would in certain c ir­ cumstances be given to shorter-term borrowing, notably to finance export credit. Outstanding borrowings and existing va l id authorizations to borrow were not affected and the changes did not apply to foreign currency bor­ rowing to finance overseas investment or "books" in foreign currency securities. (Borrowing by U. K. author­ ized banks from nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea for the purpose of on-lending in sterling had already been under de facto control, since such on-lending was con­ trolled by the limits placed on bank lending in the Un i ted K ingdom generally.) In addition, U. K. resi­ dents other than authorized banks would not normally be permitted to borrow sterling or other Sterling A r ea currency from non-Sterling A r ea residents for any purpose. January February 15. The Exchange Con t rol (Deposit of Securities) (Exemption) Order 1970 came into opera­ tion. Two exemptions from the deposit requirement were narrowed. Henceforth a ll foreign currency securi­ ties (except those registered in the Un i ted K ingdom or the Channel Islands other than in a subsidiary register on which none of the dividends or interest is payable on presentment of a coupon), and a ll secondary securities relating to foreign currency securities, had to be placed and kept in the custody of an authorized depository. 16. Fo l low ing the termination at the end of 1970 of dealing in U. S. dollar futures contracts on the London Cotton Term inal Marke t, residents with authority to deal were no longer required to meet their commitments for futures contracts expressed in U. S. dollars by borrowing foreign currency. Once again such payments could be made with official exchange. March 17. An agreement on cereals was signed with the Un i ted States. Undertakings were given with respect to minimum import prices for certain cereals. No import levy would be placed on corn imported for industrial use. March 17. An agreement on cereals was signed with Canada. Undertakings were given with respect to m in i­ mum import prices for certain cereals and related matters. March 17. The import levy arrangements were announced that would be introduced in July for cereals, 443 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM beef and veal, mutton and lamb, and dairy products other than butter and cheese. March 17. The butter import quota for the year end­ ing M a r ch 31, 1972 was announced as 420,000 tons, 5,000 tons lower than that for the previous year. The cheese quota was announced as 135,575 tons compared with 132,750 tons in the previous year. March 30. Guidelines on lending by banks and finance houses were maintained. The London and Scot­ tish clearing banks were asked that their sterling lending to the domestic private sector and to overseas borrowers (other than fixed-rate lending under the special schemes for export and shipbuilding finance) should not rise in the aggregate during the quarter to mid-June 1971 to more than about 7% per cent above its level at m id- M a r ch 1970 (after allowance for seasonal influences). March 31. Controls over direct investment outside the Sterling A r ea were eased. The l im it on permitted remittances in official exchange for direct investment outside the Sterling A r ea in "super-criterion projects" was raised from £ 5 0 , 0 00 or 50 per cent of the total investment, whichever was larger, to £ 2 5 0 , 0 00 or 50 per cent of the total investment, whichever was larger. D irect investments outside the Sterling A r ea other than for "super-criterion projects" henceforth would be con­ sidered on the basis that their capital cost should not fa ll directly upon the official foreign exchange reserves at least un t il an equivalent amount had been received in the United K ingdom by way of benefits arising from the investments. The distinction between "cr i ter ion" and "noncriterion" projects was abolished and the three-year pay-back requirement for the former and the five-year restriction on the use of official exchange for both lapsed. A ll projects formerly falling within these two categories could henceforth be financed by the use of investment currency, with foreign currency borrowing (with repayment on a self-liquidating basis), or by exports free of payment. The level of remittances from nonresident companies controlled by U. K. residents would henceforth be considered on a global basis. Pre­ vious exchange control practice, when reviewing the level of profit remittances by companies outside the Sterling A r ea controlled by U. K. residents, was to deal with these subsidiaries on a country-by-country basis, allowing the permitted proportion of retained earnings (normally one third of net earnings after taxes) to be used for reinvestment only in the country in which the earnings arose. The permitted proportion of retained earnings on the new basis remained at the same level, but approval would normally be given for these earnings to be utilized for approved reinvestment in any non-Sterling A r ea country, irrespective of the country in which they originially arose. W i th respect to foreign currency borrowing, the requirement that repayments within five years be made with investment currency or from the proceeds of fur­ ther borrowing was relaxed as follows: Permission would be given for such borrowing to be repaid at any 444 time with official exchange to the extent that foreign currency earnings had been received from the invest­ ment; for super-criterion investments such repayments would be authorized only from earnings in excess of those needed to recoup any remittance of official exchange or to the extent that the fu ll entitlement to official exchange was not taken up in i t ia l ly. March 31. The voluntary program of restraint on overseas investment was continued without change. April 1. The Exchange Con trol (G o ld Coins Exemp­ tion) Order 1971 exempted a ll gold coins, irrespective of their date of minting, from the provisions of Sec­ tions 1, 2, and 3 of the Exchange Con t rol A ct 1947. Consequently, a ll gold coins could be bought and sold, borrowed and lent, and held without exchange control permission. Exports of gold coins remained controlled under Section 22 of the A c t. At the same time, the pro­ hibition on the use of gold for the manufacture of medals, etc., was removed. A ll gold coins, irrespective of date, and medals, etc., were again on Open General Import License (except for Rhodes ia). April 26. It was announced that a scheme was under preparation to insure overseas investment against such noncommercial risks as war, expropriation, and restric­ tions on remittances. April 29. Open individual licenses were granted in supplement of the annual quota system for butter. Con­ trols on butter imports thus were in effect suspended un t il June 30, then subsequently to September 30, 1971 and to M a r ch 31, 1972. In June it was announced that ind iv idual import licenses for ghee, near-butters, and butter oils would be issued freely. May 10. A supplementary quota of 5,000 tons for bananas of Do l lar A r ea origin was established; on September 9, a further supplementary quota of 5,000 tons was established. May 28. As a measure of formal liberalization of the regulations introduced on January 12, authorized banks were permitted, without reference to the Bank of England, to make foreign currency loans to resident exporters, merchants, and participants in commodity schemes for specified trade purposes; no minimum repay­ ment period was required. The measure confirmed existing approval practices. June 29. Insurers in the Un i ted K ingdom were per­ mitted to export insurance policies to nonresidents of the Sterling A rea without formality. Previously, Bank of England approval was required. June 30. It was announced that the tariff on cotton textiles from the Commonwealth Preference A r ea that would replace existing quantitative restrictions on Janu­ ary 1, 1972 would, with minor exceptions, be 85 per cent of the current most-favored-nation rates. July 1. Variable import levies were imposed on mutton and lamb from a ll countries except the Irish Republic. Both minimum import prices and variable levies were introduced for beef and veal and dairy ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution products other than butter and cheese; the Irish Republic was exempt from the variable levies on beef. July 7. The Treasury would no longer insure the exchange risk for foreign currency borrowing by nationalized industries and local authorities for loans of less than ten years. (In M a r ch 1972 the exchange rate guarantee was discontinued entirely.) July 12. A time schedule was agreed with the mem­ ber countries of the E EC for the progressive dismantling of the controls over portfolio and direct investment in E EC countries as well as personal capital transfers to the Commun i ty. July 16. Certain delegated authorities to authorized banks to approve specified current payments ("sundry payments") outside the Sterling A r ea were increased. Applications to pay professional fees and charges relating to direct investments outside the Sterling A r ea no longer had to be referred to the Bank of Eng land. July 19. A new open general import license was granted. Controls on imports from mainland Ch ina were liberalized, mainly by transferring a wide range of items from open general ind iv idual license to open general license; for goods subject to special controls according to origin, mainland Ch ina was enabled to share in import quotas for the Eastern A r e a. July 26. It was announced that generalized tariff preferences for manufactured goods and certain pro­ cessed agricultural products originating in 99 developing countries would be introduced on January 1, 1972. August 13. The Federal Reserve Bank of New Y o rk was asked to activate the reciprocal swap facility in order to provide the Exchange Equalisation Account with forward cover. August 16. The gold market was closed. It reopened on August 17. August 16. The foreign exchange market was closed. The Bank of England subsequently allowed authorized banks, however, to lend foreign currency to residents for payments due to nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea in circumstances where remittances could have been approved under existing authorities ( in such cases, the January 12 measures, i.e., the five-year term require­ ment, would not app ly ). Nonresidents were also allowed to incur temporary overdrafts on their External Accounts to meet any obligations to residents of the Sterling A r e a. August 23. The. foreign exchange market reopened. Wh i le the existing par value of the pound was main­ tained, the official buying rate for the U. S. dollar was suspended. As a result, the pound began to appreciate in terms of the U. S. dollar, the effective parity relation­ ship for which had been £ 1 = US$2 .40. The Bank of England continued to publish daily dealing limits. August 31. F inanc ial institutions (including building societies, trustee savings banks, and similar bodies) and local authorities were prohibited from accepting sterling deposits or sterling loans from nonresidents of the Sterling A r e a. U N I T ED K I N G D OM August 31. Nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea were prohibited from purchasing or subscribing to specified types of sterling securities (sterling certificates of deposit, treasury bills, and government, government-guaranteed, and local authority securities) having fixed maturity dates earlier than October 1, 1976; switching of existing holdings, however, was permitted. August 31. Authorized banks were not permitted to convert foreign currency into sterling on a swap basis for lending to residents to the extent that such conver­ sion would result in their net spot position in foreign currency becoming a short position covered by net forward purchases of foreign currency. Banks which had already carried out such swaps were required to restore their foreign currency positions as the swaps matured. Previously, inward switching had not been restricted. The restriction was lifted on December 20. August 31. Au thor ized banks, discount houses, and other bodies operating sterling accounts for nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea could not, for the time being, pay interest on any increase in the balance on such an account after the opening of business on August 31, 1971 except to the extent that the increase was attribut­ able to accrued interest. September 2. Consistent with the August 31 measures to discourage speculative inflows from overseas, the bank rate was reduced from 6 per cent to 5 per cent. September 14. The restrictions on payment of interest on external accounts introduced on August 31 were relaxed for personal accounts of individuals where balances did not exceed <£ 20,000 or the balance held at the opening of business on August 31, whichever was the greater. App l ica t ions for exemption from the restriction would be considered for certain international bodies and for accounts (not in the nature of imprest accounts) of other international bodies and of foreign governments and their representatives. September 14. Bu i ld ing societies and trustee and other savings banks were exempted from the August 31 restrictions on the acceptance of sterling deposits and loans from nonresidents of the Sterling A r e a. Other financial institutions (such as hire-purchase finance houses) and local authorities were permitted to open new accounts for private individuals resident outside the Sterling A r ea and to accept further deposits from such persons provided, in each case, that the balance in an account did not exceed £ 2 0 , 0 0 0. September 16. New arrangements for the control of credit came into effect. The existing quantitative ceilings on sterling lending by banks and finance houses were removed. September 20. Controls on imports of cheddar and cheddar-type cheese were suspended until M a r ch 31, 1972. September 21. The Basle arrangements were renewed. It was announced that 33 of 35 members of the Sterling A r ea who had in 1968 concluded three-year agreements with the Un i ted K ingdom on maintenance of sterling 445 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED K I N G D OM balances had agreed to extend these agreements to September 24, 1973. (Twenty-nine other members had originally entered into five-year agreements terminating on that date.) The extensions involved an understanding for a uniform reduction in the proportion of sterling which both three- and five-year agreement countries undertook to hold in exchange for a dollar value guarantee on the bulk of those holdings. The change was expected to contribute toward a leveling out in the growth of official sterling balances, consonant with the Un i ted Kingdom's undertaking to the countries of the E EC to "manage its policies with a view to j stabilizing the official sterling balances." September 23. Authorized banks' limits on holdings of spot balances against forward commitments in foreign currency were doubled. The limits on open positions in foreign currency were maintained. The measure was revoked on December 20. October 1. M i n im um import prices were established for imports of poultry meat from a ll sources other than Denmark and Ireland. Cheaper qualities became subject in addition to variable levies. October 7. A ll transfers from and credits to External Accounts were made subject to general or special exchange control permissions given by the Bank of England rather than being permitted under a payments order issued by the Treasury. October 7, The August 31 ban on the acquisition of specified types of sterling securities by nonresidents of the Sterling A r ea was extended to cover such securities of a ll maturities. Switching from existing holdings remained permitted, but pending reinvestment the pro­ ceeds had to be held in a suspense account bearing no interest. Moreover, nonresidents of the Sterling A rea could no longer purchase sterling acceptances or com­ mercial bills or promissory notes denominated in sterling (other than notes which were or had been legal tender in the Sterling Area); the proceeds on sale or maturity of such instruments could not be reinvested in similar instruments or in the precluded securities. October 12. Futures quotations in sterling on the London Cotton Term inal Market were suspended indefinitely. October 25. New customs procedures for exports came into effect. These were intended to give a more accurate record and eliminate the statistical problem of underrecording of exports. November 1. The cost of medium-term and long-term finance for exports (other than for ships) was reduced from 7 per cent to 6V> per cent when supported by 446 an unconditional bank guarantee provided by the E C G D. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that they are pro­ hibited to and from Cuba, No r th Ko rea, N o r th V ie t- N am, and Rhodesia. Capital Incoming or outgoing capital payments by residents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on certain transactions with or involving Cuba, N o r th Ko rea, N o r th V i e t -N am, and Rhodesia. U. S. citizens or residents, when purchasing foreign stocks and debt obligations (including shares in off­ shore mutual funds) from foreigners, are subject to an Interest Equalization Tax equivalent to a borrowing charge of % of 1 per cent a year (the rate of tax being 11.25 per cent for certain acquisitions of stock and 0.79 per cent to 11.25 per cent, depending on maturity, for certain acquisitions of debt obligations, including bank loans, w i th a period remaining to maturity of one year or mo re ). Ma jor exemptions from the tax are direct investments, investments in less developed coun­ tries,2 purchases from other U. S. holders, debt obliga­ tions acquired in connection with exports, and the purchase of original or new issues when the President of the Un i ted States determines that the application of the tax w i ll have such consequences for a foreign country as to impe r il or threaten to imperil the stability of the international monetary system, pursuant to which new or original Canadian obligations are exempt, as are bank loans, whether denominated in U. S. dollars or foreign currencies and regardless of maturity, that are made by foreign branches of U. S. banks to foreign borrowers. A voluntary foreign credit restraint program has resulted in the establishment of "guidelines" for banks and nonbank financial institutions in respect of their foreign assets. A mandatory foreign direct investment program has placed restraints on direct investment by setting annual limits on net capital outflow plus reinvested earnings, prescribing that the total amount of investment each year be limited to a percentage of the amount invested in the base pe r iod ,3 and l im i t ing the amount of short-term financial assets held abroad by direct investors. A direct investor is defined as a person within the Un i ted States who directly or indirectly owns or acquires 10 per cent or more of the voting power, right to receive income, or right to receive assets on liquidation of a foreign national. Three regional ceilings are enforced on the making of direct investment during any year by direct investors which do not elect the m in imum world-wide allowable of US$2 m i l l i o n: one for less developed coun t r ies ;4 one for other countries judged to be dependent on a substantial continuing inflow of capital that cannot be adequately met from non -U. S. sou rces ;5 and one for a ll other countries.6 There is in principle an embargo on net capital out­ flows to this group of countries as a whole, including most of continental Western Europe, but direct investors are virtually free to finance new or additional direct investments in Schedule C countries with long-term funds and rolled-over short-term funds borrowed in any foreign country. Funds raised abroad may be used to finance direct investments without a current charge against a company's ceilings. Canada is exempt from a ll balance of payments restraints, except for the application of the Interest Equa l iza t ion Tax to some transactions. Gold Residents may import, purchase, ho ld, and sell for numismatic purposes domestic and foreign gold coins minted before 1934. G o ld coins minted after this date may be held if they have been determined to be of recognized special value to collectors. Licenses are required to import any gold coins minted in or after 1934, and generally are available only for gold coins of exceptional numismatic value. Import licenses are not normally issued for coins minted in 1960 or after. The import of counterfeit coins and restrikes is prohibited. G o ld bu l l ion may not be held in the Un i ted States except by monetary authorities and licensed industrial, professional, and artistic users. The purchase or holding of gold abroad by U. S. citizens and firms is also pro- 2 Among other countries the tax is applicable to Abu Dhabi, Bahama Islands, Bahrain, Bermuda, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait-Saudi Arabia Neutral Zone, Libyan Arab Republic, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia. The only European countries at present designated as less developed countries are Cyprus, Finland, Greece, Iceland, Malta, Turkey, and Yugoslavia. 3 Where the regulations require a company to repatriate more income than is allowed by host country laws or by business circumstances, such as certain joint ownership situations, unconditional specific relief may be granted by the Office of Foreign Direct Investments. 4 As defined for the purposes of the Interest Equalization Tax (see footnote 2). They are referred to as Schedule A countries. 5 Abu Dhabi, Australia, Bahama Islands, Bahrain, Bermuda, Canada, Hong Kong, Iran, Iraq, Ireland, Japan, Kuwait, Kuwait-Saudi Arabia Neutral Zone, Libyan Arab Republic, New Zealand, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Spain, and United Kingdom.
