Producers of gold may sell their output at free market prices either to licensed industrial users or abroad (except to monetary authorities). G o ld may be freely imported by licensed users within the limitations of their authorized inventory holding. A license is required for the export of gold except gold recovered from natural deposits in the Un i ted States, which may be exported without license. Commerc ial imports of gold jewelry are free of quantitative restric­ tion. Imports and exports of gold coins and gold bu l­ l ion are free of customs duties and other fiscal charges. Domestic sales of jewelry, inc lud ing gold jewelry, are subject to excise duty at the rate of 15 per cent, while domestic sales of gold in any other form, including rare gold coins, are free of fiscal charges. The use of the international reserve assets of the Un i ted States has been limited to settlement of out­ standing obligations and, in cooperation with the Inter­ national Monetary Fund, to other situations that might arise in which such use could contribute to international monetary stability and the interests of the Un i ted States. January Changes during 1971 1. A Presidential Order imposed annual import quotas on four dairy products. January 1. The ban on transshipments of Aus tra l ian, New Zealand, and Irish beef from Canada to the Un i ted States was continued. January 1. The following changes in the direct invest­ ment controls came into effect. The allowable quota for new net direct investment abroad, exempt from control, was doubled to US$2 m i l l ion. The amount of cumula­ tive direct investment that must be exceeded before quarterly reporting is required in any year also was increased from US$1 m i l l ion to US$2 m i l l ion. January 5. The guidelines under the voluntary foreign credit restraint ( V F C R) program were revised with immediate effect. No change was made in the overall guideline ceilings already in effect, but certain technical changes were made which were designed to equalize treatment under the guidelines between banks and other financial institutions and to give banks greater flexibility in using their existing leeway under the general ceiling for export financing. Bonds and notes of international institutions of which the Un i ted States is a member were excluded from the guidelines. Export credits were exempted from a subceiling that limited short-term credits to residents of developed countries of continen­ tal Western Europe, although banks would still be required to report these credits under their general ceiling. January 7. The Treasury and Commerce Departments and the Federal Reserve System announced their inten­ tion to continue in 1971 the three existing programs to restrain capital outflows. The Treasury wou ld request U N I T ED S T A T ES the Congress to extend authority for the Interest Equa l i­ zation Tax, wh ich was to expire on M a r ch 31, 1971. There would be some technical changes in the direct investment program and the V F CR program, but these were designed merely to facilitate administration and compliance consistent with the need to continue restraint for the period ahead. January 7. In accordance with its decision of Novem­ ber 30, 1970, the Federal Reserve Board ( F R B) amended the Supplement to Regulation D and amen­ ded Regulation M for the purpose of strengthening the inducement for U. S. banks to retain their Euro-dollar liabilities and thus moderate the pace of repayment of Euro-dollar borrowings. The Board raised from 10 per cent to 20 per cent the reserves required to be maintained by member banks against Euro-dollar borrowings that exceeded the amounts that the banks were allowed as a reserve-free base. (The higher requirement became effective in the four-week reserve computation period ended December 23, 1970.) The marginal reserve requirement was made applicable to borrowings above either (1) the minimum base equal to a percentage of deposits, or (2) the average level in the reserve computa­ tion period ended November 25, 1970, whichever was higher. The Board also amended its regulations to dis­ courage repayment of Euro-dollar liabilities not only by banks that used a historically determined reserve-free base originally related to their M ay 1969 borrowings, but also by those banks that operated under a m in imum base equal to 3 per cent of their overall deposits sub­ ject to reserve requirements. The amendment applied the automatic downward adjustment to reserve-free bases of the latter k ind as well as of the former. (This amendment became effective w i th the computation period ending January 20, 1971.) January 7. The Cap i tal Projects guidelines of the Agency for International Development ( A I D) were liberalized in implementation of the policy of "untying" of procurement source restrictions for loan-financed commodities and services. January 15. Special Export-Import Bank and U. S. Treasury securities began to be issued which were designed to provide an investment outlet for Eu ro­ dollar funds held by foreign branches of U. S. banks, thus reducing incentives to return funds to the Eu ro­ dollar banks. The Export-Import Bank sold US$1 .5 b i l­ l ion of three-month securities in January and February, and in A p r il the Treasury issued US$1 .5 b i l l ion of short-term certificates of indebtedness. These two kinds of special issues reached a high of US$3 .2 b i l l ion in mid-August, when they were allowed to run off, and were completely retired by October. (The Export- Import Bank notes were replaced by Treasury securi­ ties around mid-year.) January 15. The Export-Import Bank announced that it would offer US$1 b i l l ion of three-month notes at 6 per cent to the foreign branches of U. S. banks. On February 23, the Bank announced an additional three- 449 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED S T A T ES April month borrowing of US$0 .5 b i l l ion. The Bank refinanced the original issue upon its maturity in A p r i l. January 15. The F RB amended Regulation M to per­ mit U. S. banks to count toward maintenance of their reserve-free Euro-dollar bases any funds invested by their overseas branches in Export-Import Bank securities offered<under the program announced by the Bank on that date. January 15. The F RB postponed for four weeks, for those banks that had a m in imum (3 per cent of deposits) reserve-free base, the application of the auto­ matic downward adjustment of their bases. January 19. Restrictions were relaxed on exports of about 100 items to Eastern Europe and the U. S. S. R. January 28. Licenses ceased to be required for exports of copper to countries other than Cuba, Rhodesia, and communist countries in A s i a. March 11. The Export-Import Bank signed a guaran­ tee and credit agreement with the Private Export Fund­ ing Corporation, a newly established private corporation aimed at tapping longer-term financing than had been available for private banks. March 13. Pursuant to Presidential Proclamations, the limit on meat imports for 1971 was established at 1,160 m i l l ion pounds. 1. To help avert an additional increase in foreign central banks' dollar holdings, the Treasury announced plans to offer US$1.5 b i l l ion in three-month certificates of indebtedness to foreign branches of U. S. banks. April 1. The F RB amended Regulation M to permit U. S. banks to count toward maintenance of their reserve-free Euro-dollar bases any funds invested by their overseas branches in U. S. Treasury securities offered under the program announced on A p r il 1 by the Treasury. April 2. It was announced that, in view of technical difficulties, it was not proposed to end the exemption of short-term bank transactions from the Interest Equ a l i­ zation Tax. Legislation extending the tax through M a r ch 31, 1973 became effective. 14. The President announced that financial, commercial, and shipping controls with respect to main­ land Ch ina would be relaxed. April 16. Export controls were lifted on walnut logs, bolts, lumber and veneers, and certain semifabricated forms of copper. May 7. The Secretary of the Treasury announced the issuance of a general license removing with immediate effect a ll controls on the use of dollars or dollar instru­ ments in transactions with mainland Ch ina and its nationals. The Treasury's Foreign Assets Con t rol Regu­ lations were amended to remove the prohibition against U. S.-controlled foreign flag vessels calling at mainland China's ports. The new general license replaced the specific licensing procedure in effect since December 1950. The amendments did not pertain to those accounts in the United States which had been blocked under the April 4 50 Foreign Assets Con t rol Regulations; these accounts would remain blocked. U. S. banks could henceforth act as intermediaries in normal financial transactions between the Un i ted States and mainland C h i na and its nationals, including remittances for family support and for humanitarian and other purposes. May 7. The Departments of Commerce and Trans­ portation announced certain relaxation measures in respect of shipping, bunkering, and servicing when related to mainland Ch ina. June 3. Licensing was approved for export to the U. S. S. R. of US$50 m i l l ion of equipment, chiefly for the manufacture of light trucks. June 11. The Treasury issued a general license remov­ ing the existing restrictions on imports from mainland Ch in a. June 11. A detailed list came into effect of com­ modities that could henceforth be exported to mainland Ch ina under general license. June 11. Sales of wheat, wheat flour, and other grains to mainland Ch ina, Eastern Europe, and the U. S. S. R. no longer required the prior approval of the Department of Commerce. The requirement that 50 per cent of U. S. exports of wheat, flour, and other grains to mainland Ch in a, Eastern Europe, and the U. S. S. R. be carried in U. S. vessels was also lifted. July 22. The Treasury amended its G o ld Regulations, with immediate effect, to reaffirm and clarify the long­ standing policy that speculation in gold in any form was prohibited. The amendments explicitly prohibited the trading of gold in any form on commodity exchanges and the acquisition of U. S. or foreign gold coins of any description for speculative purposes. August 10. It was announced that credit would hence­ forth be denied to any foreign country that nationalized U. S. private property without giving an immediate commitment on acceptable terms of compensation. August 15. The President issued a Proclamation declaring a national emergency, suspending temporarily the convertibility of the U. S. dollar into gold and other reserve assets, and imposing with effect from August 16 a temporary import surcharge. August 15. The Secretary of the Treasury notified the International Monetary Fund that, effective as of that date, the Un i ted States would no longer freely buy and sell gold for the settlement of international trans­ actions under the second sentence of A r t i c le I V, Section 4(b), of the Fund's Ar t ic les of Agreement. Previously, the Treasury had sold gold at US$35 a fine ounce to governments and central banks abroad, and, under certain circumstances, to international institutions, for the settlement of international balances and other legiti­ mate monetary purposes. (Subsequently, the U. S. authorities did not intervene in the exchange market to influence the exchange rate of the U. S. dollar and the currency began to depreciate in terms of certain foreign currencies.) August 15. It was announced that the Secretary of the ©International Monetary Fund. S. inter­ national reserve assets to the settlement of outstanding obligations and, in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund, to other situations that might arise in which such use could contribute to international mone­ tary stability and the interests of the Un i ted States. August 15. The Secretary of the Treasury requested the Federal Reserve System to suspend the virtually automatic use of its swap network for the purpose of converting dollars into other currencies; the future operation of these and other mutual credit facilities with foreign countries would be determined in the light of emerging developments. August 15. It was announced that the official U. S. dollar price of gold had not been altered by the suspen­ sion of convertibility, and that the President had directed that that price be maintained. Moreover, the functioning of the two-tier gold system decided upon in M a r ch 1968 should not be affected, nor was it intended to be. No new decision had been made with respect to the several restraints on capital outflows abroad. The restraints remained in effect, and their future disposition would be under review. August 15. The President proposed a Job Develop­ ment T ax Credit applicable to purchases of new pro­ ducers' durable equipment. Subsequent statements of po l icy confined the proposed tax credit to domestically produced new machinery and equipment as long as the import surcharge remained in effect. August 16. A temporary import surcharge of generally 10 per cent ad valorem was imposed on dutiable imports, irrespective of or ig in. The tax applied only to goods on which duties had been reduced from the 1930 level under reciprocal trade agreements, and in no case did it raise a duty beyond the statutory ceiling prescribed in column 2 (the 1930 tariff) of the U. S. tariff schedules; where a statutory ceiling existed, the surcharge was less than 10 per cent (for auto­ mobiles, for example, it was 6.5 per cen t). A ll imports subject to mandatory quantitative restrictions imposed under statute were exempt from the surcharge; these included petroleum, sugar, meat, dairy products, certain other agricultural products, and cotton textiles covered by the Long-Term Cotton Textiles Agreement. The sur­ charge affected about one half of U. S. imports by value. August 17. The Export Expansion Finance A ct of 1971, Pub l ic Law 92-126, was enacted. Am o ng other things, it directed the removal of export credits from the V F CR program. (On August 18 the F RB requested banks and other financial institutions to continue to comply with the existing program for the time being.) It also had the effect of authorizing the President to extend Export-Import Bank credits to further exports to communist countries when he found this to be in the national interest. (In his first use of this authority, the President on December 1 directed the Bank to partici­ pate in financing exports to Rumania.) Receipts and U N I T ED S T A T ES disbursements of the Export-Import Bank were removed from Federal unified budget totals. August 23. The Secretary of the Treasury issued Add i t ional Du ty Order N o. 2, which exempted from the temporary import surcharge a number of items, including beef, veal, and mutton; certain dairy prod­ ucts, wheat, peanuts, and cotton; crude o i l, unfinished oils, finished o il products, and certain petrochemicals; cotton textiles subject to quantitative restraints under the long-term international cotton textile agreement; and sugar. September 7. It was announced that, whenever applicable on goods of Philippine origin, the temporary surcharge would be assessed only up to a maximum of 8 per cent, under the terms of the U. S.-Philippine trade agreement. September 7. The Treasury announced that it was not renewing a maturing tranche of special certificates placed with foreign branches of U. S. banks. By October 26 a ll of the US$3 b i l l ion of special certificates issued between January 25, 1971 and A p r il 7, 1971 had been retired. October 15. Fo l low ing the negotiation of self- limitation agreements w i th certain major suppliers (including Japan), imports of man-made and woolen textiles from a ll sources were exempted from the tem­ porary surcharge, with retroactive effect from October 1. October 19. The F RB extended the deadline for the application by banks of the reporting and record­ keeping rules provided for by Titles I and II of the Foreign Bank Secrecy A ct ( PL 91-508, enacted on October 26, 1970). (With effect from M ay 1, 1972, financial institutions were required to report to the Government a ll transactions of more than US$5,000 in domestic or foreign currency, and any individual entering or leaving the United States with more than US$5,000 in cash or in bearer instruments, or trans­ porting such instruments by ma i l, messenger, or com­ mon carrier, was required to file a report with customs officials.) November 1. A new F RB regulation, Regulation X, came into force. It implemented Title III of the Foreign Bank Secrecy A ct ( PL 91-508). The Regulation required persons borrowing in the United States to comply with the margin regulations applicable to the lender extending him credit on securities, and required U. S. persons borrowing abroad (w i th certain excep­ tions) to comply with the provisions of the margin regulation that would apply if the credit were obtained in the Un i ted States. Foreign subsidiaries of U. S. cor­ porations making markets in Euro-bonds were exempt. October 14. The President signed into law amend­ ments to the U. S. Sugar A ct of 1948. These included provisions for an annual quota, beginning in 1972, for imports of certain sweetened chocolate, candy, and confectionery products. November 5. The President signed a Proclamation extending indefinitely the importation of N o. 2 fuel o il 451 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U N I T ED S T A T ES into the Northeast and increasing the quota by 5,000 barrels a day to 45,000 barrels. The proclamation also provided for increased flexibility in administration; the Secretary of the Interior would be empowered to waive source limitations in the light of price or supply con­ ditions, and to permit the diversion of fuel o il quotas for increased imports of crude o il if appropriate. November 11. The guidelines under the V F CR were revised, chiefly to bring them into conformity with recent legislation. Export credits to foreigners by banks and nonbank financial institutions were excluded from the ceilings. Export credits were defined as credits that financed either the shipment of goods produced in the Un i ted States or the performance abroad of services by U. S. nationals; they could be either direct credits financing exports or indirect credits to foreign financial institutions that in turn would utilize these funds to finance U. S. exports. A new formula was set for calculating ceilings. The ceiling for nonexport financing of each bank would be the highest of (a) 85 per cent of its general ceiling on September 30, 1971; (b) its general ceiling on Septem­ ber 30, 1971 minus any export credits subject to that ceiling as of that date; or (c) 2 per cent of its total assets as of December 31, 1970. The ceiling for non- export financing of each nonbank financial institution would be the higher of (a) its ceiling on September 30, 1971 minus export credits subject to that ceiling as of that date; or (b) 85 per cent of its ceiling on Septem­ ber 30, 1971. The export term-loan ceiling was discontinued. The subceiling on short-term claims on residents of developed countries of continental Western Europe was eliminated. Reporting requirements were imposed on U. S. agencies and branches of foreign banks. An exemption for nonbank financial institutions was narrowed in respect of long-term investments to finance o il tankers. November 11. As a result of the exemption of export credit extended to foreigners from restraint under the V F CR guidelines, the discounting of export credit obligations of affiliated foreign nationals on or after November 11 w i th banks or other financial institutions subject to the V F CR guidelines would not reduce direct investment for purposes of the foreign direct investment regulations. November 12. The Foreign Credit Insurance Associa­ tion was given wider authority to insure U. S. exports at its own discretion and without the prior approval of the Export-Import Bank. November 17. The President signed legislation wh ich would terminate as of January 1, 1972, the ban on the importation of strategic and cr i t ical materials from Rho­ desia, by removing the President's authority to ban such imports. December 1. The 1970 amendments to the Bank Ho ld ing Company A ct became effective. The regula­ tions, defining the types of business activities in wh ich 452 foreign bank holding companies might engage in the United States, had been announced by the F RB on November 12. December 9. The deadline for compliance w i th the 1971 ceilings under the foreign direct investment con­ trols was extended for 60 days beyond the end of 1971 because of international monetary uncertainties, and a year-end repatriation requirement for certain proceeds on long-term foreign borrowing that were held abroad was eliminated for the current year. December 10. W i th the signing into law of the Revenue A ct of 1971, the Job Development Investment Credit provisions became effective. Businesses were granted a tax credit equal to 7 per cent of the cost of new producers' durable equipment either ordered from domestic firms after M a r ch 31, 1971, or acquired after August 15, 1971, with minor exceptions. December 10. Under provisions of the Revenue A ct of 1971, U . S. exporters were able to enjoy tax treat­ ment partially comparable to that of U. S. producers located abroad. The law provided for a new type of cor­ poration to be known as a Domestic International Sales Corporation ( D I S C ). Taxes on 50 per cent of a DISC'S income cou ld be deferred indefinitely, provided that 95 per cent of the DISC'S receipts and assets related to qualified exports. Loans to a parent company to finance research and development expenditures, inventory accu­ mulation, or investment in plant and equipment could be counted as export-related assets, so long as the pro­ portion wh ich these loans bore to total expenditures for such purposes did not exceed the proportion of the bor­ rower's total sales accounted for by exports. Dividends to D I SC stockholders were to be fully taxed. The tax deferral on any D I SC profits which were lent to parent companies wou ld be terminated if such profits were judged to have been invested in foreign plant and equipment. December 18. Agreement was reached w i th in the G roup of Ten on a realignment of exchange rates. The Un i ted States agreed, subject to Congressional approval, to raise the dollar price of gold by 8.57 per cent, from US$35 to US$38 a fine ounce, as soon as a related set of short-term trade expansion measures (to be developed through negotiations with Canada, Japan, and the E EC countries) was available for Congressional scrutiny. The Un i ted States also agreed to lift the import sur­ charge with immediate effect. December 20. The temporary import surcharge was eliminated. At the same time pursuant to the Revenue A ct of 1971, and as a result of the removal of the import surcharge, property produced abroad or pre­ dominantly of foreign origin henceforth qualified for the Job Development Investment Credit if acquired on or after December 20, 1971, provided the property was not ordered during the surcharge period (August 16 through December 19, 1971). The Treasury announced that the final stage of the Kennedy Round tariff reductions would become effective as scheduled on January 1, 1972. U N I T ED S T A T ES 453 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER V O L TA Exchange System No par value for the currency of Upper V o l ta has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the C FA F r a n c ,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of C F AF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange trans­ actions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de l 'A f r ique de l'Ouest ( B C E A O) and commercial banks take place at the rate of C F AF 1 = F 0.02, free of commission charges. Exchange transactions relating to foreign countries, i. e., countries other than France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries of the French Franc A r e a, take place in a dual exchange market at rates based on the fixed rate for the F rench franc and the Paris exchange rate for the foreign currency concerned in either the official exchange market or the financial franc market. Settlements eligible for the official exchange market are payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, and incidental expenses on imports and exports (freight, insurance, etc .), as well as current payments by or in favor of domestic and foreign public authorities and public bodies. A ll other settlements with foreign countries, as well as transactions in banknotes of foreign countries and banknotes issued by the B C E A O, take place through the financial franc market at freely fluctuating rates. Exchange rates in the official market are based on par values and central rates; the effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar in this market is C F AF 255.785 = U S $ 1. W i th the exception of those relating to gold, Upper Volta's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France and its Overseas Departments and Territories (except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) a ll other countries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the French Treasury by an Opera­ tions Account (Cameroon, the Central A f r ican Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, the Malagasy Republic, M a l i, Maur i tan ia, N iger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Vo l ta ). Hence, a ll payments to these countries may be made freely. A ll other countries, except Upper Vo l ta itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle finan­ c ial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Pub l ic Accounts in the M in is t ry of Finance and C om­ merce, wh ich also supervises borrowing abroad, the I1 The C FA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de l'Afrique de l'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 454 issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper V o l t a, inward direct investment and a ll outward investment, and the soliciting of funds in Upper V o l ta for placement in foreign countries. The approval authority in respect of exchange control, except for imports and exports of gold and business travel allocations in excess of C F AF 400,000, has been delegated to the B C E AO and, within limits specified in the exchange control regulations, to authorized inter­ mediaries. The B C E AO also is authorized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of the banks and the Postal Adm in is tra t ion, any information neces­ sary to compile the balance of payments statistics. A ll exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks, the Postal Administration, or the B C E A O. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Commerce at the M in is t ry of Finance and Commerce. Import certifi­ cates for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself and are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Upper V o l ta is an Operations Account country of the French Franc A r e a, since the B C E AO maintains an Operations Account with the F rench Treasury; settle­ ments with France (including its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the F rench Terr i tory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, and the other Opera­ tions Account countries of the French Franc A r ea are made in C FA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Cer ta in settle­ ments w i th Ghana are made through special accounts. Settlements w i th a ll other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in F rench francs through Fore ign or F inanc ial Accounts in Francs. A ll settlements w i th Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. B C E AO bank­ notes may be credited to F inanc ial Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the B C E AO agency in Ouagadougou by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of B C E AO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Imports from countries in the French Franc A r ea may be made freely. Imports from E EC countries are liberalized and require only an import ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution certificate. Most imports from other countries are sub­ ject to licensing. Imports from n o n -EEC countries out­ side the French Franc A r ea are admitted in accordance with an annual import program, determined each year by the Directorate of Commerce. Under this program, global quotas are established up to which import licen­ ses are issued for specified commodities to licensed traders. Imports from Ghana are subject to special reg­ ulations. F or goods admitted without quantitative restriction, certificates of importation are issued. A ll import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds C F AF 500,000. The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodi­ ties have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French F ranc A r ea are permitted freely; those to other coun­ tries are subject to exchange control approval, wh ich for many invisibles has been delegated to the author­ ized banks. A ll payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted. Res­ idents traveling for tourism to countries other than France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc A r ea may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to C F AF 175,000 a person a trip ( C F AF 87,500 for ch i l­ dren under ten ); any foreign exchange in excess of C F AF 5,000 remaining after return to Upper V o l ta must be surrendered. Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a maxi­ mum of C F AF 25,000 in B C E AO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by any institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the F rench Treasury. Travelers to other countries may take out any amount in B C E AO banknotes, but if their des­ tination is not to a member country of the West A f r i c an Monetary U n i o n, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds C F AF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out, in addi­ tion to any means of payment established in their name abroad, foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of C F AF 25,000 or (if it was either declared upon entry or acquired by drawing on a F inanc ial Account in Francs or an Account in Fore ign Currency or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, etc .), any larger amount. They may also take out any foreign means of payment other than banknotes acquired in Upper V o l ta U P P ER V O L TA by debit to a F inanc ial Account in Francs or an Account in Fore ign Currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the French Franc A r ea may be made freely but for statistical purposes require a license from the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Exports to a ll other countries are permitted freely but some also require a license. Certain commodities can be exported in special circumstances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regulations. Export pro­ ceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be surren­ dered. A ll export transactions relating to foreign coun­ tries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds C F AF 50,000, and the exporter must sign a foreign exchange commitment (engagement de change) and submit a customs certification (attesta­ tion dJ exportation). Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles w i th France, Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc A r ea may be retained. A ll amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and a ll income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date. Such proceeds and earn­ ings must not be received in or from Rhodesia. Resi­ dent and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the B C E A O, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc A r e a. Resident travelers must within eight days surrender to an authorized bank any foreign means of payment in excess of C F AF 5,000 that they bring i n. Capital A ll capital movements between Upper Vo l ta and Rhodesia are prohibited. Cap i tal movements between Upper V o l ta and France, Monaco, and other Opera­ tions Account countries in the French Franc A rea are free of exchange control; capital transfers to a ll other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper V o l t a; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. W i th the exception of those over foreign securities in Upper 4 55 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution U P P ER V O L TA Vo l ta, the control measures do not apply to relations with France and its Overseas Departments and Territo­ ries (except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, the other member countries of the West A f r ican Monetary Un ion, and those other coun­ tries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Accoun t. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign p r i­ vate persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. A ll investments abroad by residents of Upper V o l ta require prior authorization by the Minister of F inance .2 Foreign direct investments in Upper V o l t a3 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to h im. The total or partial liquidation of either type of investment also is subject to prior declaration to the M in is ter. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Upper V o l ta investments abroad or foreign investments in Upper Vo l ta, must be reported to the M in is ter of Finance within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere par­ ticipation is not considered as direct investment, pro­ vided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Vo l ta requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Upper V o l ta Govern­ ment and (2) shares similar to securities whose issue, offering for sale, or sale in Upper Vo l ta has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires p r ior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authoriza­ t ion: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports from Upper Vo l ta, or by international trading houses to finance international merchanting transac­ tions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total 2 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign compa­ nies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Upper Volta and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of compa­ nies in Upper Volta. P Including those made by companies in Upper Volta that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Upper Volta of foreign companies. 456 amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed C F AF 100 m i l l ion for any one borrower, and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Minister if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization by the B C E A O, acting on behalf of the M in is ter of Finance. The lending of C FA francs to nonresidents for periods of up to two years, however, is freely permitted. Ordinance N o. 7 0 - 0 7 4 / P R E S / P L - TP of December 31, 1970, the Investment Code, provides preferential treat­ ment for foreign investment in Upper Vo l t a. Two pref­ erential categories (A and B) are established, in accord­ ance with which preferential treatment with respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Category B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negoti­ ated between the investor and the Government, and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of exceptional importance to the development of the country. Law N o. 2 5 / 6 1 / AN set up an assistance fund for new industries. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Upper V o l t a. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the External Finance Bureau in the M in is t ry of Finance and Commerce, which is seldom granted. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the B C E A O; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold objects up to a combined weight of 500 grams. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY* Exchange Rate System On October 7, 1960, a par value for the Uruguayan Peso was established by Uruguay with the F u n d. H ow­ ever, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. Certain exchange trans­ actions take place in an official exchange market conducted by the monetary authorities.1 The Central Bank sets official buying and selling rates in this market. Other exchange transactions take place in an interbank free market. In practice, the exchange rates in the two markets are virtually identical; the Central Bank sup­ plies foreign exchange to the commercial banks for current transactions, and the proceeds from traditional exports must be surrendered to the monetary authori­ ties while those from nontraditional exports must be sold to authorized banks. The commercial banks are not permitted to exceed specified overbought positions and must surrender any excess exchange holdings to the Central Bank. On December 31, 1971, the official buying and selling rates were Ur$248 and U r$250 per US $ 1, respectively. Most exchange transactions take place at different effective exchange rates resulting from the application of an exchange premium or exchange commission to the official buying or selling rate. On December 31, 1971, the effective rates for traditional exports ( inc lud­ ing wool and meat) ranged between Ur$248 and Ur$368 per U S $ 1; the effective rate for a ll nontradi­ tional exports was Ur$368 per U S $ 1; the rates for imports were U r$250 per US$1 for petroleum, U r$500 for books and periodicals, and U r$370 for a ll other commodities; for other payments, effective rates included the fo l low ing: Ur$368 per US$1 for amortiza­ tion and interest on private loans; U r$370 per US$1 for freight; U r$500 per US$1 for travel expenses (other than fares) in countries other than Argentina, B r a z i l, and Paraguay, family remittances, royalties, dividends, commissions, insurance, technical assistance, and con­ sular fees; and U r$600 per US$1 for passages (travel tickets). In addition, certain export proceeds are subject to retention taxes (detracciones or retenciones) and certain imports are subject to special deposits (consignaciones) and surcharges (recargos), a ll of which give rise to various other effective buying and selling rates. Commercial banks are authorized to purchase exchange arising from transactions other than the above and other than certain other specified transactions at the rate of U r$500 per US$1 minus a fixed commis- * With effect from March 2, 1972 the exchange rate structure was simplified. A dual exchange rate system was introduced, with a com­ mercial rate (initially fixed at Ur$495 buying, and Ur$500 selling, per US$1) and a freely fluctuating financial rate (initially about Ur$7()0 per US$1). The commercial rate would be adjusted from time to time. iOn March 1, 1967, a new Central Bank was established but some operations are still being carried out on its behalf by the Bank of the Republic. The term "monetary authorities" as used here refers to both banks taken together. 458 sion of U r$3 per U S $ 1. Proceeds from invisibles received in Argentine pesos and B raz i l ian cruzeiros are bought and sold through the banking system at a fluctuating exchange rate. A tax of 2/io of 1 per cent is payable on a ll funds received from abroad. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through author­ ized banks, banking houses, and the monetary authori­ ties. The latter collect import surcharges and export taxes, hold the prepayments and advance deposits required for certain imports, and receive export and import registrations. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree­ ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the L A F TA multilateral clearing system; these countries are Argentina, Ch i l e, Co lomb ia, Mex ico, Peru, and Venezuela. Settlements w i th other countries are made in U. S. dollars or other convertible cur­ rencies. Imports and Import Payments A ll imports are subject to registration pr ior to placing orders abroad. There are certain import proh i­ bitions and most commodities are subject to surcharges, prepayments, and /or prescribed terms of payment. These special requirements often are different for imports of L A F TA or ig in and imports of other or ig in. Imports are classified into eight categories. Goods in one category are not subject to surcharge (recargo). Many imports require prepayments {consignaciones) in Uruguayan pesos of a certain percentage of the c.i.f. value; the prepayment must be lodged with the mone­ tary authorities at the time of registration and is refundable on application after six months. Imports by public sector agencies are exempt, as are, inter alia, imports financed with loans from international agencies or foreign governments at maturities of over ten years. An advance deposit of 200 per cent of the aforo c.i.f. value is required in principal on imports of vehicles equipped with foreign-made tires or tubes of types also produced in Uruguay, but the requirement is not enforced. As at the end of 1971, imports subject to a surcharge of 50 per cent or more were prohibited, as were certain imports of capital goods. V i r tua l ly a ll imports are subject, in addition to any customs duty required, to additional import duties ranging from 1.5 per cent to 18 per cent of the c.i.f. value and payable upon customs clearance; the 18 per cent rate introduced by a Decree of December 21, 1967 is not applied when the goods originate in G A TT ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution or L A F TA countries. A ll imports valued at over US$1 .82 are subject to consular charges of 1 per cent on the peso amount resulting from conversion of the f.o.b. value at a rate of U r$55 per U S $ 1; the amount of the charges is payable in foreign exchange, at a rate of U r $l = US$2 .10 (at a rate of U r $l = US$1 for private imports of petroleum and petroleum pro­ ducts, alcohol, and tetraethyl lead, and U r $l = US$0 .50 for official imports of the same commodities). Prepayments and surcharges in most cases are calcu­ lated either on assumed c.i.f. prices (aforos) established for many commodities or on the actual c.i.f. value, whichever is higher. In a few cases, the calculation is based on an officially assessed price (also referred to as aforo), which usually is expressed in U . S. dollars per k i logram. The application of surcharges may differ according to whether imports are or are not transported in Uruguayan ships or in ships owned by foreign lines that participate in line conferences in which Uruguay also takes part. In 1971 the authorities followed a policy of pro­ hibiting the sale of foreign exchange for imports not having certain m in imum terms of financing. F or certain imports meeting these financing requirements, an exchange rate guarantee was given subject to the lodging of a peso deposit. In the implementation of the arrange­ ments certain payments arrears arise. Payments for Invisibles There are basic exchange allowances for certain current invisibles. The exchange allocation for travel to Argentina, B r a z i l, and Paraguay is $a 1,500 and C r$ 1,000; that for tourist travel to other countries is equivalent to the price of an economy-class ticket, subject to a l im it of US$900 a person a tr ip. Pur­ chases of exchange for travel can only be made once every 30 days. Exchange for family remittances is limited to the equivalent of US$50 a month for each recipient and remittor. Transportation companies may convert the peso proceeds from the sale of passages at an effective exchange rate of U r$600 per US$1 (which includes a 20 per cent exchange t ax ). Pay­ ments for a ll other invisibles may in principle be made freely through the banking system, provided that in the case of contractual payments the relevant foreign obligation has been registered with the Central Bank; private sector payments in respect of profits, dividends, rents, and certain other invisibles must be registered in advance at the beginning of the semester in which they are to be made and must be authorized by accept­ ance of the registration. There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes, but except for travel to countries with which Uruguay maintains reciprocal credit agreements, only 10 per cent of the travel allocations may be taken out in the form of foreign banknotes and 40 per cent in travelers checks. U R U G U AY Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of the principal exports are subject to taxes (detracciones or retenciones), which are with­ held by the monetary authorities on the basis of the aforo value of the commodity concerned. The tax is stipulated in pesos per unit of export commodity, but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export, except that for exports of meat the stipulated maximum is 25 per cent while for wool the permitted limits are 2 per cent and 35 per cent of the aforo value. The actual percentages may be adjusted at 60-day intervals. The exchange proceeds of traditional exports subject to taxes must be surrendered in fu ll to the monetary authorities not later than 30 days after shipment has been authorized; the proceeds from exports of nontra- ditional products must be surrendered within 60 days if the sale is on a cash basis or within 210 days if the sale is made on credit. F or most exports, including wool and meat, minimum f.o.b. values (minimum sur­ render prices or aforos) expressed in U. S. dollars per kilogram have been established for various grades and types. Subsidies (reintegros) of up to 35 per cent of the f.o.b. value are granted on certain nontradi- tional exports. Exports of certain types of beef dairy cows and wool ewes are prohibited. Exports of wheat, sorghum, corn and sunflower seeds are from time to time per­ mitted up to certain quantities. Proceeds from Invisibles A ll proceeds from invisibles may be held, utilized, or sold to the banking system. There are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital Inward capital transfers by either residents or non­ residents may be made freely through the banking system. Outward capital transfers are subject to prior authorization; those of resident-owned capital are restricted. A ll obligations in excess of US$1 ,000 that are contracted abroad by the private sector must be declared within 30 days of the date of the contract. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, in Uruguay or abroad; any purchases abroad for nonindustrial use, however, must be financed from the buyer's own exchange holdings. Imports and exports of gold by or on behalf of the monetary authorities or authorized industrial and professional users are settled at the official buying and selling rates. The Central Bank would de­ liver foreign exchange cover immediately to enable the importer to comply with the terms of the import contract. (2) Imports financed under payment terms of 90 days: Importers were required to deposit within a period of 45 days after June 30 the local currency equivalent of bills due or falling due up to July 31. Foreign exchange cover would be supplied by the Central Bank 90 days after the expiration date of the b i l l. (3) Imports financed under payment terms of 120, 180, 270, and 360 days: F or these, the Central Bank would provide foreign exchange cover 120, 180, 270, or 360 days after the expiration dates of the respec­ tive bills.
