U R U G U AY 465 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.265275 gram of fine gold per Venezuelan Bo l ivar. No transactions take place at the par value. Exchange transactions take place at the fo l­ lowing rates.1 The Central Bank of Venezuela purchases proceeds of the petroleum and iron ore exporting com­ panies at the rate of Bs 4.30 per U S $ 1. A ny proceeds from exports of cacao and coffee that are offered for sale to the Central Bank must be purchased by it at the rate of Bs 4.485 per US$1. The Central Bank sells exchange to the Government and its agencies and to the commercial banks (for sales to the public only) at Bs 4.385 per U S $ 1 .2 The commercial banks purchase foreign exchange from the public at rates close to Bs 4.38 per US $ 1. Commercial banks must sell exchange to the public at Bs 4.40 per US$1 for a ll transactions; foreign banks may only sell foreign exchange that has not been obtained from the Central Bank. Some foreign exchange is also negotiated on the two stock exchanges, where buying and selling rates usually are slightly below Bs 4.40 per US$ 1. Exchange houses are permitted to deal only in banknotes, coins, and travelers checks. The Central Bank offers swap facilities under which it buys U. S. dollars at Bs 4.37 and resells at Bs 4.40 after 90 or 180 days. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and export licenses, when required, are generally issued by the M in is t ry of Development or the M in is t ry of Agriculture and Livestock, depending on the commod­ ity. Under the terms of an agreement between the Government and the Central Bank, the latter has the responsibility of ensuring that a subsidy is applied to imports of wheat for human consumption and to cer­ tain exports of coffee and cacao. Prescription of Currency Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Ch i le, Co lomb ia, the Dom in ican Republic, Mex ico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. Proceeds from exports of petroleum and petroleum derivatives must not be received through these accounts. Otherwise, no prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain goods is either prohibited or 1 The exchange rates given (except those for the Central Bank's swap transactions) are those applicable to sight drafts on New York. 2 The Central Bank does not sell foreign exchange to the public but does sell minor amounts to its staff and certain government officials, at the Bs 4.40 rate, for travel expenses and personal remit­ tances. 466 reserved for the Government; these include fully assem­ bled automobiles, certain textiles, coffee, citrus fruit, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigarette paper, natural pearls, and matches. In addition, many other commodities require import licenses; quantitative restrictions applicable irrespective of origin are main­ tained on these items for protective purposes. Licenses are valid for a ll countries except Rhodesia and South A f r i c a. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quantity imported (contingentamiento). Imports of wheat for human consumption receive a subsidy of 25.55 per cent of the f.o.b. value, calculated at Bs 4.40 per US$1; they require an import license, and the Central Bank's Import Subsidy Office establishes eligibility for the subsidy. A ll other commodities are free from import licensing. Imports from Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are prohibited. Import payments may be made freely. Payments for Invisibles A ll payments for invisibles may be made freely; private sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made from commercial banks or exchange houses. Resident and nonresident travelers must on departure pay a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemptions exist for children under seven, foreign tourists, Vene­ zuelan and foreign diplomats, and personnel of inter­ national organizations. Travelers may freely export domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain furs and hides, scrap metals, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of many other commodi­ ties, except petroleum. Most export licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of Development, but those for coffee and cacao are granted by the M in i s t ry of Agr icu l ture and Livestock. Exports of products containing subsidized imported wheat are subject to special arrangements to ensure that the sub­ sidy received is repaid. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the M in i s t ry of Finance. The petroleum and i ron ore exporting com­ panies must surrender to the Central Bank export pro­ ceeds, to the extent of their local currency requirements (including taxes), at a rate of Bs 4.30 per U S $ 1. Otherwise, there are no surrender requirements for export proceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may (but need not) sell exchange proceeds to the Central Bank at Bs 4.485 per U S $ 1; they may receive an export subsidy calculated to pre­ vent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Vene­ zuelan ports from falling below specified m in imum ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution amounts regardless of external prices for these prod­ ucts. E l ig ib i l i ty for this subsidy is maintained also if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. The m in i­ mum prices guaranteed by the Government range from Bs 175.00 to Bs 185.44 a quintal for coffee, and are Bs 121 or Bs 150 a quintal for cacao. In principle, the benefit of these arrangements may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. A ll exports to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are pro­ hibited, as are exports of petroleum and military equipment to mainland Ch ina and No r th Ko r e a. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are freely disposa­ ble. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, w i th the exception that the Currency Law prohibits the importation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins. The importation of Venezuelan gold coins is reserved for the Cen tral Bank. Capital A ll capital transfers are permitted freely. Brokerage activity in Venezuela, however, in shares or units of foreign investment trusts or mutual funds is prohibited. There is no registration procedure for incoming capital. The Cen tral Bank regulates bank credit to nonresidents and companies whose capital is more than 50 per cent owned by physical persons or companies that are resi­ dent or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law of December 30, 1970 authorizes the Government to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 per cent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. Th is law also provides special regulations for foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may ho ld, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment pur­ poses. The Cen tral Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coins, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated between licensed importers, exchange houses, and the public. Commerc ial banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as is the import of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Other imports and exports of gold require licenses. Imports require licenses from the M in i s t ry of Finance and in certain cases also from the M in i s t ry of Development, while exports are licensed by the M in i s t ry of Finance only. The law prescribes a V E N E Z U E LA license for a ll imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the M in i s t ry of Development as an industrial user, but in practice imports and exports by private persons are permitted free of license. Imports of gold coins and of gold bars and ingots weighing more than 12 kilograms are free of customs duty; a ll other gold imports are subject to duty at varying rates. A ll imports of nonmonetary gold are subject to consu­ lar duties ranging from 2 per cent to 3Vi per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1971 In addition to the measures specified below, a num­ ber of commodities were added to the list of goods that require an individual import license. January 1. In application of the General Banking L aw of December 30, 1970, the reserve requirements were eased for domestic commercial banks and tight­ ened for foreign commercial banks operating in Vene­ zuela. Foreign banks were required within six months either to become domestic banks or to declare their intention to do so, if they wished to be treated as domestic banks after June 30, 1971. F r om that date, foreign banks would no longer be able to receive sav­ ings deposits or deposits from public agencies, issue savings bonds or negotiable certificates of deposit, sell foreign exchange acquired from the Central Bank, or increase their capital or the number of their offices. No foreign banks that had not yet established a branch in Venezuela could be authorized to establish one in the future. July 29. To stimulate industrial exports, export licensing requirements were abolished for many manu­ factured, semimanufactured, or processed commodities. July 31. The Hydrocarbons Reversion Law was enacted. It provided that a ll o il concessions wou ld revert without compensation to the State upon their expiration; the residual assets of foreign-owned petro­ leum companies also would at that time revert to the State. August 10. The Central Bank issued regulations enabling the issuance of negotiable certificates of deposit. The m in imum denomination was set at Bs 50,000 and the m in imum maturity at 180 days. August 23. The exchange rates for the U. S. dollar were maintained unchanged. August 26. A b i ll was signed into law reserving the exploitation of natural gas resources to the State. December 21. A ll exchange rates were appreciated in terms of the U. S. dollar by 10 points, from Bs 4.40 to Bs 4.30, from about Bs 4.48 to about Bs 4.38, from Bs 4.485 to Bs 4.385, and from Bs 4.50 to Bs 4.40. 467 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution V I E T N AM Exchange Rate System No par value for the Vietnamese Piastre has been established w i th the Fund. The official parity is VN $ 8 0 . 00 per U S $ 1; no sales or purchases of exchange take place at the official rate. There are two exchange markets, both with fixed exchange rates: the official market and the limited parallel market (see Table of Exchange Rates, be low ). Transactions on behalf of Vietnamese and foreign governments for official pur­ poses and transfers to Vietnamese students abroad pass through the official market. The application of a con­ solidation premium or a consolidation tax of VN $ 3 8 . 00 per US$1 to the official rate gives rise to effective exchange rates of VN$117 .20 buying, and VN$118 .80 selling, per US $ 1. The limited parallel exchange market is a three-tier market based on rates of VN $ 2 7 5, VN $ 4 0 0, and VN $ 4 10 per US $ 1. Imports of U . S. origin financed under the Commerc ial Import Program or U. S. P. L. 480 (Title I) are subject to a selling rate of VN$277 .75 per U S $ 1. The same selling rate plus an equalization tax of VN $ 75 per US$1 is applicable to imports of non -U. S. origin under the Commerc ial Import Program, giving rise to an effective selling rate of VN$352 .75 per US $ 1. A selling rate of VN$404 .00 per US$1 is applicable to a ll other imports. Imports of textile piece goods, however, are subject to an equaliza­ tion tax of VN $ 2 00 per U S $ 1; hence, the effective selling rate for these commodities is VN$477 .75, VN$552 .75, or VN$604 .00, depending on origin and financing. A ll payments for invisibles, other than those passing through the official market, as well as any authorized capital transfers, are settled at a selling rate of VN$414 .10 per US $ 1. On the buying side, a ll exchange receipts that must not be sold in the official market are purchased at an effective rate of VN$405 .90 per U S $ 1; these exchange receipts include a ll export proceeds except those from rubber, the effective buying rate for which is VN$401 .841 as a result of a 1 per cent tax on the proceeds. The application of pre-November 1971 equalization taxes (taxes de perequation) to imports financed by the importer (sans devises) gives rise to a piastre cost wh ich may range between VN$284 .75 and VN$754 .00 per US $ 1. Payments and receipts in either exchange market must be effected through the authorized banks. Au tho r­ ized banks are allowed to engage in forward buying or selling of foreign exchange in the domestic or foreign exchange markets only in relation to payments for imports and in specified currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Na t ional Bank of V i e t -N am (Directorate-General of Exchange). 468 Most remittances not made through the parallel market must have the prior approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange; the authority to approve some payments for private invisibles has been delegated to the author­ ized banks. Imports under the U. S. "Pub l ic A i d" pro­ gram 1 require no license but are subject to special con­ tracts or procurement procedures. Licenses for other imports financed with U. S. aid are issued by the M i n­ istry of Economy (Directorate of General Trade) and are countersigned by the Na t ional Bank (Directorate of Fore ign A i d ). Licenses for imports financed with V ie t- Nam's own exchange are issued, when required, by the M in i s t ry of Economy (Directorate of Ex ternal Trade) and are countersigned by the Na t ional Bank (Directorate- General of Exchange). However, for imports of a non­ commercial character, machinery spare parts, and cu l­ tural materials, when valued at US$100 or less, the Na t ional Bank (Directorate-General of Exchange) is authorized to grant foreign exchange, when required. Export licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of Economy (Directorate of External T rade ), but they also require the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Prescription of Currency W i th the exception of import payments under the F rench credit insurance program, a ll settlements must be made and received in U. S. dollars. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may maintain accounts with banks, sub­ ject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Nonresident Accounts in Free Piastres may be freely credited with the proceeds from the sale of convertible exchange and may be freely debited for most payments to residents. A category of nonresident accounts, Cap i tal Accounts, covers piastres owned by nonresident foreigners that may " it be transferred abroad. Balances in Cap i tal A c. i. . is may be used for investment in certain areas of w onomic activity designated by the M in i s t ry of N a t ioi 1 Economy. The ir use is subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Investments financed from Cap i tal Accounts generally are not cov­ ered by the Investment L aw of 1963 (see section on Cap i ta l, be low ), and proceeds from the liquidation of such investments are credited to Cap i tal Accounts unless the M in i s t ry of Na t ional Economy has declared them eligible for the privileges of the law. Balances in Cap i tal Accounts are negotiable between nonresident foreigners. Imports and Import Payments Most imports are made in accordance w i th an annual 1 I.e., imports under the Dollar Project, under part of the AID pro­ gram, under Development Loan Funds, and under Titles II and III of U. S. P .L. 480. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Commerc ial Import Program, the bulk of which is divided into three parts: (1) imports financed w i th funds from the U. S. Agency for International Develop­ ment ( A I D ); (2) imports financed from V ie t -Nam 's own foreign exchange resources; and (3) "third-country- financed imports," i.e., imports financed with Japanese reparations, French, German, and Japanese loans, or F rench export credit. In principle, products imported under the A ID program are not included among imports that are financed otherwise, and vice versa. However, when A ID financing proves insufficient for obtaining imports of essential products, such imports may be financed from V ie t-Nam's official exchange reserves. M any imports are prohibited. Except for those commodities also financed by the U. S. A ID programs and prohibited commodities (a temporary prohibition applies to two-, three-, and four- wheeled vehicles, fresh fruits and vegetables, and com­ pletely knocked-down television and radio sets w i th the exception of three specified makes), a ll imports financed with V ie t -Nam 's own exchange are effected through the "Import C red i t" procedure, under which they are exempt from license. A ll other imports require licenses. Some imports are subject to advance deposits. Some imports are permitted without foreign exchange (sans devises); these include imports by end-users with branches abroad, gifts and samples, spare parts for international airlines, and other small imports, when the Directorate-General of Exchange is satisfied that the foreign exchange privately held by the importer has not been obtained illegally. Such imports, in addition to any applicable advance deposit requirements, are subject to the equalization taxes in force prior to November 16, 1971, which range from V N $7 to VN $ 3 50 per U S $ 1. A ll imports of textile piece goods are subject to an equalization tax of VN $ 2 00 per U S $ 1. Imports from the Khmer Republic are suspended. Import licenses generally are va l id for all noncommu- nist countries except the Khmer Repub l ic; the main exception is that goods financed by U. S. aid must originate in " P D 3 1" countries (the Republic of Ch ina, Cey lon, India, the Republic of Ko rea, Mo rocco, P a k i­ stan, the Philippines, Singapore, Tun is ia) or the Un i ted States. A ll imports financed with V ie t-Nam's own foreign exchange and valued at V N$ 10,000 or over require a letter of credit. In addition to the advance deposit requirements mentioned above, mandatory margin deposits are prescribed on the opening of import letters of credit for most commodities; depending on the goods involved, these deposits are 25, 35, and 50 per cent. They are calculated on the countervalue at the applica­ ble exchange rate of the invoice price. A l though the m in imum margins are set at 25, 35, and 50 per cent, commercial banks are free to apply higher margins according to the standing of the importer and the mar­ ket situation for the commodity concerned. Some essen­ tial commodities are exempt from margin deposit V I E T - N AM requirements; these include flour, m i lk, sugar, newsprint, petroleum products, fertilizers, agricultural implements, and raw materials and industrial equipment imported by end-users. Some imports are subject to a different type of deposit (consignation). Exchange, when granted, is made available at the limited parallel market rates of VN $ 2 75 and VN $ 4 00 per US $ 1. Imports of non -U. S. origin under the C om­ mercial Import Program are subject to an equalization tax of VN $ 75 per US $ 1, giving rise to an effective sell­ ing rate of VN$352 .75 per U S $ 1. Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require approval by the Directorate-General of Exchange. Exchange for govern­ ment transfers and for transfers to Vietnamese students is sold at the rate of VN $ 1 18 per U S $ 1. F or a ll other authorized payments for invisibles, exchange is sold at the limited parallel market rate of VN $ 4 10 per U S $ 1. Students are granted US$80 a month for study in the Republic of Ch ina or Hong K o ng and US$150 a month for study elsewhere; they are also granted allocations for housing and for extraordinary expenses. Foreign spe­ cialists employed in V i e t -N am may transfer up to 50 per cent of their salary every month, and applications for larger transfers may be approved; they are also entitled to a special allocation for home leave. In principle, foreign firms are generally permitted to transfer up to 70 per cent of their net annual profit after tax, after examination of their accounts and after deduction of any losses in previous years. Profit trans­ fers by foreign enterprises established or expanded after 1963 under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law are governed by the provisions of that law; since 1971 there is also a "Foreign Exchange Wo rk ing Cap i tal System" (see section on Cap i ta l, be low ). A l though dividends declared in V i e t -N am and accruing to non­ residents may in principle be transferred up to 70 per cent, under a system established in 1971 transfers of profits, dividends, and interest are limited to 20 per cent annually of the registered amount. Each resident authorized to travel abroad is entitled to purchase the following amounts of foreign exchange at the limited parallel market rate of VN $ 4 10 per U S $ 1: travelers to the Khmer Republic and Laos US$30 a day, with a maximum of US$300 a person a trip, and travelers to other countries US$40 a day, with a maximum of US$2,400 a person a trip. V ie t­ namese nationals are required to pay the following exit visa fees: travelers to the Khmer Republic and Laos VN $ 5 , 0 00 a trip, without limitation of duration; travelers to other A s i an countries and Aus tra l ia V N$ 15,000 to V N$ 105,000, depending on duration of the trip; and travelers to European, A f r ican, and Ame r ican countries VN$50 ,000 to VN$140 ,000, de­ pending on duration. If the destination of the traveler includes several countries, the exit visa fees are calcu­ lated on the basis of the farthest country. Ch i ld ren 469 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution V I E T - N AM under ten years of age pay half of the above fees. The allocations mentioned may be supplemented by the equivalent of US$40 in foreign banknotes. Travelers are permitted to take with them up to V N$ 1,000 in Vietnamese banknotes. Foreign exchange not used by foreign travelers may be re-exported when a declaration is made to the customs and evidence is given that any utilized exchange has been sold to an authorized bank. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports do not require a license; they must be registered with an authorized bank, however, which is responsible for the repatriation of the foreign exchange. A ll exports to communist countries, exports to any destination of manufactured or semimanufactured prod­ ucts originally imported into V i e t -N am, gold, rice, rice products, and certain other items are prohibited. Export proceeds must be surrendered at the limited parallel market rate of VN $ 4 10 per U S $ 1. Export proceeds of rubber are subject to a tax of 1 per cent on the f.o.b. value calculated at the limited parallel market rate of exchange. Exporters are allowed to retain in E F AC (Exportations, Fra is Accessoires) accounts 3 per cent of their total export proceeds for the settlement of incidental expenses related to the export transaction. Proceeds from Invisibles The rate of V N $ 1 18 per US$1 is applicable to receipts from invisibles arising from sales of foreign exchange by the Vietnamese and foreign governments. A ll other proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered at the limited parallel market rate of VN $ 4 10 per US $ 1. Fore ign military personnel and official U. S. c iv i l ian personnel serving in V i e t -N am are paid in scrip ( "m i l i­ tary payment certificates" or M P C s) which can be exchanged for piastres at the limited parallel market rate of VN $ 4 10 only through official channels. They are not permitted to possess foreign banknotes or travelers checks in V i e t -N am, but there are military banking facilities under which eligible foreign persons may open accounts in piastres, M P C s, or U. S. dollars at two U. S. banks in Saigon. Travelers entering V i e t -N am may bring in any amount of foreign exchange, but it must be declared to the cus­ toms on entry. A traveler may bring in Vietnamese banknotes up to a total of V N$ 1,000. Foreign military and c iv i l ian personnel (government officials) must sur­ render on arrival any foreign banknotes they bring into V i e t -N am. Capital Under general regulations, capital may be imported without formalities, but foreign investors must register their capital w i th the Vietnamese authorities and agree on the terms of the investment in order to be able to 470 repatriate their capital and to transfer profits. Under the Investment L aw of 1963, special benefits may be accorded to new foreign investments in the sectors of the economy that are given high pr ior i ty. Applications must be approved by the interdepartmental Investment Committee. The m in imum investment in agriculture was established at VN $ 0 .5 m i l l ion, and in industry at V N $1 m i l l ion. Imports of equipment and spare parts needed by foreign undertakings covered by the law are exempt from customs duties. Fore ign technicians employed by these enterprises are exempt from income tax for 2 years. Foreign investments are free of taxes on profits, securities, and real estate for specified periods of time. The new investments are not subject to any nationalization measures for the first 15 years from the date of the written authorization granted to the investor; they are accorded the same treatment as that applicable to domestic investments. The law provides for the trans­ fer of profits at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent of the invested capital, and for the repatriation of the original investment after 5 years at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent if the capital is newly imported (after 20 years for investment of foreign-owned capital previously held in V i e t -N am ). A ll imports and exports of capital (including imports in k i n d ), except those made by the Vietnamese Government or foreign governments, are settled at the limited parallel market rate. Investments not covered by the Investment Law or by the regime described in the following paragraph are subject to the regulations and case-to-case decisions of the Directorate-General of Exchange, wh ich normally authorizes the transfer of up to 70 per cent of net annual profits after taxes but does not permit disinvest­ ment; such investments are not eligible for the above- mentioned tax exemptions. Under a "Fore ign Exchange Wo rk ing Cap i tal System" introduced in 1971, foreign capital imported in the form of direct investment or as medium-term and long-term credit in cash or in k ind may be registered w i th the Na t ional Bank and treated as follows. Cap i tal must be brought from abroad and sold through authorized banks, where it is credited to a "Fo re ign Exchange Wo rk ing Accoun t ." Profits, dividends, and interest on such capital may be transferred annually up to a max i­ mum of 20 per cent of the registered amount and repatriation may be made up to an annual maximum of 25 per cent of the registered capital. Gold W i th in V i e t -N am, the holding of gold and a ll trans­ actions in gold are subject to licensing, but the controls are not rigidly enforced and unlicensed holdings of gold by individuals are tolerated. On ly the Na t ional Bank is empowered to import and export gold. A ll domestic transactions in gold are subject to a luxury tax of 10 per cent on the sale value or the manufacturing cost. The export of gold by physical or jur id ical persons other than the Na t ional Bank is prohibited. The import of gold by ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution physical or jur id ical persons other than the Na t ional Bank is also prohibited, w i th the following exceptions: (1) Vietnamese settled in Laos may, when returning to V i e t -N am, br ing in up to 13 taels 2 of gold in the form of jewelry; (2) residents may import gold without allocation of foreign exchange, provided that they have an import license and pay a customs duty of 130 per 2 One tael equals about 37.57 grams or 1.18 troy ounces. cent and an equalization tax of VN $ 1 00 per U S $ 1; (3) nonresidents may, without allocation of foreign exchange, bring into V i e t -N am any quantity of gold, provided that its entry is declared and that it is deposited in safe custody w i th an authorized bank; the utilization of such gold is subject to prior authorization by the Directorate-General of Exchange, and if it is sold in V i e t -N am the sales proceeds must be credited to a Cap i tal Accoun t. Authorized capital outflows. Changes during 1971 February 3. By Joint Decision N o. 34 of the M in i s­ tries of Economy and Finance the complementary sub­ sidy for black tea exports was reintroduced. The sub­ sidy amounted to VN $ 1 25 per US$1 of repatriated export proceeds and applied retroactively to such pro­ ceeds repatriated after October 4, 1970. March 6. By Interministerial Order N o. 86 of the Ministries of Economy and Finance the parallel market rate of VN$277 .75 per US$1 was made applicable to payments of freight, insurance, and incidental expenses relating to imports with V ie t -Nam 's own foreign exchange, imports under foreign credit insur­ ance, and imports under the U. S. P. L. 480 program, except specified petroleum products. These payments previously were settled at the VN $ 1 1 8 . 80 rate. Cus­ toms duties and the austerity tax continued to be calculated on the basis of V N $ 80 per U S $ 1. May 19. Import deposit requirements were removed for 29 categories of goods, mostly chemicals and machinery. June 7. Joint Order N o. 242 established, in addition to the existing import procedures, an "Import C red i t" system for imports of specified commodities financed with V ie t -Nam 's own foreign exchange. Imports under this system were exempt from licensing. An importer could obtain on request an "import fund" in foreign exchange from an authorized bank, provided that he deposited: (a) the counterpart of the goods computed at the rate of VN $ 2 75 per U S $ 1; (b) an equalization 471 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution V I E T - N AM tax of VN $ 1 25 per US $ 1, irrespective of the type of commodity; and (c) any import deposit that might be specified by circular. The "import fund" had to be utilized within one year for the opening of a letter of credit; it could not be returned to commercial banks but could be transferred freely to another importer. The goods for wh ich the system could be used were a ll goods permitted to be financed w i th V ie t-Nam's own resources (i.e., excluding those being imported w i th U. S. A ID funds or included in the prohibited l i s t ), whether previ­ ously payable through the official or the parallel market, with the exception only of automobiles, two-wheeled or three-wheeled vehicles, fresh fruits and vegetables, and a ll completely knocked-down television and radio sets not of three specified makes. The goods had to be imported direct from the country of or ig in. Imports under this system were subject to a ll existing customs duties and austerity taxes. June 7. The following prescription of currency rules went into effect for imports under the "Import C red i t" system: payment in sterling for goods of Hong K o ng origin and provenance purchased from a supplier in Hong K o n g; payment in French francs for goods of F rench origin and provenance purchased from a supplier in France; and payment in U. S. dollars in a ll other cases. June 10. By order N o. 250 of the M in i s t ry of Economy, export licensing requirements were abolished except for the fo l low ing: rubber, imported products, products using imported raw materials, products financed under U. S. P. L. 480 as we ll as similar domestic products, metals and scrap metals, antiques, military equipment, and export services. June 10. Order N o. 251 of the M in i s t ry of Economy established a supplementary subsidy of V N $ 75 per US$1 for exports exempt from licensing requirements. The subsidy was paid by the Na t ional Bank of V ie t- N am through authorized banks. July 2. A new equalization tax was imposed on cer­ tain imports financed by the U. S. A I D. The tax was V N $ 10 to V N $ 80 per US$1 and the goods concerned included pulp, soybean o i l, and cotton yarn. July 8. An Interministerial Order of the Ministries of Economy and Finance specified that the parallel market rate did not apply to duty-free imports effected, whether directly or through the intermediary of the Office de Ravitaillement Central, by administrative or military organizations, provided the expenditures were included in the Na t ional Budget or a regional budget. Such im­ ports, therefore, were eligible for the VN $ 1 18 rate. July 20. Joint Communique N o. 145 of the M i n i s­ tries of Economy and Finance specified the conditions under which goods entering V i e t -N am as "baggage accompanying owner through the Tan Son Nhut air­ port" were exempt from all entry taxes and from licensing requirements. August 23. The spot buying and selling rates of the Na t ional Bank and the authorized exchange banks for 472 the U. S. dollar were maintained at VN$117 .20 -118 .80 in the official exchange market and at VN$272 .25 -277 .75 in the limited parallel market. September 1. The Na t ional Bank limited its foreign dealings to the U. S. dollar and suspended quotations for the French franc and the pound sterling. The offi­ c ial quotation of these currencies was resumed on December 21, 1971. September 1. Henceforth a ll imports financed w i th V ie t-Nam's own reserves had in practice to be settled in U. S. dollars. In exceptional cases, however, import­ ers could be granted an exemption from this require­ ment. Previously, in addition to the U. S. dollar, settle­ ments also took place in French francs and pounds sterling, but the U. S. dollar already was the only cur­ rency used for imports from sources other than France and Hong K o ng that were financed by V i e t -N am. September 4. By Joint Decision N o. 373 of the M i n­ istries of Economy and Finance, an export subsidy of V N $ 50 per US$1 was established for black tea. The subsidy was additional to the V N $ 75 per US$1 export subsidy established on June 10, 1971 and was retroac­ tive to that date. September 22. Communique N o. 162 of the M in is t ry of Economy set new advance deposit rates for imports under the U. S. A ID program. September 22. The Na t ional Bank's Notice N o. 86 to Banks went into effect. It confirmed officially that for financial settlements under the export and import pro­ grams financed with Vietnamese resources, the Na t ional Bank would buy and sell U. S. dollars only (except for imports under the French credit insurance procedure). Importers were allowed limited forward cover facilities at authorized banks for cases where suppliers' invoices were expressed in deutsche mark, Japanese yen, Ne th­ erlands guilders, or pounds sterling. September 30. Order N o. 435 and Communique N o. 166 of the M in i s t ry of Economy specified that the sup­ ply of certain products and services (lumber, clothing, batteries, etc.) to the U. S. Government by Vietnamese contractors within the territory of V i e t -N am, if settled in U. S. dollars, would be considered as on-the-spot exports and benefit from the VN $ 75 per US$1 export subsidy of June 10, 1971. November 15. An exchange reform was promulgated, which took effect the next day. Pending the approval by the Na t ional Assembly of a law authorizing the G o v­ ernment to change the official parity, the rate in the official exchange market remained at VN $ 1 18 = U S $ 1, but would apply only to outward transfers by the V ie t­ namese Government, inward transfers from foreign gov­ ernments, and transfers to students abroad; this rate would no longer apply to any imports. W i th in the limited parallel market, where previously a fixed rate of VN $ 2 75 per US$1 was applied, a three-tier system was established: an exchange rate of VN $ 2 75 per US$1 would be applicable to imports under the Commerc ial Import Program and under the U. S. P. L. 480 T i t le I ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution program; an exchange rate of VN $ 4 00 per US$1 would apply to a ll other imports; an exchange rate of VN $ 4 10 would apply to a ll exports and a ll other transactions. It was announced that the new rate structure wou ld be managed as a flexible system w i th frequent adjustments in small steps commensurate w i th the rate of inflation. Du r ing the rest of the year, however, no further adjust­ ments in the basic rates of the new exchange rate struc­ ture took place. It was also stated that protective policies were being reviewed; a simplified customs tariff would be intro­ duced, austerity taxes would be abolished, and the scope of import prohibitions would be reduced. November 15. By Decree N o. 148 an Exchange C om­ mittee composed of the M in is ter of Finance as Cha i r­ man, and the Minister of Economy and the Governor of the Na t ional Bank as members was established with the following responsibilities: determining the criteria and procedures for the organization and functioning of the parallel exchange market; determining the exchange rates applicable to operations effected in the parallel exchange market; and deciding on any other necessary measures relative to that market. The decree, which replaced Decree N o. 116 of October 3, 1970, also specified the transactions having access to the parallel exchange market. U n t il further notice, the U. S. dollar would be the only currency admitted to the parallel exchange market. November 15. No t ice N o. 0 1 0 / 9 5 /D of the Na t ional Bank supplemented Decree N o. 148. It specified the transactions eligible for the parallel exchange market and the exchange rates and procedures applicable. It also specified that, except for certain specified transac­ tions, foreign exchange sales in the parallel exchange market no longer required authorization by the Directorate-General of Exchange. November 15. No t ice N o. 0 1 0 / 9 6 /D of the Na t ional Bank allowed authorized banks, under certain condi­ tions, to delegate to hotels the right to purchase foreign exchange from tourists. November 15. Joint Decision N o. 498 of the M i n i s­ tries of Economy and Finance established a "Foreign Exchange Wo rk ing Cap i tal System" to encourage the inflow of capital in the form of direct investment and of medium-term or long-term credit in cash or in k ind. Profits, dividends, and interest on capital registered under this regime could be transferred annually up to 20 per cent of the registered capital and the capital itself could be repatriated at a rate not exceeding 25 per cent a year. November 15. By Decree N o. 1120 the amount of foreign exchange which may be directly granted by the Directorate-General of Exchange for the import of cu l­ tural publications, machinery spare parts, and noncom­ mercial articles was raised from US$50 to US$100. November 15. By Interministerial Decree N o. 494 a ll imports financed with V ie t -Nam 's own foreign exchange (with the exceptions listed under June 7: automobiles, V I E T - N AM etc.) could be effected only under the "Import C red i t" system, under which no import licenses were required. The existing prohibited import list remained in effect. Henceforth, the Na t ional Bank would make available to authorized banks the foreign exchange for the "Import C red i t" funds concerned, but without giving an exchange rate guarantee. Imports under this procedure wou ld temporarily be exempt from import deposits, but import duty and austerity tax were payable in accordance w i th existing regulations, and equalization taxes wou ld be applicable as the Minister might direct. Implementing Notice N o. 186 replaced No t ice N o. 115 of June 9, 1971. November 15. By Decree N o. 677 a Na t ional Coun­ c il for Export Promotion was established under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister. November 15. Interministerial Order N o. 492 of the Ministries of Economy and Finance established as an interim measure a system of supplementary equaliza­ tion taxes and subsidies, pending the enactment of the new customs tariff. These taxes and subsidies were ca l­ culated so as to result in the same import tax receipts envisaged under the new customs tariff. The system was abolished the same day. The equalization taxes existing pr ior to November 15 also were abolished, except for imports sans devises (see next en try). November 15. By Interministerial Order N o. 493 of the Ministries of Economy and Finance, the equaliza­ tion taxes applicable to imported goods were amended as follows: Goods of U. S. origin imported under the Commerc ial Import Program, goods imported under U. S. P. L. 480, and goods imported under other import programs were exempt. Goods of non -U. S. origin imported under the Commerc ial Import Program were subject to an equalization tax rate of V N $ 75 per US $ 1. Goods imported without foreign exchange (sans devises) remained subject to the previous system of equalization taxes, ranging from V N $7 to VN $ 3 50 per U S $ 1. November 15. Joint Decree N o. 495 of the Ministries of Economy and Finance established an E F AC (Expo r­ t a t i o n, F ra is Accessoires) system allowing exporters to retain an "export surcharge" of 3 per cent of total export proceeds for the settlement of incidental expenses related to the export transaction. November 15. By Joint Decision N o. 496 of the Ministries of Economy and Finance the supplementary subsidy of V N $ 50 per US$1 on exports of black tea was abolished. November 15. By Decree N o. 497 of the M in i s t ry of Economy the export subsidy on "on-the-spck" exports and that of V N $ 75 per US$1 on minor exports were abolished. November 15. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA 1 Exchange Rate System No par value for the Western Samoan Ta la has been established w i th the Fund. A fixed relationship is main­ tained between the tala and the New Zealand dollar; the middle rate is WS$0.8076 = N Z $ 1, and the buying and selling rates are WS$0.8019 and WS$0.8132 per N Z $ 1, respectively. The buying and selling rates for the U . S. dollar are US$1.4937 and US$1 .4662, respec­ tively, per WS $ 1. Administration of Control Western Samoa is a member of the Sterling A r e a. Exchange control is administered by the M in is ter of Finance operating as the exchange control authority; the M in is ter may delegate his approval authority to the F inanc ial Secretary, who in turn may delegate part of his powers to authorized banks. A ll payments to non­ residents of Western Samoa require the approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance. The M in is t ry, however, has dele­ gated to the Bank of Western Samoa, the only author­ ized bank, authority to approve certain payments up to any amount and certain other payments up to specified amounts. Prescription of Currency A l though Western Samoa is a member of the Sterling A r e a, and although most settlements with Sterling A r ea territories take place in Sterling A r ea currencies, there are no prescriptions as to the currencies in wh ich pay­ ments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of resi­ dents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited from a ll sources, mainly for reasons of security or health. Most other commodities may be imported from any source. Each licensed commercial importer receives an annual allocation of foreign exchange which may be used freely for the import of any commodity that is not prohibited except automobiles. The allocations are made by the M in i s t ry of Finance and communicated to the Bank of Western Samoa; the latter automatically provides the foreign exchange required for import pay­ ments upon submission of documentary evidence. Per­ sons who are not licensed importers may import any commodity freely up to WS$100 a person a year but require the prior approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance for imports of higher value. The import of automobiles, 1 Western Samoa became a member of the International Monetary Fund on December 28, 1971. whether for business or personal use, is subject to spe­ cific approval on a case-by-case basis by the M in is t ry of Finance. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles are approved auto­ matically by the Bank of Western Samoa up to any amount or within limits determined by the M in is t ry of Finance. Payments in excess of these limits as well as payments for a ll other invisibles require the prior approval of the M in is try of Finance. Remittances in respect of study abroad are freely authorized up to the equivalent of WS$600 a student. The Bank of Western Samoa approves up to any amount the transfer of genuine income derived locally from pensions, rents, interests, and dividends by persons permanently resident overseas. Residents traveling to Amer ican Samoa, whether for business or private purposes, are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to US$50 a person a quarter; an additional allowance of US$15 a day is provided to cover hotel expenses. The basic travel allowance for other countries is equivalent to WS$10 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$ 1,000. Resident travelers may take out foreign banknotes, as part of their foreign currency allowance, up to WS$20 a person a trip. Resident and nonresident travelers may take out any amount in domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds V i r tua l ly a ll exports require the prior approval of the M in is t ry of Finance. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agriculture on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic shortages. Cop ra exports are controlled by the Cop ra Boa rd. Export proceeds must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa within a specified time after shipment. A ll exports are subject to export duties rang­ ing from 5 to 10 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles A ll receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Resident travelers must on return sell to the Bank a ll foreign currency brought in. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign and domestic banknotes. Capital A ll outward capital transfers by residents require the specific approval of the M in is t ry of Finance and capital received by residents must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. The transfer of legacies from estates of deceased local residents due to beneficiaries per­ manently residing overseas is approved up to a limit of WS$ 10,000 a year. The Bank of Western Samoa approves transfers of gifts to relatives and dependents, 475 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution W E S T E RN S A M OA either for special family occasions or by way of mainte­ nance, up to WS$200 a year for each family group. Foreign investments in Western Samoa are encouraged. The "Enterprises Incentive A c t" N o. 27 /1965, as amended in 1969, makes provision for the granting of certain relief of customs duties, income tax, and busi­ ness license fees to persons engaged in approved enter­ prises. Both the repatriation of capital and profit remittances on foreign capital are subject to approval by the Minister of Finance; such approval is normally granted. Not for Redistribution Y EM EN ARAB REPUBL IC Exchange Rate System The currency of the Yemen A r ab Republic is the Yemen R i a l, which is issued by the Central Bank of Yemen. No par value has been established with the F u n d. A ll transactions take place in a free market at a fluctuating exchange rate; on December 23, 1971 the rate for the U. S. dollar was about Y R ls 4.69 per U S $ 1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered on behalf of the M in is ter of Economy by the Central Bank of Yemen, which has the authority to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports. The only commercial banks and authorized dealers are the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development ( Y B R D) and two branches of foreign commercial banks. Prescription of Currency Settlements under bilateral payments arrangements 1 are made in the currencies and through the accounts provided for by these arrangements. Otherwise, settle­ ments are usually made in pounds sterling or U. S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel are prohibited. Imports of a few commodities are reserved for the Government. A ll other imports require import licenses. These are in principle issued in accordance with a list of authorized imports which was established by Decree N o. 1 of January 1969 and is reviewed periodically, but licenses are issued freely for a ll commodities for which government agen­ cies do not have the exclusive right of importation. Importers who have obtained an import license may obtain the necessary foreign exchange from the free market. Imports that are financed by the importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad do not require an import license. In addition to the applicable customs duty, imports are subject to a defense tax of 5 per cent ad valorem and a statistical tax of 2 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles A ll payments in respect of invisibles require an exchange license issued by the Central Bank. Remit­ tances of savings by expatriates are permitted up to 50 per cent of annual salary. Resident nationals may remit up to the equivalent of £ stg. 30 a ch i ld a month for educational purposes. Foreign exchange for medical treatment abroad is freely granted. F or tourist travel, the Central Bank authorizes foreign exchange 1 The Yemen Arab Republic maintains a bilateral payments arrange­ ment with Egypt. according to the merits of the application. F or business travel, authorization is freely granted. In principle, travelers require the prior authorization of the Central Bank to take out Yemen currency in excess of Y R ls 200 or any foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. A ll exports require export licenses. Exporters are in principle required to surrender the foreign exchange proceeds within three months from shipment. In practice, the surrender requirement for exports of cotton, coffee, salt, and hides and skins is 50 per cent, payable within three months from shipment; the remaining 50 per cent may be kept by the exporter as a foreign currency deposit with a commercial bank and may be used freely for authorized transactions. Proceeds from qat exports are subject to 100 per cent surrender in Yemeni dinars w i th in 15 days from shipment, a 5 per cent in i t ial deposit having to be made at the Y B RD upon receipt of the license. Other exports (comprising mainly fruits, fish, and tobacco) are not subject to surrender requirements in cash terms, but the proceeds must be used fully for importing food, and an in i t ial r ial deposit of 5 per cent of the export value is required. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered but citizens of the Yemen A rab Republic may maintain foreign currency deposit accounts with commercial banks. In principle, the import of foreign exchange (whether in the form of gold, silver, currency, or drafts) and of banknotes of the Yemen A rab Republic requires the prior authorization of the Central Bank, but foreign nationals and nonresidents are exempt from these provisions. Capital A ll capital transfers require prior approval and capi­ tal proceeds must be surrendered. Both domestic and foreign investment are regulated by Law N o. 13 of 1970. Foreign investors in the Yemen A r ab Republic are free to transfer abroad any desired proportion of their net profits after taxes or their capital. Gold A 20-rial gold coin has been issued, which is not legal tender and does not circulate in the Yemen A r ab Repub l ic. Dealings in gold are governed by Regula­ tion N o. 5 of 1967. The Regulation stipulates that, apart from dealings for numismatic or ornamental purposes, residents may not deal in gold except with the authori­ zation of the M in is ter of Economy. Residents coming into possession of gold (other than ornaments or 477 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAV IA Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0481478 gram of fine gold per Yugoslav D inar. The effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar is D in 17.00 = US $ 1. There is no exchange market. The Na t ional Bank quotes rates for leading convertible currencies on the basis of their rates against the U. S. dollar in international centers. On Decem­ ber 31, 1971 the Na t ional Bank's buying and selling rates for the U. S. dollar were D in 17.00 and D in 17.15. Administration of Control On the basis of laws governing these matters, the Federal Executive Counc il prescribes the general pro­ visions in respect of foreign trade and exchange trans­ actions. The Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade, by virtue of these general provisions, establishes rules and regulations, makes decisions governing commercial transactions, and issues import and export licenses when required. It is also charged with securing balanced trade with payments agreement countries. The Federal Sec­ retariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange transactions. This Secretariat and the Na t ional Bank of Yugoslavia administer the exchange control. The Na t ional Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and from foreign countries; it also licenses compensation transactions. A ll foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the Na t ional Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. F u l ly authorized banks, which must have a minimum foreign exchange credit fund equivalent to US$2 m i l l ion and an annual exchange turnover of at least US$80 m i l l ion, may engage in all foreign exchange transactions in Yugo­ slavia and abroad, as well as in foreign credit operations (including the granting of guarantees). L im i ted author­ ized banks, which must have a minimum foreign exchange credit fund equivalent to US$400,000, may conduct foreign exchange operations in Yugoslavia only; they may neither keep foreign exchange accounts abroad nor engage in foreign credit operations, except through the intermediary of a fully authorized credit bank. Au thor ized exchange offices may only deal in foreign banknotes and travelers checks; this status is open to a ll commercial and savings banks. Commerc ial exports and imports may be effected by a ll economic organizations (both producing and trading undertakings) registered for this purpose with district courts. Registration is effected automatically, provided that certain conditions, including the provision of minimum working capital for trade enterprises, are fu l­ filled. Economic organizations that are not registered to conduct foreign trade channel their orders through economic organizations which export and /or import on their own behalf. 4 82 Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Yugo­ slavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set forth in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Yugos lav ia has payments agreements requiring settlements through bilateral accounts as follows: (1) in U . S. dollars with Afghanistan, A lban ia, A lge r ia, B r a z i l, Bulgaria, Czecho­ slovakia, Eastern Germany, Ghana, Greece, Hungary, Mongo l ia, Po land ,. Rumania, and the U. S. S. R .; and (2) in their respective currencies w i th India and Iraq. Certain settlements with Co lomb ia, Mex ico, and P a k i­ stan take place through special accounts. A degree of multilateralization of payments is provided under the bilateral payments agreements with Afghanistan and Iraq. Nonresident Accounts Foreign jur id ical and physical persons may maintain accounts denominated in foreign exchange and in dinars in Yugoslavia according to the following rules. Foreigners resident outside Yugos lav ia may freely open accounts in convertible currencies in Yugos lav ia. F o r­ eign missions and foreigners resident in Yugos lav ia may freely open with authorized banks accounts expressed in foreign currencies or dinars .1 Foreign exchange accounts in convertible currencies of nonresident jur id ical and physical persons are kept in the currency deposited.2 Balances on these accounts may be used for all payments in Yugos lav ia, in dinars or in the currency concerned, and abroad, in any con­ vertible currency. Transfers from these accounts are free if made in the currency in which the account is kept; outward transfers in other convertible currencies are subject to the account-holding bank's being pre­ pared to make the necessary conversion. Nonresident foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be opened only for foreign jur id ical and physical persons resident in Yugoslavia and subject to prior approval by the Na t ional Bank. Balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugos lav ia or for retransfer to the bilateral country to wh ich the account is related. Nonresident jur id ical and physical persons may also open dinar accounts with authorized banks. Imports and Import Payments Comme rc ial imports may be effected only by economic organizations registered as participating in foreign trade. In addition to economic organizations specializing in foreign trade, most major industrial producers are registered. The import of certain basic foodstuffs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, edible o i l, and sugar, is carried out by economic organizations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, on the basis of public bids. F or most commodities, import licenses are not required. A ll commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in four categories according to the manner in which exchange is made available: LB — l ib e r a l i z ed goods; GDK — g o o ds imported under 3 Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Poland, Rumania, and U. S. S. R. 4 Algeria, Afghanistan, Brazil, Greece, India, and Iraq. Y U G O S L A V IA global exchange quotas; RK and DK —goods subject to individual quotas ( RK if individual quotas are fixed by quantity and DK if they are fixed in d inars); and D— imports subject to ad hoc licensing. About 1,850 items (out of a total of over 4,500) are classified under L B; protective equipment for workers and a ll other goods not specifically included in the G D K, R K, D K, or D lists are also liberalized and free from any quantitative restriction. LB goods are mainly raw materials, foodstuffs, and spare parts; they also include some consumer goods. In 1971 goods currently imported under the LB regime accounted for about 29 per cent of total imports. Exchange for payments for LB imports from the convertible currency area is made available freely in any convertible currency appropriate to the exporting country. Payments for imports of l ib­ eralized goods from payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant pay­ ments agreement and may be restricted according to the availability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. The G DK list comprises most consumer goods, most raw materials, and most capital equipment. In 1971 imports of commodities presently on this list amounted to about 46 per cent of total imports. Such imports can be made under several different procedures. Those for nonconsumer goods are as follows. Each importer of raw materials and other reproduction materials receives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to purchase any such goods listed as G D K. F or certain imports by the metal-working, shipbuilding, electrical, and textile industries the authority to use the allocated foreign exchange quota is dependent on the exports that the importers have made (import-export l ink ing ) .5 Ma jor exporters, i.e., export­ ers whose exports settled in convertible currency account for more than 51 per cent of their total sales proceeds, are permitted to pay freely for imports of raw materials and other reproduction materials for their own needs. Payment for imports of capital goods on the G DK list may be financed from specific exchange allocations; a considerable portion may be freely financed from retention quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low), funds originat­ ing in depreciation allowances, and credits obtained abroad, including suppliers' credits. The specific exchange allocations are limited mainly to large invest­ ment projects, including public utilities; the amounts are determined by the Federal Assembly. Econom ic organizations may acquire foreign exchange not exceed­ ing 10 per cent of their annual depreciation allowance. Certain services may use percentages varying between 30 per cent (ocean and river shipping) and 100 per cent (air transportation). One half of the exchange thus allocated is in convertible and one half in bilateral currency. Imports under commodity quotas (list RK or list This system is also applied to certain DK imports. 483 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Y U G O S L A V IA D K ), mainly selected agricultural and mineral products (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also cigars, cigarettes, and machine tools, are subject to maximum quotas established for each commodity and cannot be imported under any other procedure. The quotas are established either in physical quantities ( R K) or in dinars ( D K ). F or a ll 93 items, the Secretariat may prescribe direct importation from the country of or ig in; these items include a wide range of tropical foodstuffs and fruits, raw materials, fats, oils, and textiles, as well as tin and raw cotton. Private persons who are Yugoslav nationals and hold foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks may use these funds freely to import goods intended for their own use or for the use of close relatives, regard­ less of the import regime for the goods. A l s o, Yugo­ slavs returning from work abroad may import goods intended for their personal needs or the needs of their own household, provided that such goods were paid for from the savings from their foreign earnings; such sav­ ings need not be kept on foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of foreign exchange accounts and Yugoslav nationals working abroad may only import motorcars, trucks, motorcycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together with mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, through a registered enterprise, provided that payment is made through a foreign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. Yugoslav and foreign nationals are exempt from this prescribed manner of payment and method of importation, however, under the following c ircum­ stances: when they return for permanent residence in Yugos lav ia, provided that they have spent at least five years abroad; when a vehicle is inherited; when a motor vehicle is purchased out of an insurance indem­ nity received for a motor vehicle that has been destroyed and had originally been paid for in foreign currency; and if they have spent at least two years abroad con­ tinuously and have owned a vehicle for at least two years. Yugoslav citizens returning from a tourist trip abroad may import any amount of goods intended for the needs of their household. However, if the value of the goods exceeds D in 1,000, these goods must be handed over, at the customs office at the point of entry, to a domestic forwarder for delivery to the owner's address; such delivery cannot be made unless the cus­ toms duties are paid. Compensation transactions are only authorized in exceptional circumstances; in 1971 they accounted for less than 1 per cent of total imports. Importers are required to notify authorized banks of a ll payments abroad of more than the equivalent of US$5 ,000 7 one month before the payments fall due. At this time 8 they are also required to deposit with an authorized bank an amount in dinars equal in value to the import order. The deposits are not interest bearing and they are used to purchase the foreign exchange for the import payment. Deposits are not required for payments made by debiting foreign exchange accounts of importers. M any agricultural commodities and foodstuffs are subject to variable import levies. A 1 per cent special tax for customs evidence and a 3 per cent equalization tax are payable on a ll commodities not exempt from customs duty; in addition, an import surcharge of 6 per cent of the c.i.f. value at the border has to be paid for a ll commodities. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise trans­ actions, including transportation, are fully liberalized. Exchange to cover export promotion expenses abroad is made freely available to exporters. Pensions, wages, and salaries are transferable under certain conditions. Pay­ ments in respect of royalties and alimony granted by court order are freely transferable, but if a payment is to be made to a country with wh ich Yugos lav ia main­ tains bilateral payments arrangements, then such pay­ ments may be made only if the agreement in question provides for this to be done. The Na t ional Bank may sell foreign currency up to the equivalent of US$32 for 6 In principle, any such allocation among importers must be agreed upon among economic organizations within the Federal Economic Chamber. If the importers are unable to agree among themselves, the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade is authorized to decide on the distribution. Imports of coffee, wheat, sugar, rice, and salt for final consumption are administered by the State Food Administration, which is authorized to select the most competitive importer from among registered importers. 7 However, for imports of certain raw materials only payments of more than US$100,000 are governed by this regulation, and no dinar advance deposit is required. y The implementing rules are such that deposits for payments in non- convertible currencies for imports from the bilateral area may be made less than one month before payments fall due. The average effec­ tive deposit period for all payments has been 15-20 days. 484 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution remittances for court and other fees abroad and for specified personal expenses. The Na t ional Bank may sell any amount of foreign exchange for certain unspecified purposes and in justified cases. There is a basic annual exchange allowance of the equivalent of US$32 for each person over 14 for tourist travel abroad (abolished on January 1, 1972). Travel agencies may obtain special exchange allocations to enable them to sell organized tours abroad against pay­ ment in dinars. The Na t ional Bank may also authorize travel agencies to sell foreign exchange for both group and ind iv idual travel in amounts exceeding the equiv­ alent of US$32. The exchange is provided in the form of travelers checks and cash. Payments for other invisibles may be made from the remittor's own foreign exchange funds (e.g., from retention quotas, or, when made by various social and socio-political organizations, from specific annual allocations); when such exchange is not available, payments for invisibles that have not been liberalized are subject to the approval of the Na t ional Bank. N ot more than D in 100, in denominations of D in 10 or less,9 may be taken out by travelers. Foreign travelers may bring in and take out any amount in foreign exchange without declaring it. Exports and Export Proceeds In principle, exports are free of control, except for certain raw materials that are in short supply on the domestic market, inc lud ing copper and certain other materials such as gunpowder, weapons, and narcotic drugs. Exports to countries with which Yugoslavia has a bilateral payments agreement are subject to approval by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. Such approval may be given for a group of commodities or for all commodities to be exported w i th in a certain period (global approva l). Permission to export to bilateral countries may be made conditional on an undertaking to import from such countries. In accord­ ance with bilateral arrangements, Yugos lav ia restrains exports of certain commodities to France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Sweden, and the Un i ted States. Proceeds from exports must be repatriated w i th in 90 days from the date of exportation, unless specific approval is granted to deviate from this rule. The surrender of these proceeds is not required. The fu ll export proceeds may be credited to foreign exchange sight deposit accounts which the exporter maintains with an authorized bank of his choice; separate accounts must be established for each currency. Exchange on these accounts may either be used, subject to the rele­ vant regulations, for payments for imports and invisibles or be sold to an authorized bank. Retention quotas may be used to pay for imports of certain consumer goods if such imports are made by economic organizations that are in the catering and tourist industries or are engaged 9 Raised to Din 500, in denominations of Din 50 or less, on Janu­ ary 1, 1972. Y U G O S L A V IA in setting up trade fairs, and by film enterprises; such imports are also permitted as consignment stocks. The part of the export proceeds that remains at the free disposal of the exporter for payments abroad is referred to as the retention quota; the remainder may be retained indefinitely but can only be used to import liberalized raw materials and cannot earn interest. The retention quotas may also be placed on interest-bearing time deposit accounts with authorized banks. The per­ mitted retention rates vary according to the type of export concerned, the share of exports in total sales of the economic organization concerned, and the increase in exports achieved over the past year; the basic rate is 7 per cent but for many economic organizations the actually permitted rate is much higher, the other fixed rates being 10, 12, 20, 50, 60, and 100 per cent and the rate for most organizations being on a progressive scale. In some instances (foreign tourist services, sales of newly mined gold to the Na t ional B a n k ), sales against pay­ ment in dinars are regarded as exports for retention quota purposes. Producing enterprises selling consumer goods in Yugoslavia for foreign currency may retain 50 per cent of the foreign exchange thus earned (reduced to 15 per cent with effect from January 1, 1972). Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated within 90 days from the date on which the claim is payable but need not be surrendered in fu l l. Various retention quota rates apply to receipts from services. Exchange proceeds may be used for payments abroad connected w i th the activities of the economic organizations concerned, including payments for purchases of equipment and other material for its own needs. The retained exchange is not transferable to economic organizations other than those with which the recipients are cooperating in technical and business matters, but it can always be sold to authorized banks. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual import procedures apply. Resi­ dents who, while employed abroad, deposited their sav­ ings in foreign savings banks and obtained a "savings book," may withdraw their balances in the form of foreign exchange when in Yugoslavia. Residents may hold interest-bearing foreign currency accounts in Yugoslavia. The accounts may be credited with the fu ll amount of a person's savings from per diem allowances, salaries, and other earnings abroad, from fellowships, and from royalties. They may also be credited with the full amount of foreign exchange accru­ ing from inheritances, indemnities, insurance, and similar compensations up to an amount equivalent to D in 136,000 per transaction; for amounts in excess of this figure, 50 per cent of the excess may be placed to the credit of the account and 50 per cent must be surrendered. In respect of pensions, disabled persons' allowances, alimony, and grants received from abroad, up to 30 per cent of the total amount received may be placed to the credit of a foreign 485 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Y U G O S L A V IA exchange account and 70 per cent must be surrendered. These accounts may be used freely for the personal needs of the account holder and of close members of his family; they are not transferable to other persons or accounts and may be retained for an indefinite period of time. Retail sales of manufactured goods by authorized trade organizations to foreign tourists in Yugos lav ia paying in foreign exchange are made at a discount of 10 per cent, representing the exemption from turnover taxes. This discount is granted only on purchases in authorized shops against checks expressed in foreign currencies or against certain foreign banknotes. Not more than D in 200 in Yugoslav banknotes, in denominations of D in 10 or less ,10 may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign loans and credits may be freely contracted by fully authorized banks and economic organizations, up to a specified percentage of their foreign exchange credit fund, their retention quotas, or their foreign exchange amortization allocations. Foreign loans and credits must be recorded with the Na t ional Bank. Loans must ord i­ narily be repaid with foreign exchange that is either obtained by the economic organization as export reten­ tion quotas and foreign exchange amortization alloca­ tions or acquired from banks according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime. Credits in the latter category are trade credits usually up to 360 days matu­ r i ty; counterpart payments in dinars must be made according to the Na t ional Bank regulations in force at the time. In 1971 the requirement in the case of LB imports was 50 per cent down and 50 per cent after three months; for G DK imports, 70 per cent was pay­ able immediately and the remainder within six months. F or import credits guaranteed by Yugoslav commercial banks, there is a required deposit in foreign exchange with the Na t ional Bank of 10 per cent, wh ich yields no interest and is held to maturity of the loan. In the case of guaranteed financial credits, the deposit requirement is 20 per cent. A ll other transfers of a capital nature by residents or nonresidents require individual licenses. Foreigners may invest in certain Yugoslav economic organizations but only through joint ventures; such for­ eign investment is limited to 49 per cent of the organi­ zation's capital. Profit transfers abroad may be financed from the retention quota, and in addition profit trans­ fers are permitted up to one third of the joint venture's foreign currency earnings from exports of goods and services. Foreign firms are permitted to establish repre­ sentational offices in Yugoslavia. Foreign ju r id ical and physical persons are permitted to purchase bonds issued by Yugoslav enterprises, socio-political commu­ nities, and other socio-legal persons. 10 Raised to Din 500, in denominations of Din 50 or less, on Janu­ ary 1, 1972. 486 The investment income of Yugoslav economic organi­ zations earned abroad is subject neither to repatriation nor to surrender requirements. If repatriated, however, the profits are governed by the regulations for retention quotas. Residents are obliged to repatriate and, w i th the exception of inheritances, to surrender a ll foreign exchange held or accruing abroad on capital account. Cap i tal transfers abroad by residents are usually not approved, but economic organizations participating in foreign enterprises may be allowed by the Federal Secre­ tariat for Fore ign Trade and the Federal Secretariat for Finance to export the necessary capital. A decision of the Federal Executive Coun c il of Octo­ ber 14, 1955 requires the Yugoslav authorities to con­ tinue to permit the remittance of inheritances to citizens of the Un i ted States, provided that the remittance is requested w i th in three years from the date of distribution of the estate. Gold The Na t ional Bank has issued certain commemorative gold coins, which are not legal tender. Residents who are private persons may hold gold coins in Yugos lav ia, which may be sold to the Na t ional Bank of Yugos lav ia or to any authorized bank, and they may freely ho ld, purchase, import, and sell gold jewelry and other arti­ cles of gold. Domestic economic organizations that have been registered as trading in gold may import gold jew­ elry under the G DK import regime; they may freely export gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Au tho r­ ized banks may freely export gold coins. Sales of newly mined gold to the Na t ional Bank against payment in dinars (calculated by applying the D in 17 per U. S. do l­ lar rate to a price of US$35 an ounce) are regarded as exports and entitle the seller to a retention quota in con­ vertible foreign exchange. Other domestic sales of newly mined gold by the producers may be made at a price wh ich equals the average quotation in free gold markets abroad. Domestic economic organizations using gold for their normal activities may purchase gold from domestic producers or abroad on the basis of quotas allocated to each ind iv idua l ly.
